('40', 0, 1, 2, 47) 1. LETTER TO BAL KALELKAR
('40', 0, 2, 3, 73) ARNI, September 2, 1927
('40', 0, 3, 4, 97) BAL, I got your letter and liked it very much.
('40', 0, 3, 5, 144) I could not reply immediately for want of time.
('40', 0, 3, 6, 192) I shall answer two of your questions.
('40', 0, 3, 7, 230) A brahmachari sacrifices all pleasures merely through faith or in obedience to his parents or a custom.
('40', 0, 3, 8, 334) There is obedience in his sacrifice, but not knowledge.
('40', 0, 3, 9, 390) And if he cannot bring himself to make for ever that sacrifice, he has freedom to enjoy pleasures within limits after completing his studies.
('40', 0, 3, 10, 532) A sannyasi makes the same sacrifice knowingly and willingly.
('40', 0, 3, 11, 593) He does not and cannot keep it open for him to return to pleasures after having abjured them.
('40', 0, 3, 12, 687) Both types of sacrifice are very essential to individuals as well as to society.
('40', 0, 3, 13, 768) Now the second question.
('40', 0, 3, 14, 793) Non violence means not harming anyone in thought, word or action out of ill will or selfishness.
('40', 0, 3, 15, 890) If we wish or do ill to any stranger in the interests of our parents, that is violence.
('40', 0, 3, 16, 978) We can see and prove with the help of our know ledge that wishing or doing ill benefits neither the world nor our parents.
('40', 0, 3, 17, 1101) Hence I had written that it was my belief we dis cover nonviolence the moment we realize that its root is to be found in wishing well to the world as much as to ourselves.
('40', 0, 3, 18, 1273) You will thus see that we can of course prove independently that one should wish well to the world, but if we abide by the dharma of non violence the responsibility to wish well to the world as well devolves on us even in pursuance of that dharma.
('40', 0, 3, 19, 1521) If we understand this from our very childhood, our reason would admit it and the heart too would like it.
('40', 0, 3, 20, 1627) That is to say, if we continue for ever the sacrifice which we have undertaken in good faith during the stage of brahmacharya we become sannyasis.
('40', 0, 3, 21, 1774) Shankaracharya did this in the past.
('40', 0, 3, 22, 1811) Dayanada did it in our own age.
('40', 0, 3, 23, 1843) That we all cannot do so is due to our shortcoming and that constitutes an obstacle to doing good to the world.
('40', 0, 3, 24, 1955) But we cannot do such things merely by exercising our reasoning.
('40', 0, 3, 25, 2020) But if, with the help of our intellect, we imprint it day after day on our hearts and if it gets so imprinted, the whole world will not, even if it tried, be able to stop us from sacrificing our all.
('40', 0, 3, 26, 2220) If any special problems arise, do tell me.
('40', 0, 3, 27, 2263) Read this to all the pupils if you can.
('40', 0, 3, 28, 2303) [From Gujarati]
('40', 0, 4, 29, 2319) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('40', 0, 4, 30, 2365) Courtesy: Narayan Desai

('40', 1, 1, 2, 2429) 2. SPEECH AT ARNI 1
('40', 1, 2, 3, 2449) September 2, 1927 You love to get a little bit of a rag, or cocoanut, or anything that you can get as prasadam from temples from which, alas, all holiness has fled.
('40', 1, 2, 4, 2614) I would ask you to transfer that spirit of humility and devotion to khaddar which is spun and woven in the living temple of Daridranarayana.
('40', 1, 2, 5, 2755) Our temples have their proper place in our religion and society only in so far they enable us to reach out the hand of fellowship to the starving millions of India.
('40', 1, 2, 6, 2920) But these very temples will be the instruments of forging our shackles if they become impassable barriers between the masses and us.
('40', 1, 2, 7, 3053) If you will wear khaddar in true spirit you will purify yourselves and the temples.
('40', 1, 2, 8, 3137) I need not explain to you now, how the removal of untouchability necessarily follows from this proposition.
('40', 1, 2, 9, 3245) Young India, 8 9 1927
('40', 1, 3, 10, 3267) 3. SPEECH AT ARCOT
('40', 1, 4, 11, 3286) September 2, 1927 I am very thankful for the cordial reception and for the purse you have given me, but I am not satisfied with this amount.
('40', 1, 4, 12, 3427) I know that there are many in this gathering who have not contributed to the Fund which is intended for our poor brethren.
('40', 1, 4, 13, 3550) You must encourage spinning by wearing khaddar.
('40', 1, 4, 14, 3598) I am very glad to find here that the Hindus and the Mussalmans have met together in mutual co operation unlike in the North where communal hatred is prevailing.
('40', 1, 4, 15, 3759) Yesterday when I had been to a Hindu temple on my way I was given the prasad by the gurukkal 2. I told him that I am a pariah and asked him whether he would allow a pariah inside the temple.
('40', 1, 4, 16, 3950) He laughed at me and said that he would do it gradually.
('40', 1, 4, 17, 4007) I appeal to all men and women who have assembled here to treat the so called pariah as our equal and move with him freely.
('40', 1, 4, 18, 4130) Since I find no place to have this silver plate, I shall have it auctioned.
('40', 1, 4, 19, 4206) Volunteers will come in your midst for collection and you

('40', 2, 2, 5, 4530) 4. LETTER TO BALWANTRAI MEHTA
('40', 2, 3, 6, 4560) [After September 2, 1927] 1
('40', 2, 4, 7, 4588) I have your letter.
('40', 2, 4, 8, 4608) You may rest assured that I shall not take a decision hastily.
('40', 2, 4, 9, 4671) I am now conveying all my doubts to everyone who should know them and am seeking assistance in coming to a decision.
('40', 2, 4, 10, 4788) I make no distinction between K and Devdas.
('40', 2, 4, 11, 4832) It is no pleasure to me to entertain any suspicion about K. K. and K are in fact related to me as children.
('40', 2, 4, 12, 4940) Hence it is not at all possible that I shall decide anything in haste.
('40', 2, 4, 13, 5011) Your argument does not appeal to me.
('40', 2, 4, 14, 5048) You may know that I myself am a proof before you that sex does not discriminate bet ween the young and the old.
('40', 2, 4, 15, 5160) Even today I have to erect all sorts of walls around me for the sake of safety.
('40', 2, 4, 16, 5240) Despite this, I was in danger of succumbing a few years ago.
('40', 2, 4, 17, 5301) Moreover, sexual desire does not bother about time either.
('40', 2, 4, 18, 5360) Despite our belief that Bhai K’s ideas about brahmacharya, etc., were pure it is no wonder if ultimately he succumbed to desire.
('40', 2, 4, 19, 5489) A young man whose case was almost similar confessed to me in Bangalore.
('40', 2, 4, 20, 5561) He is regarded as a brahmachari.
('40', 2, 4, 21, 5594) He is a darling of his family.
('40', 2, 4, 22, 5625) No one can suspect him as things stand.
('40', 2, 4, 23, 5665) He studies in the intermediate class.
('40', 2, 4, 24, 5703) He has not been able to save himself from a widow who is related to him.
('40', 2, 4, 25, 5776) He came to me saying, “Save me from this fever.” Despite having sworn to a friend, he fell again.
('40', 2, 4, 26, 5874) Hence he sought refuge in me.
('40', 2, 4, 27, 5904) What refuge could I provide?
('40', 2, 4, 28, 5933) But that is a digression.
('40', 2, 5, 29, 5959) What I have learnt is this: K had closer relations with K and her family than warranted.
('40', 2, 5, 30, 6048) Both were reprimanded and both were convinced.
('40', 2, 5, 31, 6095) Both agreed not to have such intimacy.
('40', 2, 5, 32, 6134) In spite of this, they were seen secretly meeting each other.
('40', 2, 5, 33, 6196) So Maganlal went on a fast.
('40', 2, 5, 34, 6224) Notwithstanding this, they again met secretly.
('40', 2, 5, 35, 6271) If my information is correct, I cannot get over my doubt.
('40', 2, 5, 36, 6329) And if K has committed this slip such a man can in no time succumb to temptations of money.
('40', 2, 6, 37, 6421) 1 The source has this letter after the entries for September 2.
('40', 3, 0, 1, 6485) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 3, 1, 2, 6525) these are all my inferences based on a single premise.
('40', 3, 1, 3, 6580) I cannot but have all sorts of doubt about a person who acts with deliberate dishonesty.
('40', 3, 1, 4, 6669) I am still investigating.
('40', 3, 1, 5, 6695) I am not unaware of Maganlal’s opinion which you quote.
('40', 3, 1, 6, 6751) You are also aware that I have great confidence in his judgment.
('40', 3, 1, 7, 6816) I shall write to him too.
('40', 3, 2, 8, 6842) Now the question that either you or his father should reimburse the amount, if K has embezzled any, does not arise at all.
('40', 3, 2, 9, 6965) I am considering only the ethical aspect of this question.
('40', 3, 2, 10, 7024) Whatever I shall now write for Navajivan cannot but reflect my doubt; hence if you let me have some draft I shall consider and publish it, if I can.
('40', 3, 2, 11, 7173) I have not made light of suicides.
('40', 3, 2, 12, 7208) I know of only two occasions when suicide becomes a duty.
('40', 3, 2, 13, 7266) There are many grounds for that opinion.
('40', 3, 2, 14, 7307) A man who is helpless against indulgence and cannot control himself but has sense enough to bring about his end ought to do so.
('40', 3, 2, 15, 7435) That would be his dharma.
('40', 3, 2, 16, 7461) Likewise, when a beast of a man attempts to criminally assault a woman, it is her duty to save herself by committing suicide.
('40', 3, 2, 17, 7587) Indeed I have very often quoted these two instances in the Ashram.
('40', 3, 2, 18, 7654) And I think it is only proper.
('40', 3, 2, 19, 7685) Even if K has committed all the three faults mentioned above, as far as the tenets of the Ashram are concerned the duty to commit suicide cannot be established nor that of running away.
('40', 3, 2, 20, 7871) Atonement is the only duty in such a case but I know from the many letters K wrote to me that he has always opposed a number of rules observed in the Ashram.

('40', 4, 7, 11, 8600) 7. SPEECH TO LABOUR, PERAVALLUR
('40', 4, 8, 12, 8632) September 3, 1927
('40', 4, 9, 13, 8650) FRIENDS, I thank you for the address and the two purses.
('40', 4, 9, 14, 8707) I congratulate you on having the club 1 whose main object is to advance the cause of khadi.
('40', 4, 9, 15, 8799) The ingenious manner in which you are advocating its cause is worthy of imitation by all of us.
('40', 4, 9, 16, 8895) For a poor man it is the most convenient form of getting a loan free of interest.
('40', 4, 9, 17, 8977) But as in most things in this also the honesty on the part of all members is an indispensable condition.
('40', 4, 9, 18, 9082) As you know, having myself become a labourer and having worked with them in their midst and for them for over 35 years I am deeply interested in everything connected with labour.
('40', 4, 9, 19, 9261) I do not propose just now to deal with the disabilities that labour is labouring under in India and here in particular.
('40', 4, 9, 20, 9381) As a matter of fact I know noth ing of your special hardship and special conditions.
('40', 4, 9, 21, 9466) At the present moment what I wish to lay the greatest stress upon is what labour can do for itself.
('40', 4, 9, 22, 9566) The one curse with which it is afflicted from within is the terrible drink habit.
('40', 4, 9, 23, 9648) If labourers do not get rid of it betimes they will be digging their own graves.
('40', 4, 9, 24, 9729) When the drink habit possesses a man it turns him into a beast.
('40', 4, 9, 25, 9793) He knows no distinction between the sister and his wife.
('40', 4, 9, 26, 9850) I therefore advise you all to give up drink.
('40', 4, 9, 27, 9895) I know what a
('40', 4, 10, 28, 9909) 1 Gandhi Club
('40', 5, 0, 1, 9923) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 5, 1, 2, 9963) severe temptation it is for a man who is once given to drink; but God has given man the capacity, if he will only use it, for conquering such defects and temptations.
('40', 5, 1, 3, 10130) The other defect which I have found amongst the labourers is that they have no consciousness of the strength which is possessed by combination.
('40', 5, 1, 4, 10274) Labourers must learn to consider that the welfare of all is the welfare of the individual.
('40', 5, 1, 5, 10365) You must therefore cultivate amongst yourselves a real brotherly spirit.
('40', 5, 1, 6, 10438) I have known that in many parts of India labourers squander their money in gambling.
('40', 5, 1, 7, 10523) It is a vicious habit and you should give it up.
('40', 5, 1, 8, 10572) The morale amongst the labourers in some parts of India is also not all as it should be.
('40', 5, 1, 9, 10661) If as labourers we want to become a recognized force in the Indian society and in the political world also, it is absolutely necessary for us to recognize the binding tie of marriage and all the obligations that that tie imposes upon us.
('40', 5, 1, 10, 10899) I have congratulated you upon having this club for the advancement of khadi.
('40', 5, 1, 11, 10976) But instead of there being a hundred members in that club every one of you should belong to it.
('40', 5, 1, 12, 11072) Remember that khadi binds us to those who are much poorer than yourselves.
('40', 5, 1, 13, 11147) To throw away the foreign cloth or even your millmade cloth costs you nothing but the simple thought on behalf of the starving millions of people who are living in our villages.
('40', 5, 1, 14, 11325) It has given me great pleasure to lay the foundation stone 1 which I have just laid over the place there.
('40', 5, 1, 15, 11431) May God help you to do the things I have suggested to you.
('40', 5, 1, 16, 11490) If you will but do these things, you will find that the majority of your difficulties will disappear without any further efforts.
('40', 5, 1, 17, 11620) The Hindu, 5 9 1927

('40', 6, 1, 11, 13548) The lesson that it should carry to you is that having given your mite to this purse, you should study the condition of these millions of villagers, in order to fit you all the better for their service.

('40', 6, 1, 14, 14026) I hope that the students also know and realize that the education is paid for out of the drink and drug revenue.

('40', 6, 2, 16, 14222) I suggest then that you should render ceaseless service to these starving millions and that you should not be satisfied till this gnawing poverty is banished from our land.
('40', 6, 2, 17, 14395) And, I have told you that khaddar is the easiest and the only way.
('40', 6, 2, 18, 14462) I ask you not to allow your minds to be befogged by all kinds of specious reasoning that will be advanced against the spinning wheel and against khadi in these days of rush for machinery.

('40', 8, 2, 6, 18225) 9. AFTER THE FLOODS
('40', 8, 3, 7, 18245) From the letters which I received regarding the flood relief work and from the reports in Navajivan I observe that volunteers are doing their work conscientiously showing no signs of exhaustion.
('40', 8, 3, 8, 18440) But I have formed the impression that all of us are not accustomed to doing physical work, that we feel aversion against certain types of work and that certain things are left undone or delayed or done with too much expense because we do not know how to do them.
('40', 8, 3, 9, 18703) For example, I read the following in reports by some volunteers which are lying with me.
('40', 8, 4, 10, 18792) The wells in this place stink.
('40', 8, 5, 11, 18823) The basin at the top of the well in this place is about to crumble.
('40', 8, 6, 12, 18891) A buffalo has fallen into the well here and the water stinks with the smell of her rotting body.
('40', 8, 6, 13, 18988) But the poor Bhangis still use it.
('40', 8, 7, 14, 19023) The grain which is rotting in this place gives off foul smell.
('40', 8, 7, 15, 19086) The people dig up even that and eat it.
('40', 8, 8, 16, 19126) We found the Bhangis here lazy.
('40', 8, 8, 17, 19158) They do not work even when asked.
('40', 8, 8, 18, 19192) I have given these statements from different letters and all of them are not in the words of the writers themselves.
('40', 8, 8, 19, 19309) I have not, however, twisted the writer’s meaning in any of them.
('40', 8, 8, 20, 19375) I think that in our work we should not have one set of people to do the actual work and another to supervise.
('40', 8, 8, 21, 19485) Our poor country can progress only if the supervisors and the workers are the same persons.
('40', 8, 8, 22, 19577) The number of persons who issue orders should be the smallest possible.
('40', 8, 8, 23, 19649) Of course we cannot do without overseers 1 altogether, but we should bear in mind that their function is largely to keep watch
('40', 8, 9, 24, 19776) 1 Gandhiji uses the English word.
('40', 9, 0, 1, 19810) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 9, 1, 2, 19851) against possible malpractices.
('40', 9, 1, 3, 19882) Volunteers, too, need supervision.
('40', 9, 1, 4, 19917) If no supervisor is appointed over a volunteer’s work, he should ask for one to be appointed.
('40', 9, 1, 5, 20011) Even so, our aim should be to get out of this unhappy condition of supervisors having to be appointed.
('40', 9, 1, 6, 20114) In any case, supervisors and others, all should carry hoes and spades wih them.
('40', 9, 1, 7, 20194) If these are not available, they should use their hands as much as possible.
('40', 9, 1, 8, 20271) I would, therefore, expect to receive reports as follows: ‘In village ‘A’, the well emitted a foul smell.

('40', 11, 0, 1, 24698) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 11, 1, 2, 24739) 1. Do not build houses which look like slums.
('40', 11, 1, 3, 24785) 2. Do not use tin sheets.
('40', 11, 1, 4, 24811) 3. Do not imitate America or England, for the climate there is different from ours.
('40', 11, 1, 5, 24895) 4. Use only a minimum of stone and mortar.
('40', 11, 1, 6, 24938) 5. In our country, we can build fine houses with straw, stalks, reeds and finely powdered, moistened earth.
('40', 11, 1, 7, 25046) 6. The site must be cleaned and made level before a house is built.
('40', 11, 1, 8, 25114) 7. There must be proper provision for ventilation.
('40', 11, 1, 9, 25165) 8. If there is enough space, a separate shed should be pro vided for cattle.
('40', 11, 1, 10, 25242) I saw an inexpensive and very hygienic arrange ment for them, which consisted of an enclosure in which they were not tied but were left free.
('40', 11, 1, 11, 25384) A strong fence of sticks or wire could be put up for the purpose.
('40', 11, 1, 12, 25450) There should be a small shed in the enclosure where the cattle can rest when they feel inclined to do so.
('40', 11, 2, 13, 25556) MISCELLANEOUS 1. Do not give people black, foreign caps, even if received as gifts for them.
('40', 11, 2, 14, 25649) A thing which is unacceptable in itself should not be received even as a gift.
('40', 11, 2, 15, 25728) A vegetarian would not accept meat because it was offered to him free.
('40', 11, 2, 16, 25799) 2. Our aim in life is not to live merely for the sake of living.
('40', 11, 2, 17, 25864) It should be, rather, to live for a good end, to awaken the soul sleeping in this body which is its house.
('40', 11, 2, 18, 25971) The difference between dharma and adharma is this: One who follows dharma will refuse to live if he has to violate certain restraints for that purpose.
('40', 11, 2, 19, 26123) One who follows adharma accepts no such restraints.
('40', 11, 2, 20, 26175) He will sell himself, his wife and children and his country in order that he may live.
('40', 11, 2, 21, 26262) 3. A trader may save and may also destroy.
('40', 11, 2, 22, 26305) The merchants of Gujarat are doing both without knowing it.
('40', 11, 2, 23, 26365) I have been observing that there is a shower of foreign and mill cloth.
('40', 11, 2, 24, 26437) Now that the immediate shock of the heavy floods is over, I caution them and the people.
('40', 11, 2, 25, 26526) It is Gujaratis and Marwaris who are responsible for the presence of foreign cloth among us.
('40', 11, 2, 26, 26619) Both these classes of merchants should consider.
('40', 11, 2, 27, 26668) If I were asked to choose between the destruction caused by foreign cloth and that caused by excessive floods, I know which I should choose.
('40', 11, 2, 28, 26809) Let the reader know that one kills the body; this can be borne and is inescapable.
('40', 11, 2, 29, 26892) The other kind of destruction kills the soul
('40', 12, 0, 1, 26937) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 13
('40', 12, 1, 2, 26985) and we can always escape it.
('40', 12, 1, 3, 27014) Who will explain to Gujarat this profound difference between the two kinds of destruction?

('40', 32, 1, 2, 73517) 22. DISCUSSION WITH NEILL STATUE VOLUNTEERS,
('40', 32, 2, 3, 73562) MADRAS September 6 and 7, 1927
('40', 32, 3, 4, 73593) We publish today, with the approval of Mahatma Gandhi, a full report of the Conference which the volunteers of the Neill Statue agitation had with Mahatma Gandhi during his stay in Madras on Tuesday and Wednesday.
('40', 32, 3, 5, 73807) The notes were taken by The Hindu representative and were revised by Mahatma Gandhi.
('40', 32, 4, 6, 73892) Some 20 members of the Tamil Nadu Volunteer Corps who are now en gaged in the agitation for the removal of the Neill Statue from the City on Tuesday afternoon conferred with Mahatma Gandhi on the subject for over an hour.
('40', 32, 4, 7, 74114) The conversations were not over and they were continued the next day.
('40', 32, 5, 8, 74184) Mr. D. Kulandai introduced himself as the leader of these young men and told Mahatmaji how he came into this movement.
('40', 32, 5, 9, 74303) He said he was horrified at the barbarous sentences which were inflicted upon these youths by the Magistrate and he felt it necessary to give his help and advice as a Congressman and a Secretary of the District Congress Committee.
('40', 32, 5, 10, 74534) He was not under any pledge and was not courting arrest.
('40', 32, 6, 11, 74591) GANDHIJI: Are there one or two who have been sentenced to two years’ R.I. in this connection?
('40', 32, 7, 12, 74685) The answer was in the affirmative and Mr. Kulandai added that as a result of their intervention the sentences were not too severe.
('40', 32, 8, 13, 74816) KULANDAI: So far 27 had gone to prison on this issue, two of whom are ladies.
('40', 32, 8, 14, 74894) Most of those had taken part in what was called the Sword Satyagraha at Madura and the total strength of the corps was 200 drawn mainly from Madura and Ramnad districts.
('40', 32, 8, 15, 75064) Who conceived this plan of attacking Neill Statue?
('40', 32, 9, 16, 75115) And the reply was that Somayajulu and Srinivasavaradan were respon sible.
('40', 32, 9, 17, 75189) That was after the failure at Madura?
('40', 32, 10, 18, 75227) A VOLUNTEER: It was not a failure at all.
('40', 32, 10, 19, 75269) We went into the streets freely with our swords and we were not arrested.
('40', 32, 10, 20, 75343) We have thus successfully broken the Arms Act.
('40', 32, 11, 21, 75390) Mahatmaji could not contain his laughter and told them not to delude themselves into thinking that it was a success.
('40', 32, 11, 22, 75507) When the Government saw what you were carrying were merely tin swords and you had no public backing, they left you alone in order not to give you any advertisement; and it is therefore no use in saying that because you were not arrested it is a success to your credit.

('40', 43, 4, 10, 100771) As you may know I am a matriculate, and therefore never had any college education worth the name in India.
('40', 43, 4, 11, 100878) But when after the address was finished and the thanksgiving completed I went out to students who were lying in wait for me and took away from all the copies of the “Green Pamphlet” 5 that I was then circulating throughout India, and it was for the sake of those students that I asked the late Mr. G. ('40', 60, 2, 3, 142906) September 9, 1927
('40', 60, 3, 4, 142924) Mahatmaji first thanked the women of Madras for the welcome they had accorded in him and for the purse.
('40', 60, 3, 5, 143028) Regarding the purse, he said he was not satisfied with the same.
('40', 60, 3, 6, 143093) He also doubted whether all of them who had assembled there knew for what purpose they had given the purse, for it they had realized it they would have given much more.
('40', 60, 3, 7, 143262) The money was not intended to be distributed among a hundred poor for charity but was going to be used for the relief of millions of starving people throughout India.
('40', 60, 3, 8, 143429) He saw round him a large number of ladies with costly jewellery on their persons.
('40', 60, 3, 9, 143511) They would no have realized that one bit of such jewellery would amount to a fortune to the starving millions.

('40', 69, 1, 6, 165728) And the one discovery that I have made is that really speaking, there is no distinction whatsoever between individual growth and corporate growth, that corporate growth is therefore entirely dependent upon individual growth and hence that beautiful proverb in the English language that a chain is no stronger than the weakest link in it.
('40', 69, 1, 7, 166066) And if we realize in its fullness the truth of this homely saying, we would discover that no single lad in this assembly may hope to isolate himself from others and consider himself above them.

('40', 69, 1, 9, 166401) And some of them domineered over the rest because they had athletic skill and had physical powers.

('40', 69, 1, 12, 166730) The first condition therefore of individual growth is utmost humility.
('40', 69, 1, 13, 166801) And if we see at the present moment in our own land, some people in their insolence calling themselves superior and regarding others as below themselves in rank and regarding yet others as untouchables and unapproachables, those who are standing aloof from this strife are able to watch and see that these in their insolence are also digging their own graves.
('40', 69, 1, 14, 167161) You will therefore see perfect correspondence between the individual and the corporation, and so I always say to students, young men and women, wanting to serve the country and to do big things: “First of all look after yourselves and make yourselves fairly good instruments of service.” I hold it to be utterly impossible for any young man and any young woman to serve society unless they start with a clean slate, that is, a pure heart.
('40', 69, 1, 15, 167600) But to say that we should have pure hearts is really easily said, but it is not equally easy to achieve and so, we have in the Christian scheme of life what is called new birth.
('40', 69, 1, 16, 167778) The corresponding term in Hinduism is dwija, i.e., twice born.

('40', 70, 0, 1, 168002) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 71
('40', 70, 1, 2, 168050) has acquired the significance which, when the word was orginally used, it never bore.
('40', 70, 1, 3, 168136) That new birth does not come from any outward circumstance nor through lip profession.
('40', 70, 1, 4, 168223) It is an inward change which is unmistakable.
('40', 70, 1, 5, 168269) It is a change which the person himself notices and so do his neighbours.
('40', 70, 1, 6, 168343) It is a transformation of the heart and it needs no lip declaration.
('40', 70, 1, 7, 168412) And that absolute transformation can only come by inward prayer and a definite and living recognition of the presence of the mighty spirit residing within.
('40', 70, 1, 8, 168568) We call this by the name of Bhakti Yoga and rendered in English it means union with God by means of devotion and that yoga is possible alike for the lad, ten years old, as for an old man on the brink of the grave and when that transformation has come as a matter of fact, there is no falling back.
('40', 70, 1, 9, 168866) But there is very often a subtle self deception about the person noticing such a transformation about himself or herself, and so in order to make it easy for ourselves we have accommodated ourselves to a term called backsliding.

('40', 78, 2, 12, 189335) 39. “WHAT SHOULD I DO?” A gentleman asks :
('40', 78, 3, 13, 189378) I am trying to get into a railway compartment; someone inside holds the door fast, though there is room, and does not let me get in.
('40', 78, 3, 14, 189511) What should I do in this situation?
('40', 78, 3, 15, 189547) There are three courses open: 1.To complain to the railway authorities on the station; 2.if one has strength enough and courage, to force open the door and get into the compartment and, if necessary, to fight with that passenger who thought he owned the railway; 3.if one has courage and spiritual strength to plead with the bully and, if he does not respond, to forgo one’s right and try to find a seat elsewhere.
('40', 78, 3, 16, 189962) If one fails in that, one may let the train pass.
('40', 78, 3, 17, 190012) One should have faith that this is for the good of that bully and of oneself.
('40', 78, 3, 18, 190090) We have no right to ask when he will become reasonable.
('40', 78, 3, 19, 190146) All the three courses are legitimate, but the third one is purely of a spiritual character.
('40', 78, 3, 20, 190238) The first two are practical, but they are not contrary to dharma.
('40', 78, 3, 21, 190304) I can imagine a fourth.
('40', 78, 3, 22, 190328) Being a coward, one may be afraid of getting beaten up in a fight and may look for a seat elsewhere.
('40', 78, 3, 23, 190429) This is adharma.
('40', 78, 3, 24, 190446) It has, therefore, no place among the legitimate courses
('40', 79, 0, 1, 190503) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 79, 1, 2, 190544) open to one.
('40', 79, 1, 3, 190557) The second question is this :
('40', 79, 2, 4, 190587) I am travelling in a train.
('40', 79, 2, 5, 190615) I get down at one station to drink water.
('40', 79, 2, 6, 190657) In my absence, someone enters the compartment and occupies my seat.
('40', 79, 2, 7, 190725) He refuses to vacate it.
('40', 79, 2, 8, 190750) What should I do ?
('40', 79, 2, 9, 190769) I think the answer to this is contained in the answer to the first question.
('40', 79, 2, 10, 190846) Such incidents are common during railway journeys.
('40', 79, 2, 11, 190897) I have often been in such difficulties.
('40', 79, 2, 12, 190937) On every occasion, I adopted the third course, and have never regretted having done so.
('40', 79, 2, 13, 191025) In many cases, I remember, the bully’s heart had melted.
('40', 79, 2, 14, 191082) Let not the reader think that people would recognize me because I was a mahatma and would therefore yield.
('40', 79, 2, 15, 191189) Most of the experiences of which I have the memory belong to a time before I became a mahatma.
('40', 79, 2, 16, 191284) But there is one condition for adopting the third course.
('40', 79, 2, 17, 191342) The person who adopts it should have a living religious faith and should not merely imitate the behaviour of another.
('40', 79, 2, 18, 191460) If one feels angry with the bully, one should realize that one is not fit to adopt the third course.
('40', 79, 2, 19, 191561) Dharma is a matter of the heart.
('40', 79, 2, 20, 191594) If we try to imitate another, there is every possibility of our falling instead of following dharma.
('40', 79, 2, 21, 191695) I have often observed Guajarat’s non violence becoming timidity and cowardice.
('40', 79, 2, 22, 191774) I, therefore, feel reluctant to discuss the third course, and there seems no need to discuss the first two.
('40', 79, 2, 23, 191882) I do not need to explain that they are even and broad.
('40', 79, 2, 24, 191937) The third is steep and narrow, and in climbing it we get out of breath, so that we can never discuss it too much.
('40', 79, 2, 25, 192051) In Gujarat more than elsewhere, but generally in the whole of India, people are usually found to adopt the fourth course which is one of adharma, and so it is necessary to mention the first two.
('40', 79, 2, 26, 192246) Anyone who adopts either of them may one day be taught to adopt the third, but I doubt if one who follows the fourth can learn the third.

('40', 80, 11, 21, 193276) As you have rightly remarked in the address, Nandanar 2 was one of the bright stars among the satyagrahis of India.

('40', 81, 1, 4, 194431) At the present moment I know many temples, whether they be dedicated to Vishnu or Siva, entered into and visited by thousands of the so called Brahmins, which are no temples of God.
('40', 81, 1, 5, 194613) Let this temple not be an addition to those numerous temples which today disfigure this holy land.
('40', 81, 1, 6, 194712) But if you want to do that; those who will be in charge of this temple will have to purify their hearts of all anger.
('40', 81, 1, 7, 194830) I am glad therefore to notice that in your address you do not seem to seek to destroy Hinduism itself as I see is being done in many places in the present time.
('40', 81, 1, 8, 194991) I appreciate your idea not to trample underfoot Hindu traditions whether they be bad or indifferent.
('40', 81, 1, 9, 195092) But as you have decided to make use of the good faculty of discrimination, and as you seek not to destroy that which is good but only that which is bad, let me congratulate you upon your determination to win status by sheer force of merit.
('40', 81, 1, 10, 195332) You rightly claim to be the descendants of the original inhabitants of this ancient land and if it belongs to any single individual as a matter of right, that right is certainly yours and yours foremost.
('40', 81, 1, 11, 195536) You are therefore entitled to every consideration.

('40', 82, 3, 14, 198325) September 11, 1927
('40', 82, 4, 15, 198344) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I thank you for all these addresses and the different purses.
('40', 82, 4, 16, 198432) I thank you also for the delicate consideration with which you have saved the reading of all the addresses, as you are aware that I have to catch the train immediately after 7 o’clock and therefore speak against time.
('40', 82, 4, 17, 198650) The saving of the time which therefore was caused by the saving of reading of the addresses is all the more appreciable.

('40', 82, 4, 19, 198874) Your fame had preceded my coming here through the beautiful story that Mr. C. Rajagopalachariar wrote through the pages of Young India.
('40', 82, 4, 20, 199010) I know the fame of this place of yours.

('40', 82, 4, 22, 199133) I have never claimed to be the original satyagrahi.

('40', 82, 4, 24, 199270) And yet it remains to be seen and
('40', 83, 0, 1, 199304) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 83, 1, 2, 199345) demonstrated that it is a doctrine which is capable of application by thousands and thousands of people in all ways.
('40', 83, 1, 3, 199462) I know therefore that mine is an experiment still in the making.
('40', 83, 1, 4, 199527) And it therefore always keeps me humble and rooted to the soil.
('40', 83, 1, 5, 199591) In that state of humility I always cling to every example of satyagraha that comes under my notice as a child clings to its mother’s breast.
('40', 83, 1, 6, 199732) And so when I hear or read the story of Nandanar and his lofty satyagraha and his great success, my head bows before his spirit.
('40', 83, 1, 7, 199861) All the day long I have felt elevated to be able to be in a place hallowed by the holy feet of Nandanar.
('40', 83, 1, 8, 199966) It will not be without a wrench that I shall be leaving this place in a few minutes’ time.
('40', 83, 1, 9, 200057) But it gave me great joy and I considered it to be a great honour that the very first act I was called upon to perform was to lay the foundation stone of the gateway of the temple that has been erected in memory of the great saint.

('40', 83, 1, 12, 200566) In the eye of God there are no touchables or untouchables.

('40', 83, 1, 14, 200854) Theirs is the privilege, theirs is the duty of serving their fellow brethren.

('40', 83, 1, 18, 201438) Nandanar broke down every barrier and won his way to freedom not by freak, not by lustre, but by the purest form of self suffering and did not swear against his persecutors.
('40', 83, 1, 19, 201612) He would not even condescend to ask from his persecutors what were his dues.
('40', 83, 1, 20, 201689) But he shamed them into doing justice by his lofty prayers and by the purity of his character, and, if I may commit it into human language, he compelled God Himself to descend and made Him open the eyes of his persecutors.
('40', 83, 1, 21, 201912) What Nandanar did in his time and in his own person, it is open to every one of us to do today.

('40', 84, 1, 2, 202096) something of the spirit of Nandanar, and if so many of us could possibly imitate Nandanar and assimilate the spark of his spirit, we can make the land, a land again of holy people.

('40', 91, 3, 13, 216132) 51. LETTER TO KATHERINE MAYO
('40', 91, 4, 14, 216161) AS AT SABARMATI, ON TOUR, September 13, 1927
('40', 91, 5, 15, 216206) DEAR FRIEND, It was through Mr. Karl Placht that I received some time ago a copy of your book.
('40', 91, 5, 16, 216301) Mother India, which he sent me with your permission.
('40', 91, 5, 17, 216354) I really get little time to read any literature but as your book attracted much attention here and gave rise to very bitter and angry comment, and as many correspondents drew my attention to the fact that you had made copious references to my writings and urged me to give my opinion upon your book I made time to read it through.
('40', 91, 5, 18, 216685) I am sorry to have to inform you that the book did not leave on my mind at all a nice impression.
('40', 91, 5, 19, 216783) I have asked the Publishers of Young India to send you a copy of my review 1 of your book.
('40', 91, 5, 20, 216874) If you think that I have done any injustice to you take care to draw my attention to it I shall feel thankful to you.
('40', 91, 5, 21, 216992) As I have not your address by me on my tour, I am taking the liberty of sending this to you through Mr. Karl Placht.
('40', 91, 6, 22, 217109) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('40', 92, 4, 17, 218083) 53. SPEECH AT MAYAVARAM
('40', 92, 5, 18, 218107) September 13, 1927
('40', 92, 6, 19, 218126) LADIES AND FRIENDS, I thank for all these several addresses and the several purses.
('40', 92, 6, 20, 218210) If you want me to make a fairly detailed reply to all the important points referred to in those addresses, it is necessary that you should keep perfect silence during the time when I am speaking.
('40', 92, 7, 21, 218406) At the outset I have to tender you the same apology that I tendered at Cuddalore; and that was to ask you, out of your generosity, to pardon me for my having been not accessible to all and sundry that came to me during my rest hours.
('40', 92, 7, 22, 218640) If I could have had the strength, I would have loved to talk to the citizens in this town to
('40', 92, 8, 23, 218733) 1 The year is inferred from the reference to Gandhiji’s tour programme and to Abdul Rashid, the assassin of Swami Shraddhanand.
('40', 92, 8, 24, 218861) 2 An armed dacoity committed on August 9, 1925 near Kakori railway station when cash and currency were plundered from the guard’s van of a train going to Lucknow from Moradabad; one person was killed.
('40', 92, 8, 25, 219062) The dacoity, it was alleged, had been committed by certain members of the Hindustan Republican Association of United Provinces, the object of which was the establishment of a ‘Federated Republic of the United States of India’.
('40', 92, 8, 26, 219289) Of the 21 accused, two were acquitted, three were sentenced to death, one to transportation for life and the rest to terms of imprison ment varying from five to 14 years.

('40', 93, 1, 2, 219501) cross question them and to understand their several viewpoints; but in the present weak state of my health, such a thing is not possible.
('40', 93, 2, 3, 219639) Some of you may perhaps recall than this is not my first visit to Mayavaram.
('40', 93, 2, 4, 219716) I have a vivid recollection of 1915, when I had the privilege of talking to some of you on swadeshi.
('40', 93, 2, 5, 219817) 1 But I must not detain you by recalling to you my pleasant recollections of that time.
('40', 93, 3, 6, 219905) I congratulate you on your work towards the uplift of the so called ‘untouchables’.
('40', 93, 3, 7, 219989) But I must this evening speak to you on a subject which is very dear to me, but on which I have not as yet spoken during this tour of mine.
('40', 93, 3, 8, 220129) I would like to speak to you on that subject this evening because it was forced on my attention yesterday morning.
('40', 93, 3, 9, 220244) I want to speak to you upon the santitation of this place.
('40', 93, 3, 10, 220303) Your municipality very kindly presented me an address in which you have mentioned some of my activites in which I am interested as a humanitarian, as a reformer.
('40', 93, 3, 11, 220465) I reckon sanitation also as one of the important things which a humanitarian or a reformer must tackle.
('40', 93, 3, 12, 220569) Within three or four minutes’ walk of the place where you have kindly housed me, I endeavoured unsuspectingly to go out for a walk thinking that it was a beautiful grove by the side of a lovely pond.
('40', 93, 3, 13, 220769) A rustic bamboo foot bridge drew my attention to walk over it.
('40', 93, 3, 14, 220832) I crossed it, turned to the right and walked with my companion but a few paces when you may imagine what I saw.
('40', 93, 3, 15, 220944) What I saw was a sight too horrible to talk about; and the stench that was coming out of it was suffocating.
('40', 93, 3, 16, 221053) I saw the water of that pond was being defiled in a disgusting manner, when, at the same time, a woman was filling her pot with that same water.
('40', 93, 3, 17, 221198) And, in order to get the morning walk, I was obliged to go out for some distance in a motor car.
('40', 93, 3, 18, 221295) I felt deeply hurt; I felt as if I was wounded.
('40', 93, 3, 19, 221343) It recalled to me the sights that I used to see in the principal streets of the Madras city itself in 1915. Surely there is something that is terribly wrong in this state of affairs.
('40', 93, 3, 20, 221526) The first condition of any municipal life is decent sanitation and an unfailing supply of pure water.
('40', 93, 3, 21, 221628) Do not for a moment consider that either of these two things require any great outlay of money.
('40', 93, 3, 22, 221724) Both these things are capable of being secured without your having to spend any money at all, if only you have the will to secure them to the citizens.
('40', 93, 3, 23, 221876) But it requires a vivid sense of your municipal duties.
('40', 93, 3, 24, 221932) Membership of a municipal board
('40', 93, 4, 25, 221964) 1Vide “Speech at Reception at Mayavaram”, May 1, 1915.
('40', 94, 0, 1, 222019) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 95
('40', 94, 1, 2, 222067) must not be treated as a place of privilege.
('40', 94, 1, 3, 222112) No man dare enter a municipality except in the spirit of a scavenger.
('40', 94, 1, 4, 222182) But what I see so often in the papers is only wrangling over municipal elections and the fight between the Brahmins and the Non Brahmins arising out of this wrangling.
('40', 94, 1, 5, 222350) If you will only remember that you are the servants of the people of Mayavaram and not their masters and that you are entrusted with the solemn duty to keep the town in perfect sanitation for the benefit of the people, you will start with a shovel in your hand and set about keeping the water pure and preserving sanitation on the land given to the poor.
('40', 94, 1, 6, 222705) You have got in your midst so many schools maintained by you; give them a holiday and ask the students of those schools to go about cleaning the streets and also telling the people themselves to keep the streets clean and the water pure.
('40', 94, 1, 7, 222943) Surely our learning and all the lessons that we receive on sanitation in schools are useless, unless we reduce them to practice in our daily life; and I urge you not to say to yourselves that our people will not listen to these appeals and will not change their habits.
('40', 94, 1, 8, 223213) The place where I was myself born had terribly impure dungheaps in the streets about fifty years back.
('40', 94, 1, 9, 223316) But there came to that place an administrator; and, be it said to his credit, he was an Englishman.
('40', 94, 1, 10, 223416) He removed the dungheaps in a day and there was no protest to his doing so from any of the people.
('40', 94, 1, 11, 223515) Nor did he use his official authority to impose his imperious will on an unwilling people.
('40', 94, 1, 12, 223606) But he reasoned with the people, bore down all opposition and carried out his reforms.
('40', 94, 1, 13, 223693) I have cited this instance before you because I am a determined opponent of this British administration but we have yet got to learn much from the Britisher in the matter of sanitation.
('40', 94, 1, 14, 223879) I ask you to shake off your lethargy, to take your courage in your hands; and you can easily carry out this reform.
('40', 94, 1, 15, 223995) I must now proceed to the very long and well argued address presented to me on behalf of the ‘suppressed’ society.
('40', 94, 1, 16, 224110) That address isolates itself from other addresses of the kind, in that it refers not so much to the social disabilities, as it does to the civil disabilities of that community.
('40', 94, 1, 17, 224287) It casts very serious reflections upon the landlord class.
('40', 94, 1, 18, 224346) It charges them with having reduced their class to serfdom.
('40', 94, 1, 19, 224406) It charges the administration with having closed the door against their holding even menial offices.
('40', 94, 1, 20, 224507) It complains of want of assistance from everybody, except [for] a few isolated instances.
('40', 94, 1, 21, 224597) It says that, whereas their average income is never more than Rs. 40 a year, their expenses are never less than Rs. 120 per year.
('40', 94, 1, 22, 224727) It complains that, being rooted to the soil, they have to remain without any occupation at all for a major
('40', 95, 0, 1, 224834) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 95, 1, 2, 224875) portion of the year.
('40', 95, 1, 3, 224896) I do not know what truth there is in all these allegations.
('40', 95, 1, 4, 224956) As it is, I can only give these friends of mine the consolation that I will endeavour to verify these statements in their address.
('40', 95, 1, 5, 225087) Generally speaking, I may assure them of my fullest sympathy and I certainly associate myself with the remark that I notice in their address that they are the first holders of the land in this country.
('40', 95, 1, 6, 225289) But there is no cause for the spirit of despair that runs throughout the address.
('40', 95, 1, 7, 225371) They, in common with the rest, cannot help profiting by the great awakening that has now come over the country.
('40', 95, 1, 8, 225483) At the present moment, it is true that that awakening has taken a sad turn.
('40', 95, 1, 9, 225559) In our blindness, we seem to think that each group, each section, each class, each caste should pull its way by itself without the one co operating with the other.
('40', 95, 1, 10, 225723) So we are torn by internal dissensions.
('40', 95, 1, 11, 225763) But these dissensions are only temporary and are bound to die out; and, when the cloud is really lifted and the day dawns, the ‘suppressed’ classes are bound to partake in the rejoicings that will come in the wake.
('40', 95, 1, 12, 225978) And in order to partake in the rejoicings at the time of the advent of that dawn, let them understand that, after all, everyone shall have ultimately to depend upon self help.
('40', 95, 1, 13, 226154) They have but to become conscious of their own strength which their numbers and their occupation give them; and they will become an irresistible force.
('40', 95, 1, 14, 226306) Immediately they realize that they are slaves of nobody, and that, after all, without their labour, the lands they are cultivating will become a horrible wilderness, then the day is theirs.
('40', 95, 1, 15, 226496) But I would say to the landlord class, that if the allegations made against them in the address are true to any extent, it reflects the greatest discredit upon them.
('40', 95, 1, 16, 226662) Let them not crush under their feet the shoulders on which they ride.
('40', 95, 1, 17, 226732) Let them consider these labouring classes, who alone make their barren fields appear smiling with rich crops, let the landlord class consider these labourers as one of their own family and allow them to share in the happiness to which the labours of these people contribute so much.
('40', 95, 1, 18, 227015) It is wrong, it is sinful to consider our own labourers as ‘untouchables’.
('40', 95, 1, 19, 227090) Let us wipe out this shame.
('40', 95, 1, 20, 227118) But I have yet to talk to you of another shame.
('40', 95, 1, 21, 227166) I saw some friends this afternoon from whose class the Devadasis are drawn.
('40', 95, 1, 22, 227242) I saw some of these sisters also and I engaged them in a very serious conversation.
('40', 95, 1, 23, 227326) And, as I was talking to them and understanding the
('40', 96, 0, 1, 227378) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 97
('40', 96, 1, 2, 227426) hidden meaning of this thing, my whole soul rose against the system in its entirety.
('40', 96, 1, 3, 227511) In calling them Devadasis we insult God Himself under the sacred name of religion; and we commit a double crime in that we use these sisters of ours to serve our lust and take, in the same breath, foul as it is, the name of God.
('40', 96, 1, 4, 227740) To think that there should be a class of people given to this kind of immoral service and that there is another class of people in this country who perpetuate the continuance of such a system, makes one despair of life itself.
('40', 96, 1, 5, 227967) And I assure you that, as I was talking to them, there was no evil in their eyes and that they were capable of as fine perceptions and as pure feelings as any other woman in the world.
('40', 96, 1, 6, 228152) What difference can there be between them and our own blood sisters?
('40', 96, 1, 7, 228221) And if we will not allow our own blood sisters for such immoral uses, how dare we then use these women for such purposes?
('40', 96, 1, 8, 228343) Let the Hindus, who are connected in any way with this evil, purge themselves of it.
('40', 96, 1, 9, 228428) The existence of such an evil in our society saps its foundations.
('40', 96, 1, 10, 228495) The majority of these sisters, or all of them, have promised me to retrace their steps on certain conditions; and I promised them that I would make it convenient and possible for them to so retrace their steps.
('40', 96, 1, 11, 228706) God willing, I shall fulfil my promise and let them also do their part.
('40', 96, 1, 12, 228778) If they cannot fulfil those conditions, I shall blame not them, but the society in which their lot is cast.
('40', 96, 1, 13, 228886) It is up to you to extend the hand of fellowship to these sisters.
('40', 96, 1, 14, 228953) It is up to you to see that they are reclaimed from this life of shame.
('40', 96, 1, 15, 229025) I know that, when again they have to face temptations, it may become a too irresistible force.
('40', 96, 1, 16, 229120) But, if man will restrain his lust and if society should disapprove of this practice, it is surely possible that they will not go astray.
('40', 96, 1, 17, 229258) I thank you for giving me this very patient hearing.
('40', 96, 1, 18, 229311) I know that you will excuse my straight talk to you this evening.
('40', 96, 1, 19, 229377) Though, during the period of my stay here I have had every attention bestowed upon me by so many of the kind friends that were by my side, I must own that the two days of my stay here were sad days for me.
('40', 96, 1, 20, 229583) This Devadasi problem which was brought to my notice yesterday and the state of insanitation that I personally observed, caused me intense grief; and in talking to you in the manner in which I did, I endeavoured to lighten my grief by making you share in it.
('40', 96, 1, 21, 229842) I shall hope that you will share that grief and lighten my burden by following my suggestions.

('40', 102, 1, 5, 241444) As a Sanatani Hindu, as I call myself to be one, I say with great deliberation that untouchability as we practise today has no warrant in Hinduism and that it is a blot on Hindu society.
('40', 102, 1, 6, 241631) I say in all humility but with equal firmness that if we, Hindus, do not take care to rid ourselves of this blot, Hinduism itself is in serious danger of being blotted out.
('40', 102, 1, 7, 241804) A religion whose two great maxims are “ Satyannasti paro dharmah” 1, “ Ahimsa paramo dharmah” 2, a religion that is broadbased on fundamental truth and fundamental love, cannot possibly tolerate untouchability because one is born in particular surroundings.
('40', 102, 1, 8, 242062) I say also with greatest emphasis that there is no warrant in this Hinduism that I have defined to you for child widowhood.
('40', 102, 1, 9, 242186) Marriage, it is universally acknowledged, gives a status and a change in life.
('40', 102, 1, 10, 242265) There can be no such thing as a sacred bond on the part of a girl of tender years who is only fit to sit in her mother’s or father’s lap.
('40', 102, 1, 11, 242403) And if fathers, who are blind to all affection springing out of parental love, give away their daughters of tender years in marriage, it is not marriage except a stone being married to a man.
('40', 102, 1, 12, 242595) Therefore I say that there is no such thing as a child widow because there is no such thing as child marriage.
('40', 102, 2, 13, 242706) I have no hesitation to repeat the advice that, if there are students who want to be married, they will be performing an act of charity towards the girls of India to seek out child widows when they have outgrown their childhood and they will be doing a service to the country if they make up their minds to end child widowhood by refusing child marriage.

('40', 103, 1, 2, 243659) I have been told that I am tender when speaking before Christian audiences or Mussalman audiences, whereas I am not at all tender about Hindu religion and Hindu weaknesses.

('40', 103, 1, 9, 245020) Taking all the care that it would be humanly possible for me to take not to give unnecessary offence and not to cause unnecessary displeasure, I must continue to give out what I feel and speak with absolute truth and absolute fairness and so I suggest as humbly as I can to all the learned pundits in this place and to every thinking Hindu, man or woman, to reconsider their views and understand the bearings of untouchability, child marriages, child widows and Devadasis and ask themselves whether there can be any warrant for all these in a religion inspired by rishis who went into endless austerities and based their faith upon the teachings of the Bhagavad Gita.

('40', 104, 3, 10, 247142) September 14, 1927
('40', 104, 4, 11, 247161) Several leading pundits of this place had a Conference with Mahatma Gandhi last night.
('40', 104, 4, 12, 247248) The pundits, it is understood, protested against the recent remarks of Mr. Gandhi about child widows and their marriage and the question of untouchability.

('40', 104, 5, 15, 247704) Nothing that was opposed to truth and love could be dharma according to Hindu Shastras.

('40', 105, 2, 4, 248645) Several correspondents have sent me cuttings containing reviews of, or protests against, Miss Mayo’s Mother India.
('40', 105, 2, 5, 248760) A few have in addition asked me to give my own opinion on it.
('40', 105, 2, 6, 248822) An enraged correspondent from London asks me to give him answers to several questions that he has framed upon the authoress’s references to me.
('40', 105, 2, 7, 248966) Miss Mayo has herself favoured me with a copy of her book.
('40', 105, 2, 8, 249025) I would certainly not have made time, especially when I have only limited energy,and caution has been enjoined upon me by medical friends against overwork, to read the book during my tour.
('40', 105, 2, 9, 249214) But these letters made it obligatory on me to read the book at once.
('40', 105, 2, 10, 249283) The book is cleverly and powerfully written.
('40', 105, 2, 11, 249328) The carefully chosen quotations give it the appearance of a truthful book.
('40', 105, 2, 12, 249403) But the impression it leaves on my mind is, that it is the report of a drain inspector sent out with the one purpose of opening and examining the drains of the country to be reported upon, or to give a graphic description of the stench exuded by the opened drains.
('40', 105, 2, 13, 249668) If Miss Mayo had confessed that she had gone to India merely to open out and examine the drains of India, there would perhaps be little to complain about her compilation.
('40', 105, 2, 14, 249839) But she says in effect with a certain amount of triumph, “The drains are India”.
('40', 105, 2, 15, 249920) True, in the concluding chapter there is a caution.
('40', 105, 2, 16, 249972) But her caution is cleverly made to enforce her sweeping condemnation.
('40', 105, 2, 17, 250043) I feel that no one who has any knowledge of India can possibly accept her terrible accusations against the thought and the life of the people of this unhappy country.
('40', 105, 2, 18, 250210) The book is without doubt untruthful, be the facts stated ever so truthful.
('40', 105, 2, 19, 250286) If I open out and describe with punctilious care all the stench exuded from the drains of London and say “Behold London”, my facts will be incapable of challenge, but my judgement will be rightly condemned as a travesty of truth.
('40', 105, 2, 20, 250516) Miss Mayo’s book is nothing better,
('40', 106, 0, 1, 250552) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 107
('40', 106, 1, 2, 250601) nothing else.
('40', 106, 1, 3, 250615) The authoress says she was dissatisfied with the literature she read about India, and so she came to India “to see what a volunteer unsubsidized, uncommitted and unattached, could observe of common things in daily human life”.
('40', 106, 1, 4, 250842) After having read the book with great attention, I regret to say that I find it difficult to accept this claim.
('40', 106, 1, 5, 250954) Unsubsidized she may be.
('40', 106, 1, 6, 250979) Uncommited and unattached she certainly fails to show herself in any page.
('40', 106, 1, 7, 251054) We in India are accustomed to interested publications patronized—“patronized” is accepted as an elegant synonym for “subsidized”—by the Government.
('40', 106, 1, 8, 251202) We have become used to understanding from pre British days, that the art (perfected by the British) of government includes the harnessing of the secret service of men learned, and reported to be honest and honourable for shadowing suspects and for writing up the virtues of the Government of the day as if the certificate had come from disinterested quarters.
('40', 106, 1, 9, 251562) I hope that Miss Mayo will not take offence if she comes under the shadow of such suspicion.

('40', 106, 1, 14, 252121) It is also untruthful because she claims for the British Government merits which cannot be sustained and which many an honest British officer would blush to see the Government credited with.
('40', 106, 1, 15, 252312) If she is not subsidized, Miss Mayo is an avowed Indophobe and Anglophil refusing to see anything good about Indians and anything bad about the British and their rule.
('40', 106, 1, 16, 252480) She does not give one an elevated idea of Western standard of judgement.

('40', 106, 1, 18, 252716) But the pity of it is that there are still thousands in the West who delight in ‘shilling shockers’.

('40', 116, 1, 10, 275760) And I therefore admit, in all humility, that even the Vedas, the Koran and the Bible are the imperfect word of God, and imperfect beings that we are, swayed to and fro by a multitude of passions, it is impossible for us even to understand this word of God in its fullness, and so I say to a Hindu boy, that he must not uproot the traditions in which he has been brought up, as I say to a Mussalman or a Christian boy that he must not uproot his traditions.
('40', 116, 1, 11, 276217) And so whilst I would welcome you learning the Gospel and your learning the Koran, I would certainly insist on all of you Hindu boys, if I had the power of insistence, learning the Gita.
('40', 116, 1, 12, 276404) It is my belief that the impurity that we see about boys in schools, the carelessness about things that matter in life, the levity with which the student world deals with the greatest and most fundamental questions of life is due to this uprooting of tradition from which boys have hitherto derived their sustenance.
('40', 116, 1, 13, 276721) But I must not be misunderstood.
('40', 116, 1, 14, 276754) I do not hold that everything ancient is good because it is ancient, I do not advocate surrender of God given reasoning faculty in the face of ancient tradition.
('40', 116, 1, 15, 276916) Any tradition, however ancient, if inconsistent with morality, is fit to be banished from the land.
('40', 116, 1, 16, 277016) Untouchability may be considered to be an ancient tradition, the institution of child widowhood and child marriage may be considered to be ancient tradition, and even so many an ancient horrible belief and superstitious practice.
('40', 116, 1, 17, 277246) I would sweep them out of existence if I had the power.
('40', 116, 1, 18, 277302) When, therefore, I talk of respecting the ancient tradition, you now understand what I mean, and it is because I see the same God in the Bhagavad Gita as I see in the Bible and the Koran that I say to the Hindu boys that they will derive greater inspiration from Bhagavad Gita because they will be tuned to the Gita more than to any other book.
('40', 116, 1, 19, 277647) Young India, 22 9 1927

('40', 117, 1, 2, 277712) 63. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MANNARGUDI
('40', 117, 2, 3, 277753) September 15, 1927
('40', 117, 3, 4, 277772) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I thank you for your several addresses and purses on behalf of the Daridranarayana.
('40', 117, 3, 5, 277882) I congratulate the Taluk Board on having given me an advance copy of the translation of its address in Hindi.
('40', 117, 3, 6, 277992) I am looking forward to the time when everywhere I should be able to make myself understood through Hindi which is or should be the common language throughout India.
('40', 117, 3, 7, 278158) At the present moment, as you know, there is almost a barrier between the North and the South.
('40', 117, 3, 8, 278253) Public workers coming from the South find themselves at sea when they are face to face to speak in the North.
('40', 117, 3, 9, 278363) I do not by any means suggest that Hindi should take the place of vernaculars but I do suggest that all public workers, leaders of public opinion, should know Hindi and should be able to express themselves wherever they go in the Hindi language.
('40', 117, 3, 10, 278609) You all know that a committee from the North began its operation some six or seven years ago with a view to popularize Hindi in the South.
('40', 117, 3, 11, 278748) Nearly one lakh of rupees have been spent by this committee, in order to teach Hindi to those who would learn it.
('40', 117, 3, 12, 278862) The central office at Madras has received from the head office in Prayag the charter of self government and it is now open to the leaders of public opinion, in the South, to extend the operation of this committee and make it self supporting.
('40', 117, 4, 13, 279104) You have in all your addresses endorsed the work of the spinning wheel and khadi that is being done throughout India.
('40', 117, 4, 14, 279222) I had known long ago that Mannargudi was famous for its weaving and I should hope that in the near future there would be no weaver in Mannargudi who is not weaving hand spun yarn.
('40', 117, 4, 15, 279402) But the weavers cannot have enough well hand spun yarn unless you go out in the villages and give work to so many who have so much idle time at their command from year to year.
('40', 117, 4, 16, 279579) I saw this afternoon a band of workers living about 10 miles from Mannargudi, in a village called Palayur, where they are trying to introduce the spinning wheel in the village and places surrounding it.
('40', 117, 4, 17, 279782) They tell me that if they can secure sufficient workers, there is great scope in these villages for the introduction of the spinning wheel.
('40', 117, 4, 18, 279922) The remarkable address that I received at Mayavaram, on behalf of the peasantry had nearly six months during the year when they had no work to do.
('40', 117, 4, 19, 280069) The address
('40', 118, 0, 1, 280081) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 119
('40', 118, 1, 2, 280130) further gives a startling information that the income of the peasantry in this rich district of Tanjore was no more than forty rupees, whereas the expenses were at 120. Making due allowance for exaggeration in this statement, if there is an exaggeration, there is no doubt whatsoever that the peasantry is living from hand to mouth and is in need of supplementary occupation.
('40', 118, 1, 3, 280506) The same address proceeded to inform me that the vast masses of toiling millions were considered to be untouchables.
('40', 118, 1, 4, 280623) And as such they were unworthy of the attention by the middle class people.
('40', 118, 1, 5, 280699) In order to prevent this atrocious state of affairs, I ventured to present India with the spinning wheel and khadi.
('40', 118, 1, 6, 280815) We, the middle class people, take no interest in them, we do not care what happened to their spinning wheel and what happened to their industry.
('40', 118, 1, 7, 280960) And so by our criminal indifference we allowed that industry to die an unnatural death.
('40', 118, 1, 8, 281048) I ask you to approach the spinning wheel with a new point of view.
('40', 118, 1, 9, 281115) I also ask you to utilize khadi in order to form an indissoluble bond between the peasantry and ourselves and I am aware that we shall not succeed in our endeavours so long as we consider these toiling millions as untouchables.
('40', 118, 1, 10, 281343) I had the pleasures, not umixed with pain, of listening to some of our learned Pundits, expounding the philosophy of untouchability, but I am happy to be able to say that these Pundits were open to conviction and open to arguments on behalf of these people.
('40', 118, 1, 11, 281601) 1 Instead of brushing aside my arguments summarily, they were pleased to listen and grant that so far as the well being of the people was concerned, the argument was all in my favour.
('40', 118, 1, 12, 281785) If that much is admitted by all the Pundits of India, I should be indifferent to what interpretation they placed upon the Shastras.
('40', 118, 1, 13, 281917) As a matter of fact for a layman like myself, it is quite enough for me to know that what is consistent with the highest good is the supreme Shastra and I should have no hesitation whatsoever in rejecting the Shastras which were inconsistent with our goal.
('40', 118, 1, 14, 282174) In connection with this I must mention the cause of the child widows.
('40', 118, 1, 15, 282244) Let us not resort to mere arguments and babbling in the act of doing this simple justice to our little daughters.
('40', 118, 1, 16, 282358) Let us be manly enough to regard every such child marriage as a nullity.
('40', 118, 1, 17, 282431) So long as we allow a single child widow to remain unmarried when she reaches her proper age, we fail in our elementary duty to humanity.
('40', 118, 1, 18, 282569) That really leads us naturally to a consideration of child marriages.
('40', 118, 2, 19, 282639) 1 Vide “Discussion with Pundits, Kumbakonam”, 14 9 1927

('40', 119, 1, 2, 282737) You will see that immediately you begin to think of these toiling millions of India and establish a loving bond between them and yourselves, it would be impossible for you to forget the drinkers.

('40', 120, 1, 2, 284824) 64. SPEECH AT TANJORE
('40', 120, 2, 3, 284846) September 16, 1927 I had hoped on coming to Tanjore today to discuss the Brahmin non Brahmin question 1 here and I had the pleasure of having a brief discussion with some of the friends this afternoon.
('40', 120, 2, 4, 285048) I am not free nor is it necessary for me to discuss and place before you the contents of our discussion.
('40', 120, 2, 5, 285153) But I was exceedingly glad of this discussion.
('40', 120, 2, 6, 285200) I now understand the movement perhaps a little better than I did before the discussion.
('40', 120, 2, 7, 285288) I have placed my humble view before those friends, of which they are at liberty to make what use they like.
('40', 120, 2, 8, 285396) But throughout the discussion I saw a note of one thing which seemed to oppress these friends.
('40', 120, 2, 9, 285491) They seemed to think that I had identified myself with the notion of inherited superiority and inferiority.
('40', 120, 2, 10, 285599) I assured them that nothing was farther from my thought and told them that I would gladly explain my meaning of varnashrama 2 more fully than I have done in order to remove the slightest misunderstanding as to this question of superiority.
('40', 120, 2, 11, 285839) In my opinion there is no such thing as inherited or acquired superiority.
('40', 120, 2, 12, 285914) I believe in the rock bottom doctrine of Advaita 3 and my interpretation of Advaita excludes totally any idea of superiority at any stage whatsoever.
('40', 120, 2, 13, 286064) I believe implicitly that all men are born equal.
('40', 120, 2, 14, 286114) All—whether born in India or in England or America or in any circums tances whatsoever—have the same soul as any other.
('40', 120, 2, 15, 286234) And it is because I believe in this inherent equality of all men that I fight the doctrine of superiority which many of our rulers arrogate to themselves.
('40', 120, 2, 16, 286389) I have fought this doctrine of superiority in South Africa inch by inch, and it is because of that inherent belief that I delight in calling myself a scavenger, a spinner, a weaver, a farmer and a labourer.
('40', 120, 2, 17, 286596) And I have fought against the Brahmins themselves wherever they have claimed any superiority for themselves either by reason of their birth or by reason of their subsequently acquired knowledge.
('40', 120, 2, 18, 286791) I consider that it is unmanly for any person to claim
('40', 120, 3, 19, 286845) 1 For Mahadev Desai’s catechism on the subject, vide Appendix “Brahmin Non Brahmin Question”, November 24, 1927. 2 The organization of society into four castes, and the division of life into four stages.
('40', 120, 3, 20, 287049) 3 The view that the atman, the self in man, is not distinct from the Brahman, the Absolute; literally, ‘non dualism’.
('40', 121, 0, 1, 287167) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 121, 1, 2, 287209) superiority over a fellow being.
('40', 121, 1, 3, 287242) And there is the amplest warrant for the belief that I am enunciating in the Bhagavad Gita, and I am therefore through and through with every non Brahmin when he fights this monster of superiority, whether it is claimed by a Brahmin or by anybody else.
('40', 121, 1, 4, 287495) He who claims superiority at once forfeits his claim to be called a man.
('40', 121, 1, 5, 287568) That is my opinion.
('40', 121, 1, 6, 287588) But in spite of all my beliefs that I have explained to you, I still believe in varnashrama dharma.
('40', 121, 1, 7, 287688) Varnashrama dharma to my mind is a law which, however much you and I may deny, cannot be abrogated.
('40', 121, 1, 8, 287788) To admit the working of that law is to free ourselves for the only pursuit in life for which we are born.
('40', 121, 1, 9, 287894) Varnashrama dharma is humility.
('40', 121, 1, 10, 287926) Whilst I have said that all men and women are born equal, I do not wish therefore to suggest that qualities are not inherited, but on the contrary I believe that just as everyone inherits a particular form so does he inherit the particular characteristics and qualities of his progenitors, and to make this admission is to conserve one’s energy.
('40', 121, 1, 11, 288272) That frank admission, if we will act up to it, would put a legitimate curb upon our material ambitions, and thereby our energy is set free for extending the field of spiritual research and spiritual evolution.
('40', 121, 1, 12, 288482) It is this doctrine of varnashrama dharma which I have always accepted.
('40', 121, 1, 13, 288554) You would be entitled to say that this is not how varnashrama is understood in these days.
('40', 121, 1, 14, 288645) I have myself said time without number that varnashrama as it is at present understood and practised is a monstrous parody of the original, but in order to demolish this distortion let us not seek to demolish the original.
('40', 121, 1, 15, 288868) And if you say that the idealistic varnashrama which I have placed before you is quite all right you have admitted all that I like you to admit.
('40', 121, 1, 16, 289013) I would also urge on you to believe with me that no nation, no individual, can possibly live without proper ideals.
('40', 121, 1, 17, 289129) And if you believe with me in the idealistic varnashrama you will also strive with me to reach that ideal so far as may be.
('40', 121, 1, 18, 289253) As a matter of fact the world has not anywhere been able to fight against this law.
('40', 121, 1, 19, 289337) What has happened and what must happen in fighting against the law is to hurt ourselves and to engage in a vain effort; and I suggest to you that your fight will be all the more success ful if you understand all that our forefathers have bequeathed to us and engage in fighting all the evil excrescences that have grown round this great bequest.
('40', 121, 1, 20, 289683) And if you accept what I have ventured to suggest to you, you will find that the solution of the Brahmin and non Brahmin question also, in so far as it is concerned with the religious aspect, becomes very easy.
('40', 121, 1, 21, 289894) As a non Brahmin I would seek to purify
('40', 122, 0, 1, 289934) VOL.40 : 2 SEPTEMBER 1927, 1 DECEMBER, 1927 123
('40', 122, 1, 2, 289982) Brahminism in so far as a non Brahmin can, but not to destroy it.
('40', 122, 1, 3, 290048) I would dislodge the Brahmin from the arrogation of superiority or from places of profit.
('40', 122, 1, 4, 290138) Immediately a Brahmin becomes a profiteering agency he ceases to be a Brahmin.
('40', 122, 1, 5, 290217) But I would not touch his great learning wherever I see it.
('40', 122, 1, 6, 290277) And whilst he may not claim superiority by reason of learning I myself must not withhold that meed of homage that learning, wherever it resides, always commands.
('40', 122, 1, 7, 290439) But I must not go deeper into the subject before a large audience of this kind.
('40', 122, 1, 8, 290519) After all I must fall upon one sovereign remedy which I think is applicable for all the ills of life.
('40', 122, 1, 9, 290621) And that is, in whatever fight we engage, the fight should be clean and straight, and there should not be the slightest departure from truth and ahimsa.
('40', 122, 1, 10, 290774) And if we will keep our carriage safely on these two rails you will find that our fight even though we may commit a thousand blunders will always smell clean and will be easier fought.
('40', 122, 1, 11, 290959) And even as a train that is derailed comes to a disastrous end, so shall we, if we be derailed off these two rails, come to a disaster.
('40', 122, 1, 12, 291095) A man who is truthful and does not mean ill even to his adversary will be slow to believe charges even against his foes.
('40', 122, 1, 13, 291216) He will, however, try to understand the viewpoints of his opponents and will always keep an open mind and seek every opportunity of serving his opponents.
('40', 122, 1, 14, 291371) I have endeavoured to apply this law in my relations with Englishmen and Europeans in general in South Africa as well as here and not without some success.
('40', 122, 1, 15, 291527) How much more then should we apply this law in our homes, in our relations, in our domestic affairs, in connection with our own kith and kin?
('40', 122, 2, 16, 291669) Young India, 29 9 1927

('40', 129, 2, 5, 302799) 75. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('40', 129, 3, 6, 302842) TRICHINOPOLY, [September 20, 1927] 1
('40', 129, 4, 7, 302879) I observe that my first speech in Trichinopoly 2 has been misunderstood abroad, and has caused anxiety to friends.
('40', 129, 4, 8, 302994) I would like to assure my friends, however, that there is not the slightest cause for any anxiety.
('40', 129, 4, 9, 303093) My statement, that I had come to the end of my resources, had a local reference, and it was therefore properly understood in Trichinopoly.
('40', 129, 4, 10, 303232) What I wanted to say was that I had hitherto taken up engagements up to the limit and that I could not comfortably go through a heavier programme in Trichinopoly.
('40', 129, 4, 11, 303395) This was a warning to friends in Trichinopoly and to the committees in the places yet to be visited, that they should not have a multiplicity of engagements.
('40', 129, 4, 12, 303553) One meeting a day is about all that I would have attended so far as my heart is concerned.
('40', 129, 4, 13, 303644) Doctor Rajan overhauled me completely, and neither he nor I have any anxiety.
('40', 129, 4, 14, 303722) The blood pressure stands at where it was in Bangalore.
('40', 129, 4, 15, 303778) Otherwise too, I am feeling quite well, and, if I do not allow myself to be overworked, I have no misgivings about my ability to go through the settled programme.
('40', 129, 4, 16, 303941) Friends about me are taking extraordinary precautions for my protection, and I am myself wide awake.
('40', 129, 4, 17, 304042) I hope therefore that there would be no anxiety felt about my tour; and I would request newspaper reporters and editors not to send or publish any reports about my health before submitting them to me, or to those who are in charge of me.
('40', 129, 4, 18, 304280) The Hindu, 21 9 1927
