('40', 134, 1, 2, 313696) 79. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TRICHINOPOLY
('40', 134, 2, 3, 313739) September 21, 1927
('40', 134, 3, 4, 313758) Mahatmaji, in the course of his speech, recalled the satyagraha days when he visited Trichy which gave him some of his best co workers.
('40', 134, 3, 5, 313894) Unity, which prevailed then among all classes, had given place to dissensions and in spite of many vicissitudes the country had passed through, khadi had remained absolutely steady.
('40', 134, 3, 6, 314076) It did not admit of dissensions, because khadi permeated the masses, who had nothing of these dissensions.
('40', 134, 3, 7, 314183) Trichy would have contributed much more but that money would be valueless, if khadi, produced by the sacred hands of villagers, was not used by them.
('40', 134, 3, 8, 314333) When khadi became universal, it would not be necessary to extend monetary assistance.
('40', 134, 3, 9, 314419) That khadi required a bounty showed they were not doing their duty by the starving millions, on whom depend their sustenance.
('40', 134, 4, 10, 314545) Mahatmaji then referred to the fouling of river water and said that, on one side of the sacred Cauvery is Trichinopoly and on the other Srirangam.
('40', 134, 4, 11, 314692) What he was about to say was not peculiar to Trichy.
('40', 134, 4, 12, 314745) It was common all over India.
('40', 134, 4, 13, 314775) He wished to draw their attention to this because Trichinopoly had got an army of workers who could, if they would, tackle this very difficult problem.
('40', 134, 4, 14, 314927) Continuing, he said: I had the pleasure of having a talk with the Chairman of the Srirangam Municipality yesterday and the young men of Vivekan anda Ashram at Srirangam this morning.
('40', 134, 4, 15, 315110) Everybody admits that the sanitation of Srirangam is not in a good condition at all.
('40', 134, 4, 16, 315195) In my humble opinion, the insanitation is not due to want of funds, nor is the fouling of river water due to want of funds.
('40', 134, 4, 17, 315319) It is purely due to our criminal apathy.
('40', 134, 4, 18, 315360) We refuse to see the dirt that is daily growing in front of us.
('40', 134, 4, 19, 315424) It really requires an army of volunteers who would understand the ABC of sanitation and who would educate the people at large in the elementary laws of sanitary science.
('40', 134, 4, 20, 315594) It cannot be right to wash our dirt in the same river from which we take our drinking water.
('40', 134, 4, 21, 315687) Our river banks should be places of recreation for all, young and old, banks on which we could with the greatest safety and ease recline ourselves but it is just the river banks which we make unfit, even for walking with bare feet.
('40', 134, 4, 22, 315919) It has become abundantly clear by this time that cholera comes out of filthy habits and nothing else.
('40', 134, 4, 23, 316021) Immediately you cease to drink dirty water and take necessary precaution there is no fear of cholera.
('40', 134, 4, 24, 316123) I understand that when the great floods overtook the South, as it has overtaken Orissa at present, cholera broke out in Trichinopoly and Srirangam and it was an infliction from
('40', 135, 0, 1, 316300) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 135, 1, 2, 316342) God Himself because we people drank the river water which was made dirty by ourselves.
('40', 135, 1, 3, 316429) In my opinion we sinned against God and man when we did not take care to keep mother earth and our river water clean.
('40', 135, 1, 4, 316547) We have poetry enough in ourselves to call earth “mother earth” and deify all rivers of India.
('40', 135, 1, 5, 316642) What a sacrilege it is to dirty “mother earth” in the manner we are doing and to make the waters of all rivers, which we deify, filthy!
('40', 135, 1, 6, 316778) It is really a simple matter for the youth of Trichinopoly and Srirangam to make up their minds to educate the people and to visit river banks from morning to morning till they have eradicated the evil from their midst.
('40', 135, 1, 7, 316998) We do not need to become municipal councillors or have any appointment from any public body and the Government in order to do this work.
('40', 135, 1, 8, 317135) Nor does it require a great deal of time.
('40', 135, 1, 9, 317177) All that you need to do is merely to have a little bit of knowledge of sanitary science and a fixed determination to get rid of the evil which is undermining the health of the population.
('40', 135, 1, 10, 317365) I hope therefore that you will all understand the humble message I have endeavoured to give you and do something to retrieve the honour of Trichinopoly and Srirangam and to make the Cauvery really sacred as we consider it.
('40', 135, 2, 11, 317588) Mahatmaji then referred to the eradication of the drink evil for which the young men had ample opportunities of service among the labouring population which was a great one here.
('40', 135, 2, 12, 317767) Even as insanitation was undermining their health, the drink curse was undermining the health and morals of the labouring population.
('40', 135, 2, 13, 317901) [Concluding, Gandhiji said:] We have a real national awakening.

('40', 137, 1, 2, 320769) 82. “RANGILA RASUL”
('40', 137, 2, 3, 320789) In spite of the goading of correspondents, wise and otherwise, I have hitherto resisted the temptation to be drawn into the controversy that has arisen over this pamphlet.
('40', 137, 2, 4, 320961) I have endeavoured patiently to deal with these correspondents by private correspondence.
('40', 137, 2, 5, 321051) But of late the correspondence has increased beyond my capacity to deal with it privately.
('40', 137, 2, 6, 321142) The last letter is from a Muslim professor in Bihar.
('40', 137, 2, 7, 321195) He sends me a newspaper cutting containing a letter rebuking me in that even I had chosen to join in the conspiracy of silence observed by the leading Hindus in general.
('40', 137, 2, 8, 321365) The professor wants me to “reply sharp”.
('40', 137, 2, 9, 321406) I gladly do so in the hope that my correspondents will be satisfied with my good faith and understand the reason for my silence.
('40', 137, 2, 10, 321535) As I do not read newspapers, save a local one, I know nothing about the “conspiracy of silence” by Hindu leaders.
('40', 137, 2, 11, 321649) The newspaper I read most frequently just now is The Hindu and I do remember having seen in it a strong article against the Rangila Rasul.
('40', 137, 2, 12, 321788) So far as I am concerned, long before many Mussalmans knew even of the existence of the pamphlet, it came into my possession.
('40', 137, 2, 13, 321914) In order to test the veracity of my informant, I read it and wrote the following note 1 in Young India, dated 19th June, 1924: Then followed protests from Arya Samajists enclosing viler writing against Arya Samajists and the great founder Rishi Dayanand, telling me that Rangila Rasul and such writings were in answer to the Muslim writings referred to above.
('40', 137, 2, 14, 322274) I thereupon wrote the following second note 2 (Young India, 10th July, 1924): Thus I had anticipated the Mussalman wrath.
('40', 137, 2, 15, 322396) But in the present agitation the meeting point ends there.
('40', 137, 2, 16, 322455) I could not approve of the turn the agitation took.
('40', 137, 2, 17, 322507) I regarded it as excessive and inflammatory.
('40', 137, 2, 18, 322552) The attack against Justice Duleepsingh 3 was uncalled for, undeserved and hysterical.
('40', 137, 2, 19, 322638) The judiciary is by no means above being influenced by
('40', 137, 3, 20, 322693) 1 Not reproduced here; vide “Notes (subtopic Inflammatory Literature)”, June 19, 1924. 2 Not reproduced here; vide “Notes (subtopic Half a Dozen and Six)”, July 10, 1924. 3 Judge of the Punjab High Court who had on appeal acquitted the author of the pamphlet, prosecuted and sentenced by the lower courts under Section 153 A of the Indian Penal Code.
('40', 138, 0, 1, 323044) VOL.40 : 2 SEPTEMBER 1927, 1 DECEMBER, 1927 139
('40', 138, 1, 2, 323092) the Government, but it would be wholly unfit to render justice if it was open to popular attacks, threats and insults.
('40', 138, 1, 3, 323211) So far as the Judge’s integrity was concerned, it should have satisfied any Mussalman that he condemned the pamphlet, as he did, in unmeasured terms.
('40', 138, 1, 4, 323361) His reading of the section ought not to have been made a cause for virulent attack against him.
('40', 138, 1, 5, 323457) That other judges have taken a different view from Justice Duleepsingh is irrelevant to the issue.
('40', 138, 1, 6, 323556) Judges have been often known before now to have given honest and opposite interpretations of the same law.
('40', 138, 1, 7, 323663) The agitation for strengthening the penal section may be wise.
('40', 138, 1, 8, 323726) Personally I question the wisdom.
('40', 138, 1, 9, 323760) Any stiffening of the section will react against ourselves, and will be utilized, as such sections have been utilized before, for strengthening the hold of British authority over our necks.
('40', 138, 1, 10, 323950) But if Mussalmans or Hindus want to agitate for unequivocally bringing such writings under the criminal law, they have a right to do so.
('40', 138, 1, 11, 324087) I hold strong views about Government protection.
('40', 138, 1, 12, 324136) Time was when we knew better and disdained the protection of law courts in such matters.
('40', 138, 1, 13, 324225) To stop anti Muslim writings like the Rangila Rasul is the work of Hindus as to stop anti Hindu writings is the work of Mussalmans.
('40', 138, 1, 14, 324357) The leaders have either lost control over mud flingers or are in sympathy with them.
('40', 138, 1, 15, 324442) In any case Government protection will not make us tolerant of one another.
('40', 138, 1, 16, 324518) Each hater of the other’s religion will under a stiffer law seek secret channels of making vicious attacks on his opponent’s religion, or writing vilely enough to provoke anger but veiled enough to avoid the penal clauses of the law.
('40', 138, 1, 17, 324752) But then I recognize that at the present moment we are not acting as sane nationalists or as men of religion.
('40', 138, 1, 18, 324862) We are seeking under cover or religion to wreak mad vengeance upon one another.
('40', 138, 1, 19, 324942) My correspondents, both Hindu and Mussalman, should understand that I am just now out of tune with the prevailing atmosphere.
('40', 138, 1, 20, 325068) I recognize fully that I have no power over the fighters whether Hindu or Muslim.
('40', 138, 1, 21, 325150) My solution for removing the tension is, I admit, not suited to the times.
('40', 138, 1, 22, 325225) I therefore best serve the nation by holding my peace.
('40', 138, 1, 23, 325280) But my faith in my solution is as immovable as my faith in the necessity and the possibility of real Hindu Muslim unity.
('40', 138, 1, 24, 325401) Though therefore my helplessness is patent, there is no hopelessness is me.
('40', 138, 1, 25, 325477) And as I believe that silent prayer is often mightier than any overt act, in my helplessness I continuously pray in the faith that the prayer of a pure heart never goes unanswered.
('40', 138, 1, 26, 325658) And with all the strength at my command, I try to become a pure instrument for acceptable prayer.

('40', 140, 3, 8, 328616) 84. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KANADUKATHAN 1
('40', 140, 4, 9, 328661) September 22, 1927
('40', 140, 5, 10, 328680) FRIENDS, I thank you for this purse.
('40', 140, 5, 11, 328717) I am both glad and sad to be in your midst.
('40', 140, 5, 12, 328761) I want to have a heart to heart talk with you this evening.
('40', 140, 5, 13, 328821) Being born in a Vaisya family, I suppose I may identify myself with you and claim to be a Chetti myself.
('40', 140, 5, 14, 328926) I came in touch with your family life when I was in Rangoon with Dr. Mehta.
('40', 140, 5, 15, 329002) I was at that time a youngster and as we walked through Mughal Street, he showed me the rows of veran dahs and counters and pointed out people busily engaged practically the whole day long counting rupees on their wooden trays.
('40', 140, 5, 16, 329230) He said that these were all Chettis and from their appearance and their verandahs I might make a mistake by thinking that these were all petty money lenders.
('40', 140, 5, 17, 329388) He said that they were not petty money lenders but they were big money lenders and some of them were fabulously rich.
('40', 140, 5, 18, 329506) I had known some Chettis before this acquaintance with them in Rangoon and South Africa.
('40', 140, 5, 19, 329595) I then knew some of them as my acquaintances but I did not know, as I knew in Rangoon, that you had monopolized practically the money lending business in Rangoon.
('40', 140, 5, 20, 329758) I then recall your acquaintance at close quarters in 1920 1 when I passed through Chettinad and made collections for Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('40', 140, 5, 21, 329894) I well remember the extreme kindness that you showed me then and that
('40', 140, 6, 22, 329964) 1 Extracts from Gandhiji’s speeches at Kanadukathan, Karaikudi, Amaravatipur and Devakottah were strung together by Mahadev Desai under the title “Message to Chettinad”, in Young India, 6 10 1927. 2 Actually 1921; vide “Speech at Kanadukathan”, September 22, 1921.
('40', 141, 0, 1, 330229) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 141, 1, 2, 330271) you are repeating now.
('40', 141, 1, 3, 330294) But at that time mine was really a hurricane tour and I had no leisure to think of anything else or to enquire into anything else and I was swaraj mad.
('40', 141, 1, 4, 330446) I am still for that matter swaraj mad but God has chastened me.
('40', 141, 1, 5, 330510) My little tin pot plan for swaraj was not very evidently His.
('40', 141, 1, 6, 330572) And He has now further blessed me with physical illness which makes it impossible for me to go on in that hurricane fashion.
('40', 141, 1, 7, 330697) Thus it is possible for me to study your life and understand you better, much better, than I was able in 1920. The best and only way I can return your extreme kindness is to give you the result of my somewhat summary study.
('40', 141, 1, 8, 330921) That study has been helped by two letters that I have from unknown friends in Chettinad giving me a description of your life.
('40', 141, 1, 9, 331047) But before I enter upon that let me urge you to make khadi your own much more fully than you seem to have done.
('40', 141, 1, 10, 331159) If you wish it, you have the power of financing the whole of the khadi movement in Tamil Nadu and for that matter in the whole of India.
('40', 141, 1, 11, 331296) As I have said to my Marwari friends, the Chettis of the North, I can say to you also that if you wish it you can really finance the khadi movement purely out of your superfluity.
('40', 141, 1, 12, 331476) With your marvellous shrewdness you can even orga nize khadi.

('40', 141, 1, 14, 331729) Though the amount may be, I have not counted it, a few thousands, it is really but a drop in the ocean of your own wealth.
('40', 141, 1, 15, 331852) If you really believe in khadi, if you have understood the message of the spinning wheel then, but not till then, I want you to give not little out of your plenty but much out of your plenty.
('40', 141, 1, 16, 332044) And what is khadi after all?
('40', 141, 1, 17, 332073) Khadi represents the cause of the starving millions and let not those who have either riches or power, in the pride of their riches or power forget these starving millions.
('40', 141, 1, 18, 332246) I urge you therefore to befriend this great cause of the starving millions and make that cause your own.
('40', 141, 1, 19, 332351) And if you will but do so, you will discard all your foreign cloth and foreign fineries and get if you will the richest khadi you want and the finest khadi your taste may demand.
('40', 141, 1, 20, 332530) When I saw your houses choked with foreign furniture, your houses furnished with all kinds of foreign fineries and foreign things, your houses containing many things for which in this holy land of ours there should be no room what so ever I told you at the outset that I had felt both glad and sad.
('40', 141, 1, 21, 332829) I tell you that I have felt oppressed with this inordinate furniture.
('40', 141, 1, 22, 332899) There is, in the midst of this furniture, hardly

('40', 142, 1, 2, 332996) any room to sit or to breathe free.
('40', 142, 1, 3, 333032) Some of your pictures are hideous and not worth looking at.
('40', 142, 1, 4, 333092) I recall the many signs and the many descriptions of the simplicity of even the rich men in the time of the Mahabharata.
('40', 142, 1, 5, 333213) Let us not wear our wealth so loudly as we seem to be doing here.
('40', 142, 1, 6, 333279) This temperate atmosphere and climate of our country really does not admit of this lavish display of all these things.
('40', 142, 1, 7, 333398) It obstructs the free flow of pure air and it harbours dust and so many million germs that float in the air.
('40', 142, 1, 8, 333507) If you give me a contract for furnishing all these palaces of Chettinad I would furnish them with onetenth of the money but give you a much better accommodation and comfort than you enjoy today and procure for myself a certificate from the artists of India that I had furnished your houses in a much more artistic fashion than you have done.
('40', 142, 1, 9, 333849) I say also that all these palaces are really built anyhow without any sense of co operation amongst yourselves and any sense of social effect and social welfare.
('40', 142, 1, 10, 334011) If you will but form a union of Chettis for the common welfare and for the welfare of the peasantry that is living in your midst you can really make Chettinad a fairyland that would attract all the people of India who would come, see and be satisfied with the ordinary life that you would be then leading.
('40', 142, 1, 11, 334317) So much for the external part of your life.
('40', 142, 1, 12, 334361) I want to plead also for internal purity.
('40', 142, 1, 13, 334403) I have the good fortune of enjoying the confidence of many moneyed friends and I have the information and I guess also that you, the moneyed Chettis, are not free from the weaknesses common to the men of wealth all through the world.
('40', 142, 1, 14, 334637) But it need not be so.
('40', 142, 1, 15, 334660) We have the celebrated instance of Janaka, the King rolling in riches and yet he was the incarnation of purity.
('40', 142, 1, 16, 334772) I therefore plead for personal purity of life.
('40', 142, 1, 17, 334819) It is really the element of manly life.
('40', 142, 1, 18, 334859) Manliness for man is to regard every woman as his sister, mother or daughter according to her age, except his own wife.
('40', 142, 1, 19, 334979) I want, therefore, fellow Chettis, to be as strict as it is humanly possible with themselves and conduct rigorous self examination.
('40', 142, 1, 20, 335111) Let your charities be also wise.
('40', 142, 1, 21, 335144) I understand that you spend lavishly on building temples.
('40', 142, 1, 22, 335202) It is no doubt a good thing to build some temples but the building of temples could easily be overdone.
('40', 142, 1, 23, 335306) It is a horrible superstition to think that, because we have built a building which we call a temple, God necessarily resides in it.
('40', 142, 1, 24, 335439) I tell you I know many temples in India in which God no more resides than in a brothel.
('40', 142, 1, 25, 335527) Some good friends like yourselves have given me some

('40', 143, 1, 2, 335622) money to build temples for the so called untouchables.
('40', 143, 1, 3, 335677) I have refused to spend that money in building a single temple for which I cannot get a holy man and for whose work I cannot get honest trustees.
('40', 143, 1, 4, 335823) The greatest charity at the present moment that I can conceive for any Indian to do is undoubtedly to promote this khadi work.
('40', 143, 1, 5, 335950) Our rich friends are fond of giving free dinners to the so called poor people.
('40', 143, 1, 6, 336029) I have often questioned the virtue of giving these dinners.
('40', 143, 1, 7, 336089) The Bhagavad Gita says that that gift only is a good gift which is given to a worthy man.
('40', 143, 1, 8, 336179) 1 Therefore it would be right to feed the blind, the maimed and those who somehow or other cannot work for a living.
('40', 143, 1, 9, 336296) But I make bold to say that if all of you conspired together and set apart a fixed sum for feedng 50,000 men in the villages of India free of charge it would be a great sin.
('40', 143, 1, 10, 336470) The man who has got good arms and good legs and honest work in front of him is not a man in need of free dinner.
('40', 143, 1, 11, 336583) The greatest need of India is work for the starving villagers in their own homes; and I tell you that every rupee that you give for the promotion of khadi means 16 meals to 16 women after they have worked for those meals.
('40', 143, 1, 12, 336805) Almost equally great is the charity in connection with the criminal waste that is going on of cattle life in India.
('40', 143, 1, 13, 336921) And he who conducts a good dairy and a good tannery saves several hundred cattle.
('40', 143, 1, 14, 337003) So if you will make Chettinad an ideal place for you to live in and every people like myself to come and pass a weary day, I would expect not only to make Chettinad a model of sanitation but I would expect you to have good cattle depots, good warehouses where you will have all kinds of cattle stocked and I would expect you also to show an ideal model dairy which will supply yourselves and the poor people round you with good, nice and pure milk at cheap rates and I would expect you to build tanneries where hides of dead cattle should be secured and turned out into shoes for the rich and the poor.

('40', 145, 9, 23, 340918) FRIENDS, I thank you for the purse that you have just given me and I hope you will excuse me for my ignorance about this place or its people and it was only upon my enquiry just now I came to know that this was the place that supplied national workers in this part of the country.
('40', 145, 9, 24, 341199) I have been saying to the rich people of India that if they would establish a living bond between themselves and the starving millions, they cannot do it better than by adopting khadi and the message of
('40', 145, 10, 25, 341402) 1Vide the preceding item.

('40', 146, 1, 2, 341476) the spinning wheel.
('40', 146, 1, 3, 341496) You have, therefore, certainly done will in giving me this purse for khadi.
('40', 146, 1, 4, 341572) And I should like you to give not the least you can but the most you can.
('40', 146, 1, 5, 341646) And if you have not given the most I suggest to all the rich people of this place that they should put their hands deep into their pockets and give what they properly consider a decent sum.
('40', 146, 1, 6, 341836) But even though you may give the most you can in the shape of money, I would not consider that to be the best work or the most you can do for khadi.
('40', 146, 1, 7, 341985) If you believe in the message of the spinning wheel then it is easy enough for me to convince you that you cannot do anything even by giving me all your wealth for khadi unless you are prepared to wear khadi; for unless we wear khadi it is perfectly useless to have it manufactured by the poor people.
('40', 146, 1, 8, 342287) I would, therefore, ask every one of you who has not become yet habitual wearer of khadi to discard the use of all foreign cloth and adopt khadi exclusively for his use.
('40', 146, 1, 9, 342457) And what I said to men applies to all sisters who are gathered around me.
('40', 146, 1, 10, 342531) I suppose as was done in Karaikudi here also you have fed poor people.
('40', 146, 1, 11, 342602) If you have done so, while I am prepared to admit that it does credit to your heart I do not consider that it has really added any more to your merit.
('40', 146, 1, 12, 342753) I am sure that many people of India do not want to make poor people beggars and paupers.
('40', 146, 1, 13, 342842) And so what I said last night I repeat tonight that the best charity that moneyed people can make today is to support khadi organization.
('40', 146, 1, 14, 342980) A rupee given to khadi means giving honest work to 16 women per day giving them also one anna each.
('40', 146, 1, 15, 343080) And if you want to become a self respecting people you should see that everyone gets honest work and gets an honest pay for the work that he or she does.
('40', 146, 1, 16, 343234) And may I repeat what I said last night that rich people need repeatedly to be reminded that after all personal purity of life is the best riches in the world?
('40', 146, 1, 17, 343394) I know what terrible temptation riches put in the way of men constantly doing evil.
('40', 146, 1, 18, 343478) I would like you, therefore, to examine, each one of you individually to examine, yourselves and eradicate wherever that evil exists in your breast.
('40', 146, 1, 19, 343627) Amaravati means literally ‘the abode of God’.
('40', 146, 1, 20, 343673) How I wish you can make your town or your city really the abode of God.
('40', 146, 1, 21, 343745) You can easily do so if you will be clean both outside and inside.
('40', 146, 1, 22, 343812) If we honestly think within ourselves each one of us will be able to see that cleanliness like swaraj is really our birthright.
('40', 146, 1, 23, 343940) The route leading to swaraj is self control.
('40', 146, 1, 24, 343985) And self control means personal cleanliness.

('40', 147, 1, 2, 344072) But I have been watching during my stay in Chettinad that so far as outward corporate cleanliness is concerned, it is really lacking.
('40', 147, 1, 3, 344206) If you all adopt concerted measures you can make your streets, your tanks and your surroundings spotlessly clean.

('40', 147, 1, 8, 344943) When I was on the Nandi Hills I saw that the tank from which drinking water was drawn by the dwellers on those hills was all day long well guarded against pollution.
('40', 147, 1, 9, 345109) Bathing tanks must be separate from the tanks that supply drinking water.
('40', 147, 1, 10, 345183) I know that the inward cleanliness of which I have talked is a more difficult and intricate proposition than the sanitation that I have just talked to you about.
('40', 147, 1, 11, 345345) But having been in my own days in possession of some amount of money I want to present you with my own recipe of how you can attain compara tively [sic] personal cleanliness although you may possess riches.
('40', 147, 1, 12, 345552) That recipe is nothing original that I am going to give you.
('40', 147, 1, 13, 345613) It is really a part of our religion and it is this that no matter how much money we have earned we should regard ourselves as trustees holding these moneys for the welfare of all our neighbours.
('40', 147, 1, 14, 345808) There is a verse which says that he who eats without sacrifice, that is without giving, is a thief.
('40', 147, 1, 15, 345908) 1 If God gives us power and wealth He gives us the same so that we may use them for the benefit of mankind and not for our selfish carnal purpose.
('40', 147, 1, 16, 346055) I would also commend to your attention the question of untouchability.
('40', 147, 1, 17, 346126) You rich people of Amaravatipur have a warm corner in your heart for those who are miscalled untouchables.
('40', 147, 1, 18, 346233) It is sinful to call a single human being an untouchable because he is born in particular surroundings.
('40', 147, 1, 19, 346337) Give them therefore wealth as if they are your own kith and kin, as really they are, and spend your riches for their well being.
('40', 147, 1, 20, 346466) I would beseech you not to dismiss what I have told you this evening but treasure them and translate into practice whatever you are capable of.
('40', 147, 1, 21, 346610) May God bless you!

('40', 155, 3, 7, 363736) I was not at all worried though I was certainly surprised.
('40', 155, 3, 8, 363795) What is your method of going to the villages?
('40', 155, 3, 9, 363841) Do you go there alone or with a companion?
('40', 155, 3, 10, 363884) Have the floods 2 left any impression on the people’s mind or is it altogether gone?
('40', 155, 3, 11, 363969) During the floods all lived in harmony.
('40', 155, 3, 12, 364009) Does it now seem a dream?
('40', 155, 3, 13, 364035) Do the people help in the relief work?
('40', 155, 3, 14, 364074) And those who accept help, are they generally honest?
('40', 155, 3, 15, 364128) What is Balkrishna’s state?
('40', 155, 3, 16, 364156) Chhotelal has again gone into silence.
('40', 155, 3, 17, 364195) I am quite happy.

('40', 155, 4, 19, 364390) and I have faith, therefore, that the wounds will heal.
('40', 155, 4, 20, 364446) Even if they do not heal, is it not promise of the Gita that one who falls in this battle meets with nothing but good?

('40', 156, 4, 9, 365365) 95. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KARAIKUDI
('40', 156, 5, 10, 365405) September 25, 1927
('40', 156, 6, 11, 365424) FRIENDS, I thank you for address and the different purses, the chief purse containing over Rs. 4,000. It is a good purse but not good enough for the people of Chettinad and it is certainly not good enough, when I compared it to the seventeen rupee purse given to me by the Adi Dravida boys.
('40', 156, 6, 12, 365715) You can well afford to give four times as much whereas the Adi Dravida boys could give four times as much whereas the Adi Dravida boys could hardly afford to give as much as they have given.
('40', 156, 6, 13, 365906) Nevertheless I am thankful for whatever you have been able to give for Daridranarayana out of a willing heart.
('40', 156, 6, 14, 366017) I wish to start my remarks by repeating the offer I made yesterday, at last night’s meeting.
('40', 156, 6, 15, 366110) I want to expose to you this beautiful piece of art prepared in your own place, and the yarn of this beautifully fine muslin which I call khadi was spun by Mr. Chokkalingam of this place.
('40', 156, 6, 16, 366298) I had the pleasure of seeing the very different processes through which he passed his cotton before he could draw his thread so fine as the threads from which this khadi piece is woven.
('40', 156, 6, 17, 366484) And if you had witnessed his handicraft you would have envied with me and with me you would have also been proud of his art.
('40', 156, 6, 18, 366609) I cannot make any personal use of so fine a piece of muslin.
('40', 156, 6, 19, 366670) If therefore I cannot evoke your love of local art and love of the country, I must take this piece away and put it among the exhibits of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('40', 156, 6, 20, 366844) But I would really like you to possess this piece of cloth.
('40', 156, 6, 21, 366904) If you will do so, you have to pay a fancy price for it.
('40', 156, 6, 22, 366961) Works of art all the world over carry always fancy prices and I have fixed the reserve price of this piece of cloth at Rs. 1,000;
('40', 157, 0, 1, 367091) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 157, 1, 2, 367133) but you may, if you wish, ask what is the artistic value about this piece of cloth or in other words you may, if you wish, enquire why is it that I value khadi so much as I do.
('40', 157, 1, 3, 367310) I was told by one who has lived in your midst for years that there are in Chettinad many people who do not understand the message of the spinning wheel nor do they understand how all these purses are to be utilized.
('40', 157, 1, 4, 367526) I propose to devote a few sentences by way of explanation of the message of the spinning wheel.
('40', 157, 1, 5, 367622) It is designed to provide work for millions of starving men and women who are living in the seven hundred thousand villages of the land.
('40', 157, 1, 6, 367759) Everyone who knows anything about India has testified that they have no work for nearly six months in the year and apart from the spinning wheel it is impossible to find work for these millions of people, and so, through the spinning wheel we can produce sufficient cloth to cover the whole of India.
('40', 157, 1, 7, 368060) And I venture to suggest that anything produced by the hands of starving millions such as this muslin is necessarily a work of art.
('40', 157, 1, 8, 368192) All art that is true and living must have some correspondence to the life that we live.
('40', 157, 1, 9, 368280) True art must not debase life but it must sustain and ennoble life.
('40', 157, 1, 10, 368348) And now you understand why I prize khadi so much.
('40', 157, 1, 11, 368398) But it would be valueless if you and I do not wear khadi.
('40', 157, 1, 12, 368456) Now I shall tell you something about the organization which is producing khadi and selling it.
('40', 157, 1, 13, 368551) There are 1,500 villages at least being served through this organization.
('40', 157, 1, 14, 368625) In these 1,500 villages over fifty thousand sisters are receiving the benefit of the spinning wheel and through this spinning wheel nearly five thousand weavers are weaving the yarn spun by these fifty thousand women.
('40', 157, 1, 15, 368843) Side by side with these spinners and weavers a class of men has been brought into being who do the special laundry work that is required in connection with the khadi as also dyeing and printing.
('40', 157, 1, 16, 369038) The whole of the beautiful art of printing and dyeing which had become extinguished in Masulipatam and elsewhere has now been revived and has been given an honourable palce.
('40', 157, 1, 17, 369212) It was through this organization that over seven lakhs of rupees were distributed amongst a network of workers.
('40', 157, 1, 18, 369324) And if it is of any consequence to you to know, let me inform you that the vast majority of these artisans are non Brahmins.
('40', 157, 1, 19, 369449) This organization is being condcuted and controlled by a council of nine men, the majority of whom are again non Brahmins, if you want to know that.
('40', 157, 1, 20, 369598) Its president is a non Brahmin who is miscalled Mahatma.
('40', 157, 1, 21, 369655) (Laughter.) Its treasurer is again a non Brahmin whose qualities as a treasurer are not to be surpassed by any treasurer on the face of the earth and its
('40', 158, 0, 1, 369809) VOL. 40: 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 159
('40', 158, 1, 2, 369857) secretary is another non Brahmin, the son of a distinguished banker in Bombay.
('40', 158, 1, 3, 369936) This organization is finding work for nearly 1,000 middle class men, the majority of whom are again non Brahmins.
('40', 158, 1, 4, 370050) It has also some workers who not only get no honorarium whatsoever but actually feed this organization.
('40', 158, 1, 5, 370154) All the accounts of the central organization as also provincial organizations are periodically audited and those account may be inspected by friend and foe, donors or non donors.
('40', 158, 1, 6, 370333) No official of the organization gets more than Rs. 175 per month.
('40', 158, 1, 7, 370399) No man or woman can approach this organization or belong to it unless he or she is dominated by a spirit of self sacrifice.
('40', 158, 1, 8, 370523) When I mentioned women, I have pleasure in informing you that there are several distinguished daughters of India who are working for this khadi, free of charge.
('40', 158, 1, 9, 370684) For instance I may mention the three granddaughters of the Grand Old Man of India 1 and the distinguished sisters belonging to the great Petit family.
('40', 158, 1, 10, 370835) The organization is operating with a capital of about 20 lakhs of rupees.
('40', 158, 1, 11, 370909) But great as these figures may appear to yoy to be they are nothing when compared with what you and I should want them to be.
('40', 158, 1, 12, 371035) If the khadi spirit possesses the whole of India we should be serving not 1,500 but 7,00,000 villages and not fifty thousand spinners but one hundred million spinners.
('40', 158, 1, 13, 371203) It is for this work that I ask the rich people of chettinad not to give me some portion of their superfluity but a substantial portion of their substance.
('40', 158, 1, 14, 371358) You may also now understand that when I put the reserve price Rs. 1,000 upon this beautiful piece of khadi I rather underrate than overrate.
('40', 158, 1, 15, 371499) Now I must repeat in a hurried fashion some of the most important local matters about which I have been talking during the last four days of my pleasant stay in your midst.
('40', 158, 1, 16, 371672) I do urge you to look after your sanitation and your water supply.
('40', 158, 1, 17, 371739) Your palaces do not look to advantage at all in the midst of insanitary streets and tanks full of not pure sparkling water but foul water.
('40', 158, 1, 18, 371878) I can show you how you can do these things at an incredibly small expense, not out of your capital but out of your savings.
('40', 158, 1, 19, 372002) I understand that some of your marriage customs are very bad.
('40', 158, 1, 20, 372064) There is very often a price put upon the head of a bride as much as Rs. 30,000. I understand that you do not hesitate to spend as much as Rs. 50,000 per marriage; but this custom I consider to be immoral.
('40', 158, 1, 21, 372269) There can be no price put either way in the matter of such a sacred
('40', 158, 2, 22, 372337) 1 Dadabhai Naoroji
('40', 159, 0, 1, 372356) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 159, 1, 2, 372398) contract as marriage.
('40', 159, 1, 3, 372420) It must be as easy for a poor man to get a virtuous bride as for a rich man.
('40', 159, 1, 4, 372497) Merit and mutual love are the sole tests for marriage contracts.
('40', 159, 1, 5, 372562) The expenses for marriage ceremonies, though I do not consider them to be immoral, I regard them as a criminal waste.
('40', 159, 1, 6, 372680) It is not becoming of a rich man to dangle his wealth before the multitude in the fashion in which he very often does.
('40', 159, 1, 7, 372799) The art of amassing riches becomes a degrading and despicable art if it is not accompanied by the nobler art of how to spend wealth usefully.
('40', 159, 1, 8, 372941) So, out of this marriage reform alone and putting a wise restraint upon your extravagance on these ceremonies, you can turn this Chettinad into a fairylnd.
('40', 159, 1, 9, 373097) You can have if you will, without much effort, public parks, recreation grounds, water works and profitable dairies that will give supply of cheap and pure milk to the poor people living in your midst.
('40', 159, 1, 10, 373299) And as I tell you as a man of experience and as a fellow Chetti that you treble your earning resources if you conserve your health by wise sanitation, by an absolutely pure supply of water and by ensuring pure milk for the rich and the poor.
('40', 159, 1, 11, 373541) A lady doctor writing to me tells that I should remind you about the immoral custom that is prevalent in Chettinad and that prevents you from thinking of these things of public usefulness.
('40', 159, 1, 12, 373730) She tells me that the rich people of Chettinad had a due share in perpetuating a hideous immoral custom of assigning girls of tender age to a life of shame under the name of religion.
('40', 159, 1, 13, 373914) She tells me that there are many Devadasis 1 in your midst.
('40', 159, 1, 14, 373974) If this is true it is really a matter for hanging our heads in shame.
('40', 159, 1, 15, 374044) Let not possession of wealth be synonymous with degradation, vice and profligacy.
('40', 159, 1, 16, 374126) And is it not a tragic irony that, in spite of these vices, you are also spending money lavishly in erecting what you flatter yourselves to believe as temples for gods to reside.
('40', 159, 1, 17, 374305) Not every structure made of brick and mortar labelled temple is necessarily a temple.
('40', 159, 1, 18, 374391) There are, I am sorry to say, many temples in our midst in this country which are no better than brothels.
('40', 159, 1, 19, 374498) Do you know that in our religion it is not possible to call any single place a temple unless elaborate ceremonial of purification has been made inside that building and unless the spirit of God has been invoked by men full of piety, so that God may reside in that?
('40', 159, 1, 20, 374763) And so, I would urge you to restrain yourselves and not lavishly spend in building temples but in the first place dedicate your own bodies to the service of God and for that reason first of all purify by ridding
('40', 159, 2, 21, 374975) 1 Female dancers attached to a temple; literally, ‘maids of God’
('40', 160, 0, 1, 375040) VOL. 40: 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 161
('40', 160, 1, 2, 375088) yourselves of the evils to which I have drawn attention.
('40', 160, 1, 3, 375145) But I am gald to be able to inform you that I received only today a gratifying letter in which whilst the writer admits most of the evils to which I have referred just now he tells me that there are in your midst several noble minded Chettis rich enough not only in gold but in treasure of virtue also.
('40', 160, 1, 4, 375448) He tells me that there are in your midst several brahmacharis 1 going on with their godly life in a silent manner.
('40', 160, 1, 5, 375563) He also tells with hope and pride that several young men were conducting against heavy odds a reform movement and I assure these young men that whilst the path of reform is not all roses and that, whilst it is bestrewn with countless thorns, success is theirs if they will persevere prayerfully and with a pure heart.
('40', 160, 1, 6, 375881) I understood that they are gradually trying to solve one very difficult question that faces every one of you.
('40', 160, 1, 7, 375991) I understood that a rigid custom has grown up in your midst whereby no Chettiar going either to Burma, Singapore or Ceylon takes his wife with him.
('40', 160, 1, 8, 376139) I regard this bar sinister against your womanhood as a double drawback and a great sin.
('40', 160, 1, 9, 376227) It exposes you when you leave homes to avoidable temptations and it deprives your life partners for a number of years of the privilege of your companionship and the opportunity of broadening their outlook by travelling to distant lands with yourselves.
('40', 160, 1, 10, 376480) I wish these young men therefore very early success in their chivalrous fight and I urge the elders, to whom my voice may reach, to give every assistance to the young men in their endeavour to carry on the necessary reforms in your midst.
('40', 160, 1, 11, 376719) And now that silence prevails in this meeting and as this is perhaps the last meeting in Chettinad that I shall address, I should like to say a few words to the sisters in front of me.
('40', 160, 1, 12, 376904) I am glad to see so many of you attending this meeting.
('40', 160, 1, 13, 376960) I am afraid you have no notion that this message of khadi is a message principally devoted to the betterment of the condition of your starving sisters living in thousands of villages.
('40', 160, 1, 14, 377144) I do not know how much men in India will have to pay for keeping you, the women of India, in darkness about so many things of the highest importance in life, both to men and women.
('40', 160, 1, 15, 377325) But thanks to God that since the advent of the movement for reviving the spinning wheel, thousands of women have learnt to come out of their homes and listen to the music of the charkha.
('40', 160, 1, 16, 377512) And I would love to think that you, the women of Chettinad, had begun to think beyond the threshold of your houses or palaces.
('40', 160, 1, 17, 377639) I would like you to realize
('40', 160, 2, 18, 377667) 1 Celibates
('40', 161, 0, 1, 377679) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 161, 1, 2, 377721) the deep and distressful poverty of millions of your sisters and I would like you independently, apart from your men, to part with your possessions, your rupees and your jewellery for the sake of these sisters and it fills me with gladness to be able to tell you that the response from the women of India has been spontaneous so far as this message is concerned and they have even given their moneys and jewelleries willingly and in many cases lavishly.
('40', 161, 1, 3, 378175) But to give me money or your jewellery is by no means enough.
('40', 161, 1, 4, 378237) If you will establish a living bond between yourselves and your starving sisters, it is absolutely necessary for you to discard your foreign fineries and adopt khadi permanently for your wear; because, if you do not wear the products of their labours, all the money that you give for khadi is a waste of effort.
('40', 161, 1, 5, 378549) The beauty of a virtuous woman does not consist in the fineness of her dress but in the possession of a pure heart and virtuous life.
('40', 161, 1, 6, 378683) Millions of men and women all over India early in the morning invoke the blessed and immortal name of Sita in order that her name may surround them during the whole day with her protecting power, not because Sita wore costly jewels but because she bore a heart that was of pure gold and purer diamond.
('40', 161, 1, 7, 378985) Sita did not remain in her palace when Rama went into banish ment but she insisted upon accompanying him through all these eventful years of exile.
('40', 161, 1, 8, 379133) Sita did not consider Nishadaraja, whom in our ignorance we consider today, to be untouchable but Sita embraced Nishadaraja and accepted with a grateful heart the services he nobly rendered.
('40', 161, 1, 9, 379324) And I would like you to imitate Sita’s virtues, Sita’s humility, Sita’s simplicity and Sita’s bravery.
('40', 161, 1, 10, 379427) You should realize that Sita for the protection of her virtues did not need the assistance of Rama, her Lord and master.
('40', 161, 1, 11, 379548) The chronicler of the history of Sita and Rama tells us that it was the purity of Sita which was her sole shield and protection.
('40', 161, 1, 12, 379677) And if you will but recognize the power that resides in your breast it is open to you by force of your purity, love and spirit of self sacrifice to bend the haughty spirit of your men and shame them into forsaking the life of vices and debauchery.
('40', 161, 1, 13, 379925) I would like you to develop the courage to insist upon accompanying your husbands wherever they go.
('40', 161, 1, 14, 380025) May God give you that strength and goodwill.
('40', 161, 1, 15, 380070) I am now very nearly done and as is usual at all meetings I must follow the custom here also of asking those who have not yet contributed to this purse to do so if they believe in khadi and if they wish it.
('40', 161, 1, 16, 380277) I would also urge those men and sisters here to give if they
('40', 162, 0, 1, 380338) VOL. 40: 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 163
('40', 162, 1, 2, 380386) wish as much as they can and therfore if there are those who have not really given enough I would like them if they believe in the statistics I have given and in the importance of the message of khadi not to be niggardly but give generously.
('40', 162, 2, 3, 380628) [after this,] the auction of the jewels, silver cups and rings, etc., presented to Mahatmaji commenced.
('40', 162, 2, 4, 380732) Mr Shanmugam Chettiar announced that he was willing to give for the muslin cloth presented to Mahatmaji at Devakottah his (Mahatmaji’s) own fancy price of Rs. 1,000. .
('40', 162, 2, 5, 380900) A small ring which was presented to Mahatmaji for a second time worth not even 10 rupees fetched a fancy price of Rs. 135.
('40', 162, 3, 6, 381023) Gandhiji became responsive to the mood of the audience exhibited during the course of the auction and was touched by their boundless affection for him and addressed a few words after the auction, a thing unusual.
('40', 162, 3, 7, 381236) He said :
('40', 162, 4, 8, 381246) I shall never forget the scene.
('40', 162, 4, 9, 381278) This will remain as one of the pleasantest memories in my life.
('40', 162, 4, 10, 381342) I have had many a pleasant and unpleasant experiences in my life outside and this will remain among the very few pleasant remembrances and especially so because I have been saying ever since I have set my foot in Chettinad many unsavoury things to you.
('40', 162, 4, 11, 381595) You might have easily misunderstood my word and my motive.
('40', 162, 4, 12, 381654) But I have seen that the more harsh words I have spoken, the greater the affection you have showered on me.
('40', 162, 4, 13, 381762) You have received me as a blood brother and taken the words I have said exactly in the spirit I have delivered them to you.
('40', 162, 4, 14, 381886) That is really my joy.
('40', 162, 4, 15, 381909) But I would like you not to forget the words that I have spoken to you but I want every word I have said to you to penetrate your hearts and if I hear that the word having remained in your heart has fructified I think it would give me much greater joy than if you give me millions.
('40', 162, 4, 16, 382191) I have no use for your money except to serve you with it and it is a strange thing but it is true that I cannot serve you even with your own money if you do not give me your hearts.
('40', 162, 4, 17, 382373) And so in order that your money which is in my possession may bear amble fruit I request you to do what I have asked you to do.
('40', 162, 4, 18, 382501) You know that if you can do that, it will do good to you, it will do good to me and also the whole of India.
('40', 162, 4, 19, 382610) May God bless you and give you the power to understand my message and act up to it.
('40', 162, 5, 20, 382694) The Hindu, 27 9 1927

('40', 163, 3, 7, 383076) 97. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('40', 163, 4, 8, 383114) September 26, 1927
('40', 163, 5, 9, 383133) DEAR SATIS BABU, I have your letter.
('40', 163, 5, 10, 383170) Mahadev must have written to you about a Pratishthan travelling wheel for a local expert 3. He spins very fine.
('40', 163, 5, 11, 383282) He presented me with a piece of his thin muslin almost like Jogesh Babu’s.
('40', 163, 5, 12, 383357) I sold it for Rs. 1,000 to a local Chetti.

('40', 163, 5, 15, 383547) As soon as I get your improved pattern I shall use it and report to you.

('40', 163, 5, 17, 383655) They have not written to me.

('40', 166, 2, 25, 389980) 101. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, PAGANERI
('40', 166, 3, 26, 390020) September 27, 1927 It delights my heart to see so many sisters attending this meeting, almost the same number as men.
('40', 166, 3, 27, 390138) As I said at the women’s meeting at Karaikudi or elsewhere to the sisters there, the movement for which you have given these purses is essentially a movement for the freedom of the women of India.
('40', 166, 3, 28, 390335) The full freedom of India will be an impossibility unless your daughters stand side by side with the sons in the battle for freedom and such an association on absolutely equal
('40', 167, 0, 1, 390511) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 167, 1, 2, 390553) terms on the part of India’s millions of daughters is not possible unless they have a definite consciousness of their own power.
('40', 167, 1, 3, 390682) Immediately the spinning wheel is reinstated in all its glory and with all its implications in the millions of cottages of India, woman recognizes her definite power and her place in India’s regeneration.
('40', 167, 1, 4, 390887) For she is then able to say to men, ’you depend for your food and your clothes as much upon us as on yourselves.’ ‘We,’ she may say, ‘clean and cook your food, we spin the yarn from which khadi is prepared.’ then she is clothed with dignity which is hers by birthright and of which we, men and traitors of our womanhood, have deprived her.
('40', 167, 1, 5, 391227) For in our stupidity and in our ignorance we removed from each cottage spinning wheels and became infatuated with the foreign fineries that came to us from the West and became greedy after the sovereigns and rupees that would dangle before us, and whether by its own design or by an accident, be it however it may, we, men, conspired to keep our daughters and sisters and our wives in utter ignorance and we denied them the education to which they had a right.
('40', 167, 1, 6, 391688) In our ignorance we gave away our daughters in marriage at an age when they were able only to sit on the lap and play with us as brothers and sisters.
('40', 167, 1, 7, 391839) By constant usage you yourselves, sisters, who are sitting in front of me, have come to think that it is the most natural thing for you to give away your daughters early in the so called marriage and to keep them in dismal ignorance.
('40', 167, 1, 8, 392073) The message of the spinning wheel is designed to undo these terrible wrongs.
('40', 167, 1, 9, 392150) The spinning wheel gives the status to which a woman is entitled and it quickens the conscience both of men and women and enables man to understand his duty by the women of India.
('40', 167, 1, 10, 392330) If my word has penetrated the hearts of men and women around me you will immediately understand why I consider these purses from you as not adequate for the purpose for which they are intended.
('40', 167, 1, 11, 392524) I want you men and women to dismiss me from your minds altogether as a Mahatma dropped on you as a curse from heaven.
('40', 167, 1, 12, 392642) But I want you to realize in all significance the fact that I come before you as a self chosen humble servant and representative of Daridranarayana.
('40', 167, 1, 13, 392791) I want you to understand that what you have given me is not given and not to be given to feed my vanity and my ambitions, but to clothe and feed Daridranarayana who is knocking every day, in season and out of season, at your doors.
('40', 167, 1, 14, 393023) I have come to you to wake you up to a sense of duty by the starving millions on whom and on whose labour you and I are living.
('40', 167, 1, 15, 393151) Even your money, your jewellery, your rings and
('40', 168, 0, 1, 393199) VOL. 40: 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 169
('40', 168, 1, 2, 393247) your necklaces can be of no earthly use to me unless both men and women will wear khadi and nothing but that.
('40', 168, 1, 3, 393357) This collecting of purses for the spinning wheel is only a brief and intermediate interval.
('40', 168, 1, 4, 393449) When every man and woman in India naturally takes to khadi as they all take to the grains that are grown on India’s plains there will be as little use for these collections as there is for collection in order to carry on propaganda for clutivating rice and wheat in India.
('40', 168, 1, 5, 393722) And it is open to you today to shorten that interval as much as you like by adopting khadi, every one of you; and in order to saturate our atmosphere with the spirit of the spinning wheel, it is necessary for you, all the sisters who are sitting in front of me, to take up the spinning wheel and if you will, it can become a symbol of your purity and your independence.
('40', 168, 1, 6, 394092) And it is equally necessary for men to take up the spinning wheel as a sacrificial rite.
('40', 168, 1, 7, 394181) I cannot cheapen khadi and I cannot popularize khadi unless I have an army of expert spinners from men who and who alone can penetrate the villages and reinstate the spinning wheel by giving necessary instruction and by doing the organizing work.
('40', 168, 1, 8, 394428) And now let me repeat what I have said in other places in Tamil Nadu about the social reforms which await fulfilment at our hands.
('40', 168, 1, 9, 394559) Men’s lives must become pure.
('40', 168, 1, 10, 394589) Faithfulness on the part of the husband towards his wife is just as much a sacred obligation as faithfulness on the part of the wife towards her husband.
('40', 168, 1, 11, 394743) It is wrong, no matter what authority may be cited from the so called Shastras, for a man to have more than one wife.
('40', 168, 1, 12, 394861) It is wrong to sell daughters in marriage.
('40', 168, 1, 13, 394904) It is a sin to have a child widow in one’s house and it is equally sinful to give away a child in marriage or to refuse to call all such contracts or ceremonies as an absolute nullity.
('40', 168, 1, 14, 395089) And it is wrong also to keep our boys and girls without proper education and it is a heinous crime to regard a single human being as untouchable because he is born in a particular group of family.
('40', 168, 1, 15, 395286) If we had a true awakening in our midst we would deal with all these social evils and deal also with the insanitation around us.
('40', 168, 2, 16, 395415) The Hindu, 29 9 1927

('40', 171, 2, 7, 399858) As I was travelling to Madura filled with the vivid scenes that took place at Waltair and asking the thousands of people who met me at the various stations at least to discard foreign cloth and take up khadi, one or more of the poor people remonstrated with me and told me that they had no money to buy khadi with.
('40', 171, 2, 8, 400173) Though I do not think, so far as I recollect now, that the answers given to me were in every case honest, I nevertheless recognized the force of the remark made by some of these poor people who seemed to me to be in rags.
('40', 171, 2, 9, 400395) I then discussed with the companions who were with me the propriety of the change I am about to describe to you.

('40', 171, 2, 15, 401347) And if you travelled with me to these villages where you see pauperism in its nakedness, you will recognize with me the necessity of throwing away many of your

('40', 172, 2, 4, 401736) Whilst I congratulate the Municipality upon this achievement I must, to be true to you, tell you that it gives me no satisfaction whatsoever.
('40', 172, 2, 5, 401878) If the people living in the few cities and towns of India were to realize that their life, their comfort, their very existence depend upon these semi starved millions, they will not treat khadi and the spinning wheel as a mere pastime, a thing for patronizing.
('40', 172, 2, 6, 402139) Remember that India does not sustain her town life from wealth drawn from other countries.
('40', 172, 2, 7, 402230) It has to depend essentially, being almost entirely an agricultural country, for the building up of her towns purely upon what is received from the villages.
('40', 172, 2, 8, 402388) And after a careful study of the problem of India’s poverty and the various remedies that have been suggested to remedy that poverty even partially, I have not been able to see anything approaching the spinning wheel in usefulness.
('40', 172, 2, 9, 402620) And it is, in my humble opinion, the sacred duty of the people within the towns to make some slight return to the villagers for what they are obliged to do for them.
('40', 172, 2, 10, 402786) In my humble opinion this problem of the ever deepening poverty of India is much more important than even the very important question of Hindu Muslim unity and, for these parts of India, the very important question of Brahmin and non Brahmin controversy.

('40', 176, 1, 2, 412175) 105. THE NEILL STATUE AND NON VIOLENCE
('40', 176, 2, 3, 412214) A Gujarati friend thus remonstrates in a letter to a common friend : Sometimes Bapu’s non violence baffles one.
('40', 176, 2, 4, 412326) He encourages the agitation for the removal of the Neill statue as he encouraged the one for the removal of the Lawrence statue.
('40', 176, 2, 5, 412455) To me it looks very much like violence; for the agitation must beget hatred against Englishmen—the very thing Bapu wants to avoid.
('40', 176, 2, 6, 412586) And where I can see no violence he sees it, as in carrying arms for removing the Arms Act.
('40', 176, 2, 7, 412677) It appears to me that in the first case there is every risk of violent temper being begotten by apparently non violent means.
('40', 176, 2, 8, 412803) And this according to Bapu should be avoided.
('40', 176, 2, 9, 412849) In the second case only a slight risk or possibility of violence is incurred in order to achieve a worthy end—just the thing I should have imagined Bapu would brave.
('40', 176, 2, 10, 413015) In order to do justice to the argument and make it easily intelligible to the reader, I have somewhat extended the argument put cryptically in the original Gujarati.
('40', 176, 2, 11, 413181) Non violence is made of sterner stuff.
('40', 176, 2, 12, 413220) There is no doubt that the agitation for removing the Neill statue and the like is likely to increase the feeling of hatred against the English.
('40', 176, 2, 13, 413365) A reformer seeking to spread non violence must take note of the fact and guard against hatred, but dare not on any account hush causes of hatred.
('40', 176, 2, 14, 413511) Non violence in the form of love is the activest force in the world.
('40', 176, 2, 15, 413580) As the Gujarati poet Shamal says, “There is no merit in returning good for good; most men do this.
('40', 176, 2, 16, 413679) Merit lies in returning good for evil.” Merit here stands obviously for non violence.
('40', 176, 2, 17, 413765) Causes of hatred everywhere obtrude themselves on one’s gaze.
('40', 176, 2, 18, 413827) The seers of old saw that the only way of dealing with the situation was to neutralize hatred by love.
('40', 176, 2, 19, 413930) This force of love therefore truly comes into play only when it meets with causes of hatred.
('40', 176, 2, 20, 414023) True non violence does not ignore or blind itself to causes of hatred, but in spite of the knowledge of their existence operates upon the person setting these causes in motion.
('40', 176, 2, 21, 414200) Were it otherwise, the fight for swaraj by non violent means would be an impossibility.
('40', 176, 2, 22, 414288) For at every step the Swarajist is bound to expose to view the blemishes of foreign rule and the foreign rulers.
('40', 176, 2, 23, 414401) The law of non violence—returning good for evil, loving one’s enemy—involves a knowledge of the blemishes of the ‘enemy’.
('40', 176, 2, 24, 414523) Hence do the scriptures

('40', 177, 1, 2, 414589) say : ““ ˜–””—“Forgiveness is an attribute of the brave.” It is perhaps now clear why a believer in non violence must endorse my non violent agitation for the removal of the Neill statue and the like.
('40', 177, 1, 3, 414790) But the carrying of arms is not permissible for a non violent man, for he is expected not to use them.
('40', 177, 1, 4, 414893) And the total removal of the Arms Act in my opinion will never be held to be a just cause.

('40', 179, 1, 2, 418874) 106. COW SACRIFICE IN VEDAS
('40', 179, 2, 3, 418902) In Young India for June 2, was published an article by Sjt.
('40', 179, 2, 4, 418962) C. V. Vaidya making valuable suggestions about saving the cow and her progeny.
('40', 179, 2, 5, 419041) But in that article the learned writer gave his opinion that sacrificial cow slaughter and beef eating were prevalent in the Vedic age.
('40', 179, 2, 6, 419177) Pandit Satavalekar sent me in Hindi a refutation of Sjt.
('40', 179, 2, 7, 419234) Vaidya’s statement about cow sacrifice and beef eating in Vedic times.
('40', 179, 2, 8, 419305) As my purpose was merely to elucidate truth and not to have a newspaper controversy, I forwarded the article to Sjt.
('40', 179, 2, 9, 419422) Vaidya.
('40', 179, 2, 10, 419430) He promptly and courteously sent me his reply.
('40', 179, 2, 11, 419477) I submitted it to Pandit Satavalekar who sent his rejoinder.
('40', 179, 2, 12, 419538) I now give below the translations 1 by Mahadev Desai of Pandit Satavalekar’s writings and the reply of Sjt.
('40', 179, 2, 13, 419646) Vaidya in the original.
('40', 179, 2, 14, 419670) Pandit Satavalekar has in two numbers of his Vaidika Dharma given a more detailed and exhaustive argument supported by copious extracts from the Vedas in support of his opinion.
('40', 179, 2, 15, 419848) I refer the curious to these valuable articles.
('40', 179, 2, 16, 419896) As a layman not knowing the original, I follow the excellent rule that when there is the slightest doubt, it is best to lean on the right side, the right side in this case being the belief that those who gave us the Vedas were not guilty of what appears to our age to be the crime of killing cows for sacrifice or food.
('40', 179, 2, 17, 420216) The discussion has otherwise no bearing on the present age, because the veneration of the cow is too deeply embedded in the Hindu bosom to be affected by any opinion, however authoritative it may be, in favour of cow sacrifice and beef eating in the Vedic age.
('40', 179, 2, 18, 420477) It has however more than an academic value for those who incline to the belief that whatever was done during those ancient times should be revived in this age by every legitimate effort.
('40', 179, 2, 19, 420664) These may study Pandit Satavalekar’s article referred to by me and Sjt.
('40', 179, 2, 20, 420736) Vaidya’s published writings which are available as well in English as in Marathi and Hindi.

('40', 184, 11, 16, 430744) 111. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, MADURA
('40', 184, 12, 17, 430783) September 30, 1927
('40', 184, 13, 18, 430802) Mahatmaji began by thanking the ladies for their address and the purse as also the many presents of yarn and other things made to him by several girls and women.
('40', 184, 13, 19, 430964) He next asked them to learn Hindi which was the language spoken by their sisters in the North.
('40', 184, 14, 20, 431059) He asked them to remember that they had given him a purse not for his own use but for the use of millions of their starving sisters.
('40', 184, 14, 21, 431192) Living in com fort as they were, he was sure they would find it difficult to imagine the distressing poverty of thousands of their sisters, with hardly one meal a day.
('40', 184, 14, 22, 431360) There were others who had
('40', 184, 15, 23, 431386) 1Vide the succeeding item.
('40', 184, 15, 24, 431413) 2 This letter was written on the back of the above.
('40', 185, 0, 1, 431465) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 185, 1, 2, 431507) hardly sufficient clothing to cover up their nakedness.
('40', 185, 1, 3, 431563) He had talked to some of these poor sisters who had no second clothing whatever and had therefore to go on from day to day without bathing.
('40', 185, 1, 4, 431703) Needless to say they had no jewels or ornaments worth mentioning.
('40', 185, 1, 5, 431769) They might not have seen or tasted ghee, oil or milk.
('40', 185, 1, 6, 431823) Millions of them had no work for nearly four months in the year.
('40', 185, 1, 7, 431888) Perhaps they would not be inclined to believe what all he had said, but he would tell them that many foreigners too had observed these things and written about them.
('40', 185, 1, 8, 432054) It was for these poor sisters that he had accepted the purse from them.
('40', 185, 1, 9, 432126) The money was not to be distributed among them as charitable doles but was proposed to be given to them as wages in return for the yarn which they would be asked to spin.
('40', 185, 1, 10, 432297) They would be supplied with charkha and cotton and the yarn would be purchased from them.
('40', 185, 1, 11, 432387) He therefore considered the spinning wheel as the greatest instrument for bettering the condition of their poor sisters.
('40', 185, 1, 12, 432508) The spinning wheel would give them a ray of hope and a sense of self respect.
('40', 185, 1, 13, 432586) It would be a means of binding together all the many millions of people in India.
('40', 185, 1, 14, 432668) They should not rest content merely making a donation which would be of no use if they did not wear khaddar.
('40', 185, 1, 15, 432777) If really they had sympathy with their poor sisters they should wear only khadi, spun and woven by them.
('40', 185, 1, 16, 432882) It might appear at first sight that it is difficult to discard all foreign cloth but if they tried they would find it very easy of accomplishment.
('40', 185, 1, 17, 433029) If they would like to be Sita he would advise them to give up rich garments and jewels and take to khadi.
('40', 185, 1, 18, 433135) But before they parted with any of their jewels he would impose on them one condition, namely, that they should not ask their parents or their husbands to replace them.
('40', 185, 1, 19, 433304) He said that three or four years ago he was presented by a lady with fifteen thousand rupees worth of jewels.
('40', 185, 1, 20, 433414) He wanted them not only not to wear too many jewels but to be careful not to place their children in danger.
('40', 185, 1, 21, 433523) For, he had come to know of an incident which took place some few days ago at Madura in which a respectable gentleman’s daughter had been robbed of her jewels by some robbers.
('40', 185, 1, 22, 433699) He also wanted them to remember that a woman’s beauty did not consist in the jewels that she wore but in the possession of a pure heart.
('40', 185, 1, 23, 433836) They should also teach this truth to their children and train them to build up their character by giving them proper education.
('40', 185, 2, 24, 433964) Again he would tell them that it is sinful to regard any single human being as an untouchable simply because he was born in particular surroundings.
('40', 185, 2, 25, 434113) If they would copy Sita they would find that she did not regard even the king of the Nishadas as untouchable but gladly and gratefully accepted the services rendered by him.
('40', 185, 2, 26, 434287) He had therefore no hesitation in saying that the evil custom of untouchability must disappear.
('40', 185, 3, 27, 434383) Yet another important matter about which he liked to talk to them was early marriages.
('40', 185, 3, 28, 434470) They must realize that it was a barbarous system to marry girls at nine, twelve and even thirteen years.
('40', 185, 3, 29, 434575) He considered such a thing to be immoral too, and urged that no girl should be married or induced to think of marriage before she had
('40', 186, 0, 1, 434709) VOL. 40: 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 187
('40', 186, 1, 2, 434757) attained her sixteenth year.
('40', 186, 1, 3, 434786) He would even ask them not to heed the Hindu Shastras if they said that girls should be married before puberty.
('40', 186, 1, 4, 434898) Taking the case of some of the girls under his control he said that though some of them were aged from seventeen to twenty years, the girls had never thought of marriage till then.
('40', 186, 1, 5, 435079) On the contrary, some of them were having good education and at the present moment some of them were working for the relief of the distressed in the flood stricken areas in Gujarat.
('40', 186, 1, 6, 435261) He was also resolved not to think of their marriage until they themselves told him that they wanted to marry.
('40', 186, 1, 7, 435371) But he would tell them that all these evil customs would disappear if they took to khadi.
('40', 186, 1, 8, 435461) For the khadi spirit would make them pure and noble.
('40', 186, 1, 9, 435514) They should not think that any small quantity of yarn spun by them would be a trifle but sould remember that every bit of it augmented the country’s wealth.
('40', 186, 1, 10, 435671) In that light he would ask all of them to take to khadi and spin yarn for the sake of Daridranarayana.

('40', 186, 2, 12, 435795) 112. SPEECH AT TIRUMANGALAM
('40', 186, 3, 13, 435823) September 30, 1927
('40', 186, 4, 14, 435842) FRIENDS, I thank you for your address and the purse given to me.
('40', 186, 4, 15, 435907) In your address you have said that this place is one of the cotton centres.
('40', 186, 4, 16, 435983) I note also that in this place there are many poor spinners, and you tell me that if there were sufficient encouragement it would be possible to work nearly 1,000 spindles.
('40', 186, 4, 17, 436156) This spinning movement is undoubtedly designed to find work for every woman who has leisure hours and who wants to do some work for coppers.
('40', 186, 4, 18, 436297) You tell me that it is not possible for you to find a market for all these yarns that can be produced by one dozen men.
('40', 186, 4, 19, 436417) It shows that in your place or in your taluk you do not possess sufficient workers.
('40', 186, 4, 20, 436501) You ask me to see to it that this place is made a second Tiruppur.
('40', 186, 4, 21, 436568) But let me tell you that Tiruppur has made itself.
('40', 186, 4, 22, 436619) It was not I nor any member of the All India Spinners’ Association that has made Tiruppur what it is today.
('40', 186, 4, 23, 436727) It is true no doubt that the A.I.S.A. came on the scene to reap the fruit of the original workers.
('40', 186, 4, 24, 436826) This is an essential work that the Union Board can do and should do and if you have in your midst a body of workers there is no reason why all the yarns that have been produced in this place cannot be sold in the market, and if you go forward and do khadi work, I am sure you cannot find the local market sufficient.
('40', 186, 4, 25, 437143) The prices of the cloth produced in these parts will be fixed by the A.I.S.A. according to the nature of the cloth woven.
('40', 186, 4, 26, 437265) I am touring in
('40', 187, 0, 1, 437281) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 187, 1, 2, 437323) all these parts of the country not merely for purse collections but to do khadi propaganda work.
('40', 187, 1, 3, 437420) I would like the sisters who are sitting here to listen to this part ofmy speech.
('40', 187, 1, 4, 437502) This poor country has some millions of men and women idling away their time for four months in the year.
('40', 187, 1, 5, 437607) Being near the railway line, you are not half as poor as the poorest, on whose behalf I am touring and on whose behalf I am speaking to you this night.
('40', 187, 1, 6, 437759) And they are so poor that the reports issued by the Government tell us that there are some people who are starving for want of food.
('40', 187, 1, 7, 437892) I hope you will not make the mistake of thinking that if the railway line was brought near to every village in India the problem of distress will be solved.
('40', 187, 1, 8, 438049) If you study the history of the railways you will find that this railway system of ours is simply sucking the village and leaves it absolutely dry.
('40', 187, 1, 9, 438197) Railways, over the world, are necessary and may be prosperous to the people.
('40', 187, 1, 10, 438274) This country is predominantly an agricultural country and therefore railways are a burden to the village people.
('40', 187, 1, 11, 438387) If you wear khadi, the product that is produced by the poor villagers, then it will be a return for what we are sucking from them.
('40', 187, 1, 12, 438518) I ask all the men and women assembled here to discard foreign cloth and use nothing but hand spun and hand woven khadi.
('40', 187, 1, 13, 438638) I take this purse only on one condition, namely, that all of you will use only khadi in future.
('40', 187, 1, 14, 438734) I would like the sisters who are sitting here to understand that the spinning movement is essentially a woman’s movement.
('40', 187, 1, 15, 438856) To me the spinning wheel is a symbol of the liberation of Indian womanhood and I would like you therefore to co operate with me in this effort not merely by giving your money or ornaments but also by wearing khadi.
('40', 187, 1, 16, 439071) If you do not need spinning for your household work you can do it as a sacrifice.
('40', 187, 1, 17, 439153) If you do it, it will add to the wealth of the country and the price of khadi also will become low.

('40', 188, 1, 2, 439322) 113. DISCUSSION WITH A. VEDARAMA IYER 1
('40', 188, 2, 3, 439362) [About September 30, 1927] 2
('40', 188, 3, 4, 439391) I plead guilty to the charge 3 but the Association has been conceived in a different spirit.
('40', 188, 3, 5, 439484) I shall explain it to you.
('40', 188, 3, 6, 439511) We may expend thousands of rupees on the starving millions, that is to say, in making spinners of them all, but we may not spend a single pice on employing agencies to promote voluntary spinning.
('40', 188, 3, 7, 439707) Those who join the Association as voluntary spinners spin as a matter of sacrifice, and a sacrifice that needs external stimulation is no sacrifice at all.
('40', 188, 3, 8, 439863) I know there are slackers, I know our defaulters’ list is heavy, but I shall employ no agency to wake them up.
('40', 188, 3, 9, 439974) Those who in spite of the apathy around them will continue to perform their sacrifice regularly and offer their quota to the motherland will be the salt of the national movement, and they will survive me and even the movement.
('40', 188, 3, 10, 440201) But I do not exclude any voluntary agency.
('40', 188, 3, 11, 440244) For instance, you may try to stimulate your friends as much as you like, in fact it is the duty of every member of the Spinners’ Association to increase the membership and to see that every member pays his quota regularly.
('40', 188, 3, 12, 440467) And for vakils like you, that is, for those who have faith in the cause, it is the easiest thing possible.
('40', 188, 3, 13, 440574) You can entrust your clerk with the work, ask him to visit every member from time to time, collect their yarn quotas, and remind them if they are in arrears.
('40', 188, 3, 14, 440732) In South Africa, I got my clerical staff to do most of the Congress work.
('40', 188, 3, 15, 440806) And that not because I was a freak.
('40', 188, 3, 16, 440842) Every lawyer if he interests himself in public work has to give his proper share to it.
('40', 188, 3, 17, 440930) During the war there, for instance, every important lawyer had left his profession to go to the front, and I could almost read the magistrate’s anger in his eyes as he saw me still linger on.
('40', 188, 3, 18, 441122) And I tell you, I found it impossible to continue my practice for sheer shame.
('40', 188, 3, 19, 441201) I felt that I must also go if I wanted to maintain my status as a lawyer.
('40', 188, 3, 20, 441275) Young India, 13 10 1927
