('40', 190, 1, 2, 442729) 116. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS ON TOUR, MADURA, October 1, 1927
('40', 190, 2, 3, 442791) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have received your letter.
('40', 190, 2, 4, 442837) This little injury of yours has given me a new meaning of, “Do unto others as you would that they should do unto you.” I did unto you about your injury as I would have wished you to do unto me.
('40', 190, 2, 5, 443031) But I see that I was hopelessly wrong in applying the principle to you.
('40', 190, 2, 6, 443103) I should have done unto you, not only what I would have wished you to do unto me but I should have done unto you what was needed for you.
('40', 190, 2, 7, 443241) Your need and not your wish should have been the determining factor.
('40', 190, 2, 8, 443310) And if I had remembered as I should have done that yours was a very sensitive skin, easily liable to infection and difficult to heal after an injury I would have thoroughly scraped the wound, drawn fresh blood and then dressed it.
('40', 190, 2, 9, 443541) As it was, I went by my own experience and that of others who had an equally responsive skin, and in doing so committed a great blunder.
('40', 190, 2, 10, 443678) Thank God that you will come out with only some considerable inconve nience.
('40', 190, 2, 11, 443755) But I do not know what I would have done with myself if there had been serious blood poisoning, as there might have been.
('40', 190, 2, 12, 443877) Your reply to my telegram sent today, I hope, will relieve me from all anxiety.
('40', 190, 2, 13, 443957) That telegram also gives you my opinion about the spinning essay.
('40', 190, 2, 14, 444023) I know nothing better available but I do not consider it to be by any means the best that could have been produced.
('40', 190, 2, 15, 444139) The writers are capable fellows but their sadhana 1 of the question is not, so far as I judge, of the highest.
('40', 190, 2, 16, 444250) They have done what they considered was their best.
('40', 190, 2, 17, 444302) But in the debilitating unoriginal atmosphere that reigns supreme in the country just now, no one has the capacity for hard thinking.
('40', 190, 2, 18, 444436) Slugishness comes over us after a little effort and then the work becomes shoddy.
('40', 190, 2, 19, 444518) I have therefore my doubts about the essay giving satisfaction to the Viceroy.
('40', 190, 2, 20, 444597) And then, it is really written for the Indian reader, and not for an exacting reader like the Viceroy, who has an overburdening load of inherited and acquired pre conceived notions and prejudices.
('40', 190, 2, 21, 444794) I have, therefore, suggested to you that you should first of all patiently read it, not as a self naturalized Indian but as an unsympathetic English critic, taking nothing for granted, wanting proof for everything.
('40', 190, 2, 22, 445009) And if it gives you no satisfaction you should not send the essay to him at all.
('40', 190, 2, 23, 445090) I had something prepared for Sir Henry Lawrence too.
('40', 190, 2, 24, 445143) It has Pyarelal’s and Mahadev’s brains in it.
('40', 190, 3, 25, 445189) 1 Study and practice
('40', 191, 0, 1, 445210) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 191, 1, 2, 445252) But even that is not what I should want if I was an unsympathetic critic.
('40', 191, 1, 3, 445326) But I had to be satisfied with what I could get.
('40', 191, 1, 4, 445375) I am quite aware that this subject requires ceaseless industry of a patient seeker.
('40', 191, 1, 5, 445459) But, unfortunately, I have no one whom I can set to that work, and so it languishes.
('40', 191, 1, 6, 445544) I cannot tell you how this want of solid research taxes me.
('40', 191, 1, 7, 445604) I do not half disclose my agony but I have unburdened myself to you somewhat as you have obliged me to confess my shame.
('40', 191, 1, 8, 445725) I know that I ought to have been able to give you satisfaction and straightway send you a first class unchallengeable and readable essay.
('40', 191, 1, 9, 445863) Now I have sufficiently prejudiced you against the essay of which I was one of the judges.
('40', 191, 1, 10, 445954) Read it with this prejudice and tell me what conclusion you have arrived at.
('40', 191, 1, 11, 446031) Up to now there is nothing wrong with me.
('40', 191, 1, 12, 446073) What you read in the newspapers was all false.
('40', 191, 1, 13, 446120) Every one of these news agencies deserves to be suppressed.
('40', 191, 1, 14, 446180) Of course, the light that you saw in Simla was correct.

('40', 191, 1, 17, 446299) If you are tak ing part in the relief operations you must see whether the accounts are accurately kept.
('40', 191, 1, 18, 446403) I have seen nothing yet published.

('40', 191, 1, 20, 446563) But what I would like you to do there is not so much immediate relief work but to find a way out of the annual calamity.
('40', 191, 1, 21, 446684) You are somewhat hard upon the Congress politics.
('40', 191, 1, 22, 446734) Surely they have also a place in national evolution.
('40', 191, 1, 23, 446787) If the Assembly and the Councils have a place, much more has the Congress.
('40', 191, 1, 24, 446862) And this I am able to say although I have not the slightest sympathy with its present programme or present mode of working that programme.
('40', 191, 1, 25, 447001) Neverthe less it is a mighty institution—the only all India institution with an unbroken record of forty years.
('40', 191, 1, 26, 447113) I shall take little part in its deliberations but I must be present so long as I do not consider it to be an evil in the totality of its activities.

('40', 191, 2, 29, 447333) 117. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA October 1, 1927
('40', 191, 3, 30, 447376) BHAI GHANSHYAMDASJI, Your letter.
('40', 191, 3, 31, 447410) I learn from Jamnalalji’s letter that you have returned from Europe with your health impaired.
('40', 191, 3, 32, 447505) I think it is imperative that you
('40', 192, 0, 1, 447539) VOL. 40: 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 193
('40', 192, 1, 2, 447587) take rest somewhere and recoup it.
('40', 192, 1, 3, 447622) I can certainly assist you in selecting a diet but for that you must stay with me for some time.
('40', 192, 1, 4, 447719) You did well in sending me your views on various matters.
('40', 192, 1, 5, 447777) It is not due to non co operation that two factions have come into being.
('40', 192, 1, 6, 447851) The two camps were already there.
('40', 192, 1, 7, 447885) What has arisen is only a change in form.
('40', 192, 1, 8, 447927) My faith is firm that we cannot gain any strength except through non co operation.
('40', 192, 1, 9, 448010) The public has been impressed by its miraculous power but has not enough strength yet to practise it.
('40', 192, 1, 10, 448112) Hindu Muslim differences are proving another obstruction in its way.
('40', 192, 1, 11, 448181) I cannot seek any help from the Councils.
('40', 192, 1, 12, 448223) The members, if so inclined, can help khadi and prohibition.
('40', 192, 1, 13, 448284) But members can do nothing to remove selfishness, ignorance and indolence.
('40', 192, 1, 14, 448359) The khadi and allied work is progressing slowly as well as rapidly.
('40', 192, 1, 15, 448427) It is slow in the sense that we cannot show [quick] results and it is rapid because all that is done is pure and for that reason bound to produce good results.
('40', 192, 1, 16, 448587) My thirst for money is unquenchable.
('40', 192, 1, 17, 448624) For khadi, untouchability and education work I required the minimum sum of Rs. 200,000. The experiment being conducted in dairying demands Rs. 50,000 at present.

('40', 194, 1, 8, 452170) You tell me that yours is a recently constituted municipality.
('40', 194, 1, 9, 452233) I do not know that it is necessarily a disadvantage, for being a new municipality you have no heritage of sluggishness or indifference.
('40', 194, 1, 10, 452369) You can cut out for yourselves a new and original path and if you desire it, you can lead in the matter of sanitation.
('40', 194, 1, 11, 452488) We have on the Bombay side a very expressive equivalent for municipality in the Gujarati language.
('40', 194, 1, 12, 452587) And that was a name when it was originally given to ridicule municipal service.
('40', 194, 1, 13, 452667) It is really a name which exactly fits municipal servants.
('40', 194, 1, 14, 452726) The literal translation of the word by which we know municipalities in Gujarati is “custodians of conservancy”.
('40', 194, 1, 15, 452838) In my opinion the beginning, the centre and the end of all municipal service consists in conserving the sanitation of the people entrusted to the charge of the municipality.
('40', 194, 1, 16, 453012) And if I had the powers of an autocrat and was minded to utilize those powers I would immediately disband that municipality which did not receive cent per cent marks in an examination in connection with its conservancy work.
('40', 194, 1, 17, 453237) If you can but keep your closets absolutely clean, if you can ensure a healthy and pure supply of water and the purest and precious free air and a supply of pure milk for your babies, you are in a position to conserve the health of those who are committed to your care.
('40', 194, 1, 18, 453507) I know that the fashion is nowadays to give primary education the first place in the work of a municipality.
('40', 194, 1, 19, 453616) In my opinion it is putting the cart before the horse.
('40', 194, 1, 20, 453671) Primary education of its children must be undoubtedly an important item in the work of a municipality.
('40', 194, 1, 21, 453774) But I have not a shadow of doubt that sanitation occupies the foremost place in its programme.
('40', 194, 1, 22, 453869) There is a very fine Latin proverb which says that healthy mind is possible only in a healthy body.
('40', 194, 1, 23, 453969) And I hold it to be impossible to give a healthy education to unhealthy children.
('40', 194, 1, 24, 454051) In fact, sanitation is itself a first class primary education for men, women and children.

('40', 195, 1, 2, 454344) able to do your work in a satisfactory manner in this direction.
('40', 195, 1, 3, 454409) And let me give you my assurance based upon personal experience that all these sanitary matters do not require so much money as care, diligence and knowledge.
('40', 195, 1, 4, 454568) Closely allied with the matter of sanitation is the question of grievances of railway passengers.
('40', 195, 1, 5, 454666) There was a time when I had almost qualified myself as an expert in the matter of expressing the grievances of railway passengers and enforcing redress.
('40', 195, 1, 6, 454819) And having travelled in many parts of the world and understood all that third class travelling was and having been a regular third class passenger on almost all railways, I had exceptional opportunity of studying the condition of railway passengers.
('40', 195, 1, 7, 455069) And whilst I believed then, as I believe even now, that for many things the railway management is criminally guilty in connection with the comfort of third class passengers, I also came to the conclusion which I retain even now that for equally important matters railway passengers were themselves liable.
('40', 195, 1, 8, 455375) I am fully aware of the fact that third class passengers are the most paying customers of the railway and that the first class passengers are practically a loss to the railways.
('40', 195, 1, 9, 455553) I know that the Railway Board does not provide enough accommodation for third class passengers; nor does it ensure primary sanitation on railway stations or in railway carriages for third class passengers.
('40', 195, 1, 10, 455759) All these things and many more I could mention if I had the time.
('40', 195, 1, 11, 455825) They undoubtedly demand attention on the part of a reformer in connection with this matter.
('40', 195, 1, 12, 455917) But let us turn the searchlight towards ourselves for a few moments.
('40', 195, 1, 13, 455986) Our own neglect of sanitation in the railway carriages as also on the stations is no less than the negligence of the Railway Board.
('40', 195, 1, 14, 456118) And I know that when I was organizing relief parties in connection with third class railway passengers how difficult it was for me to enlist volunteers for doing the special work of carrying on education amongst the third class railway passengers about the primary needs of sanitation.
('40', 195, 1, 15, 456404) Every railway passenger traffic reformer has therefore to extend the activities of municipal boards.
('40', 195, 1, 16, 456505) On this analogy that charity begins at home, the reformer must first commence with the passengers themselves and patiently and gently inculcate in them habits of personal sanitation and habits of consideration for their fellow passengers.
('40', 195, 1, 17, 456744) I suggest to this useful Association that this is a privileged work of which every reformer may be proud.

('40', 200, 4, 5, 463825) 127. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, RAJAPALAYAM October 4, 1927
('40', 200, 5, 6, 463885) Mahatmaji addressed the gathering in Hindi which was translated into Telugu.
('40', 200, 5, 7, 463962) After thanking them for the address and the purses he said they had given the money for Daridranarayana.
('40', 200, 5, 8, 464067) But while receiving the money he had mingled feelings of joy and sorrow—joy that they had given money for the Khadi Fund and sorrow in seeing that in spite of strenuous work for the last six or seven years for the spread of khadi among them so few of them wore khadi.
('40', 200, 5, 9, 464335) Mahatmaji could not see any reason why they, Andhra Kshatriya ladies, should adopt purdah.
('40', 200, 5, 10, 464426) If they remained at home, never came out into the public, they would not be able to know what was going on in the world.
('40', 200, 5, 11, 464547) He wanted them to throw off foreign cloth and wear only khadi.
('40', 200, 5, 12, 464610) He saw that they were rich people but he would tell them that there were thousands of poor sisters who were suffering from want of even one meal per day.
('40', 200, 5, 13, 464764) To them the charkha could give a livelihood.
('40', 200, 5, 14, 464809) But then if they, the rich people, did not wear khadi, their poor sisters could not earn anything.
('40', 200, 5, 15, 464908) He asked them to remember that every man, woman and child of this land had a dharma to fulfil, and that was to wear khadi.
('40', 200, 5, 16, 465031) They should do their dharma even as Sita Devi did and if all of them tried to act like Sita, he would tell them Ramarajya would come into existence.
('40', 200, 5, 17, 465180) If they could not entertain feelings of sympathy and love for their poor brothers and sisters, of what use was their life to them?
('40', 200, 5, 18, 465311) Rajapalayam khadi was very fine and an effort was being made to spread khadi work by giving away a hundred charkhas free of cost.
('40', 200, 5, 19, 465441) He would therefore ask them to wear cloth spun and woven by them.
('40', 200, 5, 20, 465507) The money they had given would be spent for the production of khadi and also in supplying charkhas to those who wanted them.
('40', 200, 5, 21, 465632) In conclusion Mahatmaji asked them to give money and jewels for the Khadi Fund, and in doing so he told them it was not ornaments but a pure heart which lent beauty to a woman.
('40', 200, 5, 22, 465809) He advised them not to load their children with jewels but give them good education and training.
('40', 200, 5, 23, 465907) He also asked them not to marry their girls before 16 or 17 years of age.
('40', 200, 5, 24, 465981) The Hindu, 6 10 1927

('40', 201, 1, 2, 466044) 128. SPEECH AT KHADI VASTRALAYA, RAJAPALAYAM October 4, 1927
('40', 201, 2, 3, 466105) There would be no difficulty in getting the money for this good work.
('40', 201, 2, 4, 466175) 1 But you should not always be intent on profits.
('40', 201, 2, 5, 466225) Even when a man invests capital as in a mill for making his own profits and giving huge dividends, some of you perhaps know that for some years he gets no return whatsoever.
('40', 201, 2, 6, 466399) But I want you to have a higher objective in view than the mill owners.
('40', 201, 2, 7, 466471) That is to say, whilst you make it a point not to lose profits on capital you should never wish to make huge profits out of it.
('40', 201, 2, 8, 466599) 2 Remember, the greatest business concerns in the world do not depend for profit on high rates but extensive business.
('40', 201, 2, 9, 466718) The Bank of England is the largest financial corporation in the world and the most influential.
('40', 201, 2, 10, 466814) It has a credit which perhaps no other such corpo ration possesses and really the history of that corporation reads like a fairy tale.
('40', 201, 2, 11, 466949) Some of the finest Englishmen have poured their life blood in order to make that corporation what it is today.
('40', 201, 2, 12, 467060) And it has acquired amazing confidence, because it has made it a point not to make huge profits on small outlays.
('40', 201, 2, 13, 467174) Profits it does make, but that is because of its phenomenal outlay.
('40', 201, 2, 14, 467242) You will therefore, I hope, not make big profits your objective, but have primarily the interests of spinners at heart.
('40', 201, 2, 15, 467362) You will not quarrel among yourselves and if you develop real union and limit your personal ambition, there is no reason why you should not aspire after a credit even larger than that of the Bank of England.
('40', 201, 2, 16, 467570) After all the clients of the Bank of England are rich men and big men and their names and accounts can be kept in a fairly large ledger, but there is no ledger big enough to contain the names of your clients.
('40', 201, 2, 17, 467779) What I have said requires a longer sight, and it may appear to you that I am talking like a visionary.
('40', 201, 2, 18, 467882) But I tell you I am not.
('40', 201, 2, 19, 467907) If I can gain the confidence of the people of India I hope to make the A.I.S.A. the largest co operative society in the world.
('40', 201, 2, 20, 468034) That time may be far off but I am not going to lose hope.

('40', 202, 3, 6, 468895) It has given me great pleasure to be able to come to this very important khadi centre.
('40', 202, 3, 7, 468982) I had the honour and the pleasure of meeting many spinners at work.

('40', 202, 3, 9, 469084) Some of them are even seventy years old.

('40', 202, 3, 11, 469273) I enquired of them all what their earnings were per month and I was agreeably surprised to find some of them earned over Rs. 4 per month.
('40', 202, 3, 12, 469411) That is much more than spinners earn in other parts of India.
('40', 202, 3, 13, 469473) You will not therefore come to the conclusion that here you are paying higher wages to them than elsewhere.
('40', 202, 3, 14, 469581) The reason is that they are more industrious, more skilful and are able to give more time to spin ning.
('40', 202, 3, 15, 469685) Unlike other spinners in other parts of India these ladies do their own carding or have their carding done by their relatives.
('40', 202, 3, 16, 469812) It thus shows you the possibilities there are in the spinning wheel.

('40', 210, 2, 6, 488315) 135. NOTES
('40', 210, 3, 7, 488326) A KHADI LOVER Dr. Kailas Nath Katju 1, a distinguished advocate of Allahabad, sent me a letter some time ago referring to several matters, and in that letter avowed his love of khadi and enclosed the first instalment of his contribution to the A.I.S.A. I felt that the part of the letter that concerned khadi should be published by way of encouragement to other moneyed men, especially lawyers.
('40', 210, 3, 8, 488721) I therefore wrote asking for his permission to publish his letter and incidentally expostulated with him about the foreign black alpaca and endeavoured to explain the value of sacrificial spinning.
('40', 210, 3, 9, 488919) I am now able to publish below his two letters so far as they relate to khadi : 2
('40', 210, 4, 10, 489001) The lawyers and other professional men may not be able to do much in other respects, but they can all follow Dr. Katju’s worthy example by adopting khadi and contributing to the All India Spinners’ Association, which is always in want because of the growing demand for organizing more villages than the Association has on hand.
('40', 210, 4, 11, 489329) It is not possible to produce an increasing amount of khadi without increasing the capital, and till khadi has become universal in India expenses of the organization must remain a recurring item.
('40', 210, 5, 12, 489525) A DOUBLE SIN

('40', 210, 7, 14, 489731) 1 1887 1968; prominent Congress leader; sometime Home Minister, Gover nment of India 2 Not reproduced here; Katju had promised to send a monthly contribution to the Khadi Fund, spin regularly and use fine black khadi in place of foreign alpaca.

('40', 211, 0, 1, 489993) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 211, 1, 2, 490035) which I abridge as follows :
('40', 211, 2, 3, 490064) I have read with interest the article in your paper of the 1st instant under the heading “Is It a Marriage?”?
('40', 211, 2, 4, 490174) Though the names of the parties are omitted it is an open secret to the Gaud Sarasvat Brahmins from Karwar.
('40', 211, 2, 5, 490282) As a member of the community in which the marriage in question took place I wish to place before the public and the Gaud Sarasvat Brahmins throughout India in particular the following few lines for their careful consideration :
('40', 211, 3, 6, 490510) Is is no doubt a disgrace for a man to buy a girl.
('40', 211, 3, 7, 490561) But there is another custom among us which is equally bad, for a father among us is obliged to buy a husband for his daughter and the amount received by the husband is called dowry.
('40', 211, 3, 8, 490743) It is not settled to suit the purse of the parents of girls but it would be according to the hereditary income of the would be husband or it sometimes depends upon the education he has received.
('40', 211, 3, 9, 490938) The more a man is educated, the higher the degrees he has received, the more is he worth in the matrimonial market.
('40', 211, 4, 10, 491054) A few months back the marriage took place in Bombay of a well educated gentleman who is a high government official and it is said that a dowry of nearly Rs. 20,000 was presented to him.
('40', 211, 4, 11, 491240) It is really a pity that the people who receive higher education are going lower and lower by resorting to the very practices they are expected to put down.
('40', 211, 4, 12, 491397) I have before me another letter on the subject from a member of the same community.
('40', 211, 4, 13, 491481) It appears that those who wish to buy wives go to Goa in search, for it is there that poor Sarasvat Brahmins are to be found who are not ashamed to enrich themselves by selling their daughters to persons old enough to be their fathers or grandfathers.
('40', 211, 4, 14, 491733) Thus the community commits a double sin.
('40', 211, 4, 15, 491774) An educated young man is open to the highest bidder for is hand,and needy parents are open to negotiate the sale of their daughters, hardly out of their teens, to the oldest men (sometimes educated) who are prepared to pay the highest price.
('40', 211, 4, 16, 492016) The only consolation that the Sarasvat community may derive, if it wishes to, and if it would postpone a dealing with the reform under some excuse or other, is that there are other ‘castes’ too that are not free from the same evil.
('40', 211, 4, 17, 492248) The difference, if any, would be that of degree.
('40', 211, 4, 18, 492297) But if the Sarasvat community would lead the reform, it will disdain to seek the doubtful refuge of the tu quoque and will, now that the evil has been exposed, set about ridding itself of the double sin.
('40', 211, 5, 19, 492501) Young India, 6 10 1927
('40', 212, 0, 1, 492524) VOL. 40: 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 213

('40', 212, 7, 17, 493568) I have a right to welcome such gifts.
('40', 212, 7, 18, 493606) I congratulate you on having a Hindi teacher in your midst and I have learnt with pleasure that not only boys and girls but also grown up men and women are learning Hindi.
('40', 212, 7, 19, 493778) But I understand that the expenses of Hindi tuition are not borne by you in their entirety.
('40', 212, 7, 20, 493870) I think that, if it is so, it is a serious reflection upon your patrotism.
('40', 212, 7, 21, 493945) As you know, for several years past the people in the north have been financing this Hindi Propaganda.
('40', 212, 7, 22, 494048) But it is high time now that it became self supporting.
('40', 212, 7, 23, 494104) Surely it cannot cost you much money in order to support one Hindi teacher or two teachers among your midst.
('40', 212, 7, 24, 494213) I may think therefore that you will take all pains to see that you pay

('40', 213, 1, 2, 494326) for all the tuition he gives.
('40', 213, 1, 3, 494356) I congratulate you also on your having a national school in your town and on having named it after Lokamanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak.
('40', 213, 1, 4, 494486) It grieves me to hear from your address that you are unable to pay for the expenses of this school.

('40', 213, 1, 6, 494703) I do hope that patriotic citizens will look into the affairs of this institution and make it self supporting.
('40', 213, 1, 7, 494813) In your address you ask me to set apart a certain portion of the amount of collections here in this town to your school.
('40', 213, 1, 8, 494934) I am sorry to have to inform you that it will not be possible for me to do so.
('40', 213, 1, 9, 495013) However willing I may feel it will not be just and honest on my part to deflect even a moiety of the sum earmarked for a definite purpose.
('40', 213, 1, 10, 495152) I may gladly, however, part with some sum of the collections if some citizens had given me the purse with a distinct request that a certain fraction of it might be given to your school.
('40', 213, 1, 11, 495338) Even now if there is any citizen so minded to give any sum in that manner, I shall only be too glad to do so.
('40', 213, 1, 12, 495448) That, however, is not the method by which you can support the institution though it would be something, but it behoves the citizens of Tuticorin to look into the existing state of affairs of this institution and make it absolutely an independent one.
('40', 213, 1, 13, 495699) I know from personal experience of several national schools how these institutions are conducted and how beautifully they are serving the national purpose.
('40', 213, 1, 14, 495855) If you have taken any interest in the distress that has overtaken our countrymen in the north, you will find that the pupils of national institutions in these villages have been rendering great help in reclaiming the area and in relieving their distress to the extent and with the resources that lay in their power.
('40', 213, 1, 15, 496171) But for the spontaneous and substantial voluntary service done by the pupils of the national schools in Gujarat, Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel would not have been able to do what he had done towards the relief of the flood stricken people.
('40', 213, 1, 16, 496403) I, therefore, ask the citizens of Tuticorin to keep the institution going.

('40', 213, 1, 18, 496549) You know that there is the All India Spinners’ Association.
('40', 213, 1, 19, 496609) If you will induce your pupils to take up hand spinning and produce yarn you can send the same to the Association which will pay you a decent price and also try to help you in a way.

('40', 214, 1, 2, 496841) I have heard people saying that I have made no reference to the Tamil language during my tour in this Province, and to the necessity of learning it.

('40', 214, 1, 7, 497343) Before the year 1917 throughout India ten years ago I carried on a ceaseless agitation for the imparting of instruction to pupils in schools through the medium of the vernacular of the province and asking people to cultivate their vernaculars by speaking in their vernaculars and studying literatures in their respective vernaculars.

('40', 215, 3, 4, 499108) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I thank you for the numerous addresses of welcome and your purses and gifts.
('40', 215, 3, 5, 499211) I thank you still more for refraining from reading all your addresses.
('40', 215, 3, 6, 499282) I have had a somewhat taxing day and a still more taxing drive in the midst of terrific din and noise in Tinnevelly and it is late for me also.
('40', 215, 3, 7, 499426) You can, therefore, now perhaps understand how I value your having waived your right of reading the addresses.
('40', 215, 3, 8, 499537) You have given me so many gifts, large and small, that it will take some time before I dispose of them all in auction as I usually do at the end of the meeting.
('40', 215, 3, 9, 499698) I need hardly tell you that I have read all your addresses, the translations of which were furnished to me.
('40', 215, 3, 10, 499806) I value the assurance given in the address of the Indian Christian Association on behalf of their community that while formerly they might not have identified themselves with national movements, now they are identifying themselves more with these movements.
('40', 215, 3, 11, 500064) Indeed, I have been watching with very great interest and pleasure this manifestation from Christian friends throughout the south.
('40', 215, 3, 12, 500195) There is no doubt in my mind that it is as it should be.
('40', 215, 3, 13, 500252) Acceptance of Christianity or any other faith should never mean denationalization.
('40', 215, 3, 14, 500335) Nationalism need never be narrow or inconsistent with internationalism.
('40', 215, 3, 15, 500407) That nationalism, which is based upon pure selfishness and the exploitation of other nations, is indeed an evil.
('40', 215, 3, 16, 500520) But I cannot conceive of internationalism without a healthy and desirable national spirit.
('40', 215, 3, 17, 500611) I was glad to note in that address complete sympathy with the khadi movement.
('40', 215, 3, 18, 500689) To me, it appears to be monstrous to see the slightest opposition to such an incredibly simple thing as khadi.
('40', 215, 3, 19, 500800) For, after all, khadi is nothing but a desire to identify oneself with the starving millions of India.
('40', 215, 3, 20, 500903) He or she, who has the slightest feeling or desire to serve these toiling millions, cannot help beginning with khadi.
('40', 215, 3, 21, 501021) Only recently did Sir M. Visvesvarayya deplore the fact that millions of people in the villages who have so much time and leisure were sending their raw produce outside India and depriving themselves of the opportu nities to help themselves with their own efforts.
('40', 215, 3, 22, 501286) Indeed, in this part of the country you have an unrivalled opportunity to turn the cotton you produce to good account.
('40', 215, 3, 23, 501405) You see
('40', 216, 0, 1, 501413) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 217
('40', 216, 1, 2, 501462) here on the table these pieces of khadi whose history I will give you.
('40', 216, 1, 3, 501533) There is in your midst a gentleman whose name is Mr. Aramvalarth anatham Pillai.
('40', 216, 1, 4, 501614) He and my kind host, Mr. Vishwanatha Pillai, have conspired to teach boys and girls in two schools simple spinning.
('40', 216, 1, 5, 501730) And the labours of these boys and girls who are spinning on the takli are enough to produce seventeen yards in one month.
('40', 216, 1, 6, 501852) And I hope that no one in this meeting despises this little production on the part of these boys and girls who have not known till now what it is to produce one yard.
('40', 216, 1, 7, 502019) This is one of the countries possessing the largest manpower on the face of the earth.
('40', 216, 1, 8, 502106) This manpower, according to the same high authority I quoted just now, remains unutilized.
('40', 216, 1, 9, 502197) If all the schools throughout India were engaged only for a short time every day you can imagine the enormous increase in the productive capacity of the country, without any capital or any special skill in technical activity.
('40', 216, 1, 10, 502423) I have got here nearly 85 yards of khadi all spun and woven here out of your own cotton by your own boys and girls.

('40', 216, 1, 15, 502910) It gives me a great joy to be able to know who was the sister or daughter who spun the yarn or whose was the hand that wove the clothes I wear.
('40', 216, 1, 16, 503054) This is one very vast universal industry in India which not only takes its sweep over millions of our starving countrymen, but is one on which you can build great national activity and unite all the castes and communities of this country.
('40', 216, 1, 17, 503293) But these friends, while they have great faith in the future of khadi and its ability to solve to a great extent the deep and distressful poverty of the masses, have little faith now in the solution of the Brahmin non Brahmin question in this country.

('40', 217, 1, 2, 504207) give you my assurance as President and head of the All India Spinners’ Association that if I can get as many skilled workers on my terms from the non Brahmins I will today dismiss all the Brahmin workers from the A.I.S.A. ('40', 217, 1, 21, 506700) If I may put it in a nutshell, after all the Brahmin non Brah min question also resolves itself into one of untouchability.
('40', 217, 1, 22, 506824) And he who will successfully kill this cobra of untouchability will have laid the axe

('40', 218, 1, 2, 506959) at the root of the Brahmin non Brahmin question.
('40', 218, 1, 3, 507008) For it is my clear conviction that it is this curse of untouchability which has crept into Hinduism and has poisoned Hinduism itself.
('40', 218, 1, 4, 507142) After all, that untouchability which, in its most excessive and excruciating form, has given us the untouchables and unseeables, has been running through the core of Hinduism.
('40', 218, 1, 5, 507318) The basis of untouchability is an arrogant assumption of superiority of one class over another; and once we have successfully dealt with the hydra headed monster of superiority, I think, we have very little to fight about.
('40', 218, 1, 6, 507541) I therefore invite you all to join me in this crusade against untouchability in every form.
('40', 218, 1, 7, 507633) Whilst I am glad to find from your addresses and the talk I had this afternoon that your municipal schools are open to untouchables, I ask you not to be satisfied with that alone.
('40', 218, 1, 8, 507813) When untouchability is really removed from our midst you will not find any untouchable quarter.
('40', 218, 1, 9, 507909) The untouchables will have the same rights as the tallest Brahmin to enter the inmost sanctuary of any temple to which any Brahmin can go.
('40', 218, 1, 10, 508048) They will have the same access that anybody else may have to public wells and public places.
('40', 218, 1, 11, 508141) We shall then have no Brahmin tanks, non Brahmin tanks and untouchable tanks.

('40', 220, 9, 21, 513010) October 8, 1927 Whilst it gives me great pleasure to pay a second visit to this most beautiful part of India, I cannot conceal from you the deep grief I feel for the fact that in this fair land untouchability has a sway which it does not exercise in any other part of India.
('40', 220, 9, 22, 513285) I feel deeply humiliated as a Hindu to find that it is in this enlightened Hindu State that untouchability appears in its most hideous form of unseeability and unapproachability.
('40', 220, 9, 23, 513464) I speak with a due sense of my responsibility that

('40', 221, 1, 3, 513881) That in this age of reason, in this age of wide travel, in this age of a comparative study of religions, there should be found people, some of whom are educated, to uphold the hideous doctrine of treating a single human being as an untouchable, or unapproachable, or unseeable because of his birth, passes my comprehension.
('40', 221, 1, 4, 514205) As a lay, humble student of Hinduism and claiming to be one desirous of practising Hinduism in the spirit and to the letter let me tell you that I have found no warrant or support for this terrible doctrine.
('40', 221, 1, 5, 514413) Let us not deceive ourselves into the belief that everything that is written in Sanskrit and printed is Shastra and has a binding effect upon us.
('40', 221, 1, 6, 514559) That which is opposed to the fundamental maxims of morality, that which is opposed to trained reason, cannot be claimed as Shastra no matter how ancient it may be.

('40', 229, 1, 9, 534673) Christian Europe is not at all Christian, but is groping, and so in my opinion is Islam still groping for its great secret, and there is today a competition, healthy as also extremely unhealthy and ugly, between these three great religions.
('40', 229, 1, 10, 534914) As years go by, the conviction is daily growing upon me that varna is the law of man’s being and therefore as necessary for Christianity and Islam as it has been necessary for Hinduism and has been its saving.
('40', 229, 1, 11, 535124) I refuse, therefore, to believe that varnash rama has been the curse of Hinduism, as it is the fashion nowaday in the South on the part of some Hindus to say.
('40', 229, 1, 12, 535283) But that does not mean that you and I may tolerate for one moment or be gentle towards the hideous travesty of varnashrama that we see about us today.
('40', 229, 1, 13, 535434) There is nothing in common between varnashrama and caste.
('40', 229, 1, 14, 535492) Caste, if you will, is undoubtedly a drag upon Hindu progress, and untouchability is, as I have already called it or described it, an excrescence upon varnashrama.
('40', 229, 1, 15, 535656) It is a weedy growth fit only to be weeded out, as we weed out the weeds that we see growing in wheat fields or rice fields.
('40', 229, 1, 16, 535781) In this conception of varna, there is absolutely no idea of superiority and inferiority.
('40', 229, 1, 17, 535870) If I again interpret the Hindu spirit rightly, all life is absolutely equal and one.
('40', 229, 1, 18, 535955) It is therefore an arrogant assumption on the part of the Brahmin when he says : “I am superior to the other three varnas.” That is not what the Brahmins of old said.
('40', 229, 1, 19, 536122) They commanded homage not because they claimed superiority, but because they claimed the right of service through and through without the slightest expectation of a reward.
('40', 229, 1, 20, 536295) The priests, who today arrogate to themselves the function of the Brahmin and distort religion, are no custodians of Hinduism or Brahminism.
('40', 229, 1, 21, 536436) Consciously or unconsci ously they are laying the axe at the root of the very tree on which they are sitting, and when they tell you that Shastras enjoin untouchability and when they talk of pollution distance, I have no hesitation in saying that they are belying their creed and that they are misinterpreting the spirit of Hinduism.
('40', 229, 1, 22, 536770) You will now perhaps understand why it is absolutely necessary for you Hindus who are
('40', 230, 0, 1, 536856) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 231
('40', 230, 1, 2, 536905) here and listening to me to energize yourselves and rid yourselves of this curse.
('40', 230, 1, 3, 536987) You should take pride in leading the way of reform, belonging as you do to an ancient Hindu State.
('40', 230, 1, 4, 537086) So far as I can read the atmosphere around you here, the moment is certainly propitious for you if you will sincerely and energetically undertake this reform.

('40', 236, 4, 18, 548966) 151. SPEECH AT QUILON 2
('40', 236, 5, 19, 548990) October 11, 1927 Untouchability poisons Hinduism as a drop of arsenic poisons milk.
('40', 236, 5, 20, 549074) Knowing the quality of milk, and the use of milk and knowing the quality of arsenic, we should be impatient with the man sitting near a pitcher of milk and trying to remove arsenic grain by grain, and we should throw the whole pitcher overboard.
('40', 236, 5, 21, 549320) Even so do I as a Hindu feel that the curse of untouchability is rendering the milk of Hinduism altogether poisoned and impure.
('40', 236, 5, 22, 549448) I feel therefore that patience in a matter of this character is not a virtue.
('40', 236, 5, 23, 549526) It is impossible to restrain ourselves.
('40', 236, 5, 24, 549566) Patience with evil is really trifling with evil and with ourselves.
('40', 236, 5, 25, 549634) I have therefore not hesitated to say that the State of Travancore should lead in the matter of the reform and blot out the evil at a single stroke.
('40', 236, 5, 26, 549783) But I know also that it was not possible even for a Hindu State to do away with this evil, unless it was backed and actively backed by its Hindu population.
('40', 236, 5, 27, 549940) And so my appeal must be mostly to you rather than to the head of the State; and to every Hindu in this meeting I wish to make a definite personal appeal.
('40', 236, 5, 28, 550095) You and I
('40', 236, 6, 29, 550105) 1Vide the preceding item.
('40', 236, 6, 30, 550131) 2 Published under the title “Message to Travancore”
('40', 237, 0, 1, 550183) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 237, 1, 2, 550225) have long neglected our duty to the so called untouchables and un approachables, and to this extent you and I have been false representatives of Hinduism.
('40', 237, 1, 3, 550380) I ask you without the slightest hesitation summarily to reject the advance of every person who comes to you in defence of untouchability.
('40', 237, 1, 4, 550518) Remember that in this age whatever one man or group of men and women do does not remain secret for any length of time, and we are daily being weighed and found wanting so long as we nurse untouchability in our bosom.
('40', 237, 1, 5, 550735) You must remember that all the great religions of the world are at the present time in the melting pot.
('40', 237, 1, 6, 550839) Let us not ostrich like hide our faces and ignore the danger that lies at the back of us.
('40', 237, 1, 7, 550929) I have not a shadow of doubt that in the great turmoil now taking place either untouchability has to die or Hinduism has to disappear.

('40', 238, 1, 2, 552047) 153. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ALLEPPEY
('40', 238, 2, 3, 552087) October 12, 1927
('40', 238, 3, 4, 552104) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I thank you for your addresses as also the several purses that have been presented to me on behalf of Daridranarayana.
('40', 238, 3, 5, 552249) As I stated at Nagercoil, immediately on my entering the Travancore border, I found myself immersed in studying and assisting at a solution of the untouchability question.
('40', 238, 3, 6, 552421) And on this the last day of my all too brief tour in Travancore for the purpose, I propose to devote the best part of my address to the same question.
('40', 238, 3, 7, 552572) I wish indeed that I had more time at my disposal so that I could have stayed here longer and studied the question still better and given what assistance I could on the spot.
('40', 238, 3, 8, 552747) Being somewhat of an expert on this question, I feel that I could, however humbly it may be, render assistance both to the State and the people in arriving at a just solution.
('40', 238, 3, 9, 552923) I am glad, as well as thankful, to be able to say that from Her Highness the Maharani Regent down to the officials of the State, they have received my remarks in the same spirit as I tendered.
('40', 238, 3, 10, 553116) I could entertain no doubt whatsoever in connection with the avarna friends.
('40', 238, 3, 11, 553193) For I regard myself as an untouchable amongst untouchables and I have not hesitated to call myself in several meetings a Nayadi.
('40', 238, 3, 12, 553322) Probably some of you even do not know what a Nayadi is.
('40', 238, 3, 13, 553378) To the eternal disgrace of the modern Hindu, Nayadi is the being who occupies the lowest state even amongst the so called untouchables.

('40', 246, 2, 10, 573055) Bhashyam Aiyengar of Bangalore writes :
('40', 246, 3, 11, 573095) The principles of Hindu Law as at present administered are antiquated and opposed to our sense of equity and justice.
('40', 246, 3, 12, 573213) I shall give a few instances 1 : The prominence I have given to the foregoing need not imply that I endorse every one of the reforms suggested by the writer.
('40', 246, 3, 13, 573371) That some of them require immediate attention I have no doubt.
('40', 246, 3, 14, 573434) Nor have I any doubt that all of them demand serious consideration from those who would rid Hindu society of its anachronisms.
('40', 246, 3, 15, 573561) In pre British days there was no such thing as rigid Hindu Law governing the lives of millions.
('40', 246, 3, 16, 573657) The body of regulations known as smritis were indicative rather than inflexible codes of conduct.
('40', 246, 3, 17, 573755) They never had the validity of law such as is known to modern lawyers.
('40', 246, 3, 18, 573826) The observance of the restraints of the smritis was enforced more by social than legal sanctions.
('40', 246, 3, 19, 573924) The smritis were, as is evident from the self contradictory verses to be found in them, continually passing, like ourselves, through evolutionary changes, and were adapted to the new
('40', 246, 4, 20, 574107) 1 The correspondent mentioned ten injunctions relating to inheritance, widow remarriage, inter caste marriage, adoption, etc., and suggested that the Mysore State should undertake the desired reforms through legislation.

('40', 247, 1, 2, 574370) discoveries that were being made in social science.
('40', 247, 1, 3, 574422) Wise kings were free to procure new inter pretations to suit new conditions.
('40', 247, 1, 4, 574499) Hindu religion or Hindu Shastras never had the changeless and unchanging character that is now being sought to be given to them.
('40', 247, 1, 5, 574628) No doubt in those days there were kings and their councillors who had the wisdom and the authority required to command the respect and allegiance of society.
('40', 247, 1, 6, 574786) But now the custom has grown up of thinking that smritis and everything that goes by the name of Shastras is absolutely unchange able.
('40', 247, 1, 7, 574921) The verses which we find to be unworkable or altogether repugnant to our moral sense, we conveniently ignore.
('40', 247, 1, 8, 575031) This very unsatisfactory state of things has to be, some day or other and somehow, changed if Hindu society is to become a progressive unit in human evolution.
('40', 247, 1, 9, 575191) The British rulers cannot make these changes because of their different religion and their different ideal.
('40', 247, 1, 10, 575299) Their ideal is to sustain their commercial supremacy and to sacrifice every other interest, moral or otherwise, for the attainment of that ideal.
('40', 247, 1, 11, 575445) Unless therefore Hindu public opinion clearly demands it, and it can be made without any injury to their ideal, no drastic change in our customs or socalled laws will be attempted or countenanced by them.

('40', 255, 3, 13, 595235) I remember my own school days when geometry was extremely unpopular amongst the boys.
('40', 255, 3, 14, 595321) The reason of its unpopularity was not in the boys but in the teacher himself.
('40', 255, 3, 15, 595400) Not having a full grasp of the subject, he rattled away for all he was worth at the propositions which he drew up on the board before the boys who never followed him.
('40', 255, 3, 16, 595567) Now, personally I consider that geometry is a most fascinating study and when I understood its fascination, I really could never appreciate objections that boys very often raised to that subject.
('40', 255, 3, 17, 595763) But you will find if you were to go deep into such things that wherever a particular subject is uninteresting or could not be popular among the boys and girls, it is not the fault of the subject or of the boys and girls, but essentially of the teachers.
('40', 255, 3, 18, 596017) But geometry which is a great science and which has thousands of votaries throughout the world is, and was in my time, in no danger of suffering harm if it happened to be handled by some idiotic teachers.
('40', 255, 3, 19, 596222) But unfotunately for the toiling millions of India, hand spinning is even now struggling for its very existence.
('40', 255, 3, 20, 596335) Many economists brought up in the European school even laugh at me when I advocate spinning as a
('40', 256, 0, 1, 596432) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 257
('40', 256, 1, 2, 596481) scientific thing and a sign of beauty and art.
('40', 256, 1, 3, 596528) And believing as they do, in the system of competition reigning supreme in this world as the final word on economics, they believes that spinning is merely a toy of mine, varily to be destroyed as soon as I retire from this world.
('40', 256, 1, 4, 596759) You will, therefore, appreciate my great anxiety for this child, struggling for its very existence and you will forgive me if I warn you against mishandling this thing for me and I say this after a careful study of the subject since 1908; spinning is not one of the many handicrafts that boys and girls may learn or our people may take to, but it is in my opinion the central fact of the life of the starving masses of India.
('40', 256, 1, 5, 597185) I have come to the conclusion that no solution of the deep and everdeepening poverty of the masses is possible without giving hand spinning a central place in any scheme.
('40', 256, 1, 6, 597356) Whilst, therefore, I tender my congratulations to the State for countenancing hand spinning in the manner I have seen and whilst I congratulate the boys and girls, whom I saw today, as well as the teachers, on their having taken up spinning, I must beseech the State authorities and the teachers and the boys and girls and all those who have the welfare of the State in their keeping to give this subject their very serious attention.
('40', 256, 1, 7, 597791) We are making an experiment in Ahmedabad on nearly 1,000 boys belonging to the so called untouchables and I can claim that we have attained a very fair measure of success.
('40', 256, 1, 8, 597963) The experiment is being tried under the personal supervision and care of Shrimati Anasuyabai, herself brought up in a millionaire family, but I told you that in order to achieve the measure of success that has been achieved in connection with that experiment, many experts have to give many a precious hour to its development and it was there that we came to the final conclusion that in the schools it would be wrong to introduce the spinning wheel, but that it would be necessary to confine hand spinning to the takli only.
('40', 256, 1, 9, 598489) I will not go through the different processes that we tried there but I will simply give you the results of that experiment.
('40', 256, 1, 10, 598614) All the boys’ taklis are carefully examined; every boy has well carded sliver.
('40', 256, 1, 11, 598693) The hands of the boys are often likely to get moist as they are handling the takli; they are instructed to see to it that their hands do not get moist.
('40', 256, 1, 12, 598845) Every boy’s yarn in carefully kept and tested for its twines and counts and strength, and we aw that in an incredibly short space of time, the results came up to 50 per cent higher.
('40', 256, 1, 13, 599027) It is also found that the average speed too increased because of this testing.
('40', 256, 1, 14, 599106) Every teacher was encouraged to learn this art by offering a small increment in his salary, if he would learn it, so that
('40', 257, 0, 1, 599228) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 257, 1, 2, 599270) now every teacher is a good carder, and a good spinner.
('40', 257, 1, 3, 599326) The testing continues up to this day.
('40', 257, 1, 4, 599364) The result is altogether encouraging during the time this experiment has been made.
('40', 257, 1, 5, 599448) And we have found also by actual experience that the quantity that we so received from those boys is four or five times greater than the quantity that we were able to get from the spinning wheels.
('40', 257, 1, 6, 599645) Not because a boy sitting at the spinning wheel would draw less than from the takli, but because a simultaneous spinning by all the boys at the spinning wheel was found to be a physical impossibility.
('40', 257, 1, 7, 599846) Spinning wheels had a knack of going out of order in the hands of these mischievous youngsters times without number, and let me give out the secret to you that we found too that the boys and girls would remain boys and girls and would be mischievous.
('40', 257, 1, 8, 600097) And there was no iron discipline in them not to do a little harmless mischief.

('40', 289, 4, 6, 676129) 176. WHY I AM A HINDU
('40', 289, 5, 7, 676151) An American friend who subscribes herself as a lifelong friend of India writes :
('40', 289, 6, 8, 676232) As Hinduism is one of the prominent religions of the East, and as you have made a study of Christianity and Hinduism, and on the basis of that study have announced that you are a Hindu, I beg leave to ask of you if you will do me the favour to give me your reasons for that choice.
('40', 289, 6, 9, 676514) Hindus and Christians alike realize that man’s chief need is to know God and to worship Him in spirit and in truth.
('40', 289, 6, 10, 676630) Believing that Christ was a revelation of God, Christians of America have sent to India thousands of their sons and daughters to tell the people of India about Christ.
('40', 289, 6, 11, 676798) Will you in return kindly give us your interpretation of Hinduism and make a comparison of Hinduism with the teachings of Christ?
('40', 289, 6, 12, 676928) I will be deeply grateful for this favour.
('40', 289, 6, 13, 676971) I have ventured at several missionary meetings to tell English and American missionaries that if they could have refrained from ‘telling’ India about Christ and had merely lived the life enjoined upon them by the Sermon on the Mount, India instead of suspecting them would have appreciated their living in the midst of her children and directly profited by their presence.
('40', 289, 6, 14, 677344) Holding this view, I can ‘tell’ American friends nothing about Hinduism by way of ‘return’.
('40', 289, 6, 15, 677436) I do not believe in people telling others of their faith, especially with a view to conversion.
('40', 289, 6, 16, 677532) Faith does not admit of telling.
('40', 289, 6, 17, 677565) It has to be lived and then it becomes self propagating.
('40', 289, 6, 18, 677622) Nor do I consider myself fit to interpret Hinduism except through my own life.
('40', 289, 6, 19, 677701) And if I may not interpret Hinduism through my written word, I may not compare it with Christianity.
('40', 289, 6, 20, 677802) The only thing it is possible for me therefore to do is to say, as briefly as I can, why I am a Hindu.
('40', 289, 6, 21, 677905) Believing as I do in the influence of heredity, being born in a Hindu family, I have remained a Hindu.
('40', 289, 6, 22, 678008) I should reject it, if I found it
('40', 289, 7, 23, 678042) 1Vide “A Good Servant Gone”, October 27, 1927.
('40', 290, 0, 1, 678089) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 291
('40', 290, 1, 2, 678138) inconsistent with my moral sense or my spiritual growth.
('40', 290, 1, 3, 678195) On examination, I have found it to be the most tolerant of all religions known to me.
('40', 290, 1, 4, 678281) Its freedom from dogma makes a forcible appeal to me inasmuch as it gives the votary the largest scope for self expression.
('40', 290, 1, 5, 678405) Not being an exclusive religion, it enables the followers of that faith not merely to respect all the other religions, but it also enables them to admire and assimilate what ever may be good in the other faiths.
('40', 290, 1, 6, 678617) Non violence is common to all religions, but it has found the highest expression and application in Hinduism.
('40', 290, 1, 7, 678727) (I do not regard Jainism or Buddhism as separate from Hinduism.) Hinduism believes in the oneness not of merely all human life but in the oneness of all that lives.
('40', 290, 1, 8, 678892) Its worship of the cow is, in my opinion, its unique contribution to the evolution of humanitarianism.
('40', 290, 1, 9, 678995) It is a practical application of the belief in the oneness and, therefore, sacredness of all life.
('40', 290, 1, 10, 679094) The great belief in transmigration is a direct consequence of that belief.
('40', 290, 1, 11, 679169) Finally the discovery of the law of varnashrama is a magnificent result of the ceaseless search for truth.
('40', 290, 1, 12, 679276) I must not burden this article with defini tions of the essentials sketched here, except to say that the present ideas of cow worship and varnashrama are a caricature of what in my opinion the originals are.
('40', 290, 1, 13, 679484) The curious may see the definitions of cow worship and varnashrama in the previous numbers of Young India.
('40', 290, 1, 14, 679591) I hope to have to say on varnashrama in the near future.
('40', 290, 1, 15, 679648) In this all too brief a sketch I have mentioned what occur to me to be the outsta nding features of Hinduism that keep me in its fold.
('40', 290, 1, 16, 679783) Young India, 20 10 1927

('40', 296, 4, 7, 689801) 186. SPEECH TO STUDENTS, TIRUPPUR October 23, 1927
('40', 296, 5, 8, 689852) In declaring the Gita class open Mahatmaji advised the students to get up at 4 o’clock in the morning and regularly read the Bhagavad Gita daily.
('40', 296, 5, 9, 689998) He was anxious that they should begin the study of the Gita in right earnest.
('40', 296, 5, 10, 690076) If they could not read Sanskrit they could go in for a Tamil translation of the Gita, but not the English one, because the English rendering could not impart the true significance of the Gita.
('40', 296, 5, 11, 690269) He said that the third chapter is an important one in the Gita.
('40', 296, 5, 12, 690333) [He continued :] 1
('40', 296, 6, 13, 690352) The Gita contains the gospel of karma or work, the gospel of bhakti or devotion and the gospel of jnana or knowledge.
('40', 296, 6, 14, 690470) Life should be a harmonious whole of these three.
('40', 296, 6, 15, 690520) But the gospel of service is the basis of all, and what can be more necessary for those who want to serve the country than that they begin with the chapter enunciating the gospel of work?
('40', 296, 6, 16, 690708) But you must approach it with the five necessary equipments, viz., ahimsa (non violence), satya (truth), brahmacharya (celibacy), aparigraha (non possession), and asteya (non stealing).
('40', 296, 6, 17, 690894) Then and then only will you be able to reach a correct interpretation of it.
('40', 296, 6, 18, 690971) And then you will read it to discover in it ahimsa and not himsa, as so many nowadays try to do.
('40', 296, 6, 19, 691068) Read it with the necessary equipment and I assure you you will have peace of which you were never aware before.
('40', 296, 7, 20, 691180) The Hindu, 25 10 1927 and Young India, 3 11 1927

('40', 297, 1, 2, 691770) superiority so long as he continued to be a Brahmin.
('40', 297, 2, 3, 691823) Gandhiji said, taking an extreme case to drive the matter home : Even Sita is not superior to a prostitute.
('40', 297, 2, 4, 691931) Are you satisfied?
('40', 297, 3, 5, 691950) The friend said, “No, quite shocked.” Gandhiji said : I am, for Sita had no sense of superiority.
('40', 297, 3, 6, 692048) Had she been proud of her purity she would have been nowhere.
('40', 297, 3, 7, 692110) But she was not even conscious of it.
('40', 297, 3, 8, 692148) She was pure, because it was impossible for her to be otherwise.
('40', 297, 3, 9, 692213) Are the Himalayas conscious of their supreme heights?
('40', 297, 3, 10, 692267) Not a bit of it.
('40', 297, 3, 11, 692284) But if they were, they would crumble to pieces.
('40', 297, 3, 12, 692332) Even so, varna, if it becomes synonymous with superiority, and an expression of egotism, will be nothing better than a halter round the neck.
('40', 297, 3, 13, 692474) Max Muller put the spirit of Hinduism in a nutshell when he said : “India considers life as only one thing—DUTY—whereas others thought of enjoyment cum duty”.
('40', 297, 3, 14, 692633) Varna is nothing more than an indication of the duty that has been handed down to each one of us by our forefathers.
('40', 297, 3, 15, 692750) In the West, when they talk of the amelioration of the lot of the masses, they talk of raising their standard of life.
('40', 297, 3, 16, 692869) In India we need not talk of raising the standard of life.
('40', 297, 3, 17, 692928) For, how can an outsider raise the standard, when the standard is within every one of us?
('40', 297, 3, 18, 693018) We can only strive to increase man’s opportunities of realizing and fulfilling his duties and of getting nearer to God.
('40', 297, 3, 19, 693138) But you are today attempting the impossible task of uprooting the tree.
('40', 297, 3, 20, 693210) Some of the branches and leaves, I admit, are rotten.
('40', 297, 3, 21, 693264) Let us have the pruning knife and lop off those diseased branches, but let us not lay the axe at the root.
('40', 297, 3, 22, 693371) You will be bad gardeners to destroy the tree under which you have lived and grown.
('40', 297, 3, 23, 693455) Cut off the unnecessary excrescences, even if in the end the trunk with the root appears like a stubble, but if you keep the root intact and then fondly water it, it will some day grow into a fine big tree.
('40', 297, 3, 24, 693662) But as I said the tree cannot be destroyed, for the true Brahmin will stand all blows and yet stand erect in his sacrificial dignity.
('40', 297, 3, 25, 693796) I will admit that there are few Brahmins today, few Kshatriyas, few Vaisyas and even few Sudras.
('40', 297, 3, 26, 693893) For the Sudra too has an individuality.
('40', 297, 3, 27, 693933) We are all slaves today.
('40', 297, 3, 28, 693958) We cower today before the insolent might of a Dyer.
('40', 297, 3, 29, 694010) Let us all aspire to fulfil each one of us his calling.
('40', 297, 3, 30, 694066) Most of us will have to be Vaisyas, for it is the Vaisyas who hold us under their heels.

('40', 298, 1, 2, 694456) 188. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TIRUPPUR 1
('40', 298, 2, 3, 694498) October 23, 1927
('40', 298, 3, 4, 694515) FRIENDS, I thank you for all your addresses and all these purses, as also the different gifts of khadi and these two diamond earrings which have cut out the work for me and for you.
('40', 298, 3, 5, 694697) Because, as you have known by this time, the valuable gifts are of value to me only on behalf of Daridranarayana and not for personal use.
('40', 298, 3, 6, 694836) What little khadi I need for my own use I have already.
('40', 298, 3, 7, 694892) And therefore, if you will have the patience, at the end of the speech I shall offer you all the khadi and these valuable earrings and these frames for your acceptance.
('40', 298, 3, 8, 695061) You remind me that when some time ago I visited Tiruppur you called me khadi king and you called this the capital of the khadi king.
('40', 298, 3, 9, 695194) It was a title which I accepted gratefully and in all humility and I recognized your claim to call this the capital of the khadi king and inasmuch as I am not an exacting king, I am able to say that you have fairly earned the title that you gave to yourselves.
('40', 298, 3, 10, 695455) You will retain the first place in all India in the matter of production.
('40', 298, 3, 11, 695529) You have improved the quality of your khadi.
('40', 298, 3, 12, 695574) But when I consider my own ambition and what it is that is required of you and of all India, I must confess that the progress, good relatively though it is, is not satisfactory.
('40', 298, 3, 13, 695752) For, considering what we intend to do through the length and breadth of India, naturally this capital is expected to make use of all the cotton that is produced in the neighbouring areas.
('40', 298, 3, 14, 695940) I expect you to have, by dint of service, such a hold upon the cotton cultivators that they would sell their cotton only to you and I expect you also by the same right of service to influence the poor villagers so that there will not be a single home left without a spinning wheel working in it, and that there will not be a single weaver who weaves anything but hand spun yarn.
('40', 298, 3, 15, 696319) I do not want you to consider that this is beyond your reach.
('40', 298, 3, 16, 696381) If you will retain the privilege of calling your town the capital of khadi you must have this ambition, and you will find that if you are actuated not by a motive of exploitation but by the simple motive of service to the poor villagers you will find that in no time you will acquire the influence that you should, both over the villagers and over the cotton cultivators

('40', 309, 0, 1, 715413) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 309, 1, 2, 715455) 201. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CALICUT
('40', 309, 2, 3, 715494) October 25, 1927
('40', 309, 3, 4, 715511) FRIENDS, I thank you for all these addresses, these purses, gifts of yarn and books and a watch.
('40', 309, 3, 5, 715608) I shall present these things for your acceptance and convert them into money.
('40', 309, 3, 6, 715686) And here our friend has just sent me a copy of Rabindranath Tagore’s Sadhana.
('40', 309, 3, 7, 715764) He is a student and says: “My sole object in presenting this book, i.e., Tagore’s Sadhana, is that you might auction it and the money so realized might be added to the students’ purse.” I recall the time now, many years ago, when I had the privilege with my friend and brother, Maulana Shaukat Ali, to address a meeting of this character from this very beautiful beach.
('40', 309, 3, 8, 716134) Since then, many changes and grave happenings have taken place in this country.
('40', 309, 3, 9, 716214) We know also that, at the present moment, the horizon in the north appears as black as it can be.
('40', 309, 3, 10, 716312) But I should be false to myself and false to my country if I did not, in spite of the blackness of the horizon, redeclare my immovable faith in the necessity and possibility of Hindus and Mussalmans living in this land as blood brothers.
('40', 309, 3, 11, 716550) God alone knows how this consummation, so much to be desired, is to be brought about.
('40', 309, 3, 12, 716636) But then, we know how often God confounds man’s plans and brings about events for which he is least ready.
('40', 309, 3, 13, 716743) And I would invite those who have the good of the country at heart to share this living faith of man with me.
('40', 309, 3, 14, 716853) And this reminds me of a somewhat remarkable letter that was placed in my hands this afternoon.
('40', 309, 3, 15, 716949) I have not yet been able to know who the writer of that letter is.
('40', 309, 3, 16, 717016) I was not able to read the whole of this long letter myself, but I asked a friend to give me the substance of that letter.
('40', 309, 3, 17, 717139) And the substance of that letter is this.
('40', 309, 3, 18, 717181) The writer says, ‘It is all very well for you to ask Mussalmans and Christians to save the cow for you.’ But the friend adds, ‘What are you doing to the Hindus who are, in the sacred name of religion, killing day after day and year after year innocent animals and birds?’ The rebuke is well deserved.
('40', 309, 3, 19, 717482) I do not know how far this evil of sacrificing innocent animals and birds in the name of God prevails in this part of India.
('40', 309, 3, 20, 717607) The writer little knows my sentiments about these things.
('40', 309, 3, 21, 717665) Wherever I have spotted this evil, I have neither spared myself nor my hearers in condemning it.
('40', 309, 3, 22, 717762) I know that this practice of
('40', 310, 0, 1, 717791) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 311
('40', 310, 1, 2, 717840) sacrificing animals and birds in the name of the Almighty is a sinful superstition.
('40', 310, 1, 3, 717924) And it is time that the Hindus, wherever they may be, who are offering great sacrifices, stop this sinful practice.
('40', 310, 1, 4, 718040) I should be always in association with any movement designed to stop this inhuman practice.
('40', 310, 1, 5, 718132) I derive comfort from the knowledge that this practice is not increasing in this country.
('40', 310, 1, 6, 718222) But it is day by day falling into disrepute.
('40', 310, 1, 7, 718267) It was only the other day that Her Highness the Maharani Regent of Travancore stopped all such sacrifices, and what she has been able to do by decree, you can do by cultivating public opinion against this practice in this part of the country.
('40', 310, 1, 8, 718510) But I must hasten to other parts of my speech.
('40', 310, 1, 9, 718557) I am glad that the students have come forward with their address.
('40', 310, 1, 10, 718623) There is nothing new about their presenting me with the address.
('40', 310, 1, 11, 718688) All over India, it has been my good fortune to enjoy the confidence and friendship of the student world.
('40', 310, 1, 12, 718793) But I mention my pleasure over this address, because it contains a promise about khadi.
('40', 310, 1, 13, 718881) The students have made a solemn promise in thier address, henceforth to use nothing but khadi.
('40', 310, 1, 14, 718976) Let me remind the students of the sacredness of promises.
('40', 310, 1, 15, 719034) It is the custom very often in our country as also elsewhere especially for enthusiastic students to make all sorts of promises.
('40', 310, 1, 16, 719163) This habit of making promises is really a vicious habit unless it is accompanied by a firm determination to fulfil them at any cost.
('40', 310, 1, 17, 719296) If my recollections serve me right, it was from a teacher in Calicut that I received a pathetic letter asking me to speak to the student world, and put an emphasis on some of their failings.
('40', 310, 1, 18, 719487) Day after day, it is being realized by educationists all the world over that mere literary education, unless it is built upon a solid foundation of character, is not only of no avail but is a mischievous accomplishment, and the beginning of character building is surely made by complete adherence to truth.
('40', 310, 1, 19, 719794) And it is a departure from truth not to fulfil a promise which has been once made.
('40', 310, 1, 20, 719877) It is not a bad thing not to make promises hastily and without due deliberation.
('40', 310, 1, 21, 719958) But it is absolutely necessary, after having once made them, to abide by them and fulfil them even though we should have to die in the attempt.
('40', 310, 1, 22, 720102) I therefore hope that the students, having made the promise, will abide by it.
('40', 310, 1, 23, 720181) But there are other things to which my attention was drawn in this letter, that the student world was thoughtlessly drifting and indulging in what might be superficially considered minor vices.
('40', 310, 1, 24, 720375) My attention was drawn to the habit, which is spreading amongst students, of smoking and excessive tea or coffee drinking.
('40', 310, 1, 25, 720498) These things may
('40', 311, 0, 1, 720515) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 311, 1, 2, 720557) appear insignificant; but I know from the experience of many students that these are by no means insignificant things.
('40', 311, 1, 3, 720676) It is a symptom of want of self restraint; and this want of self restraint is undermining the constitutions of the student world throughout India.
('40', 311, 1, 4, 720823) I, therefore, urge the students to think well over what I have said reconsider and recast their life.
('40', 311, 1, 5, 720925) According to the Hindu conception, a student has to be and should remain a brahmachari so long as he is studying.
('40', 311, 1, 6, 721039) If a student desires, as he ought to, to observe this self control both in mind and body, it is necessary for him to deny himself all those things that are superfluous.
('40', 311, 1, 7, 721208) Coming to the other addresses I am glad that I find in every one of them, an enthusiastic endorsement of the message of the spinning wheel.
('40', 311, 1, 8, 721348) There is no doubt that, in abandoning home spuns, we have committed a crime against Indian humanity, and it seems that Calicut was the very first offender in this respect; for I understand that it bears the name it does because Calicut was the first port where India turned to import calico from outside.
('40', 311, 1, 9, 721653) But now I see your belief in the potency of khadi, and as you have told me that, whilst Calicut itself might appear a prosperous place, the country all round is groaning under poverty, it behoves you now to undo the mischief which Calicut commenced.

('40', 311, 1, 11, 722105) But even that is not enough.
('40', 311, 1, 12, 722134) You have to apply your talent to the organization and production of khadi in this very place.
('40', 311, 1, 13, 722228) You, the citizens, including the students, can do so by doing sacrificial spinning and, having thus created the spinning atmosphere, you can take the gospel of spinning to all the villages round you and expect the villagers to spin for the whole of Malabar.
('40', 311, 1, 14, 722486) And if you will but do so, you will find that you can add Rs. 4 per head per year to the wealth of the country and that you will do without replacing any other profitable occupation or without taking away from a single minute of your time which might be otherwise usefully occupied.
('40', 311, 1, 15, 722769) And this is the penance we are expected to do for the sin that our forefathers committed.
('40', 311, 1, 16, 722859) There is again the great evil, concentrated or intensified in this part of the country, of untouchability known as unapproachability and unseeability.
('40', 311, 1, 17, 723010) The sooner we Hindus get rid of it the better it is for us and Hinduism.

('40', 313, 12, 15, 725461) October 26, 1927
('40', 313, 13, 16, 725478) DEAR FRIENDS, It has given me the greatest pleasure to be in your midst.
('40', 313, 13, 17, 725551) I also liked the idea of your absolutely facing me so that I can have a good look at all of you.
('40', 313, 13, 18, 725648) It distresses me somewhat that we have got these different sections here.

('40', 314, 1, 2, 726517) only occasion when I was able to see a Nayadi I was not able to get a touch of him, because of a fearful hedge dividing me from him.
('40', 314, 1, 3, 726650) I could not induce him to come round the hedge and onto the road, where I and my friends were standing, and I made myself believe that then I had no time to pass nor walk along the hedge and then pass by it and go on to this friend.
('40', 314, 1, 4, 726883) So, if anybody in this audience or elsewhere accused me of making empty professions, I should straightway plead guilty.
('40', 314, 1, 5, 727003) But, side by side with pleading guilty, I should also unhesitatingly declare that I felt for them and felt for you as keenly as anyone can possibly do in this world.
('40', 314, 1, 6, 727169) Well, I am rather afraid that this very long address you have not understood, nor has it been explained to you.
('40', 314, 1, 7, 727281) And so, I propose to tell you what that address contains.
('40', 314, 1, 8, 727339) The substance of it is that those who are called untouchables and unapproachables and unseeables are treated in the land of their birth as not merely outcastes, but as slaves; that they are property to be sold and bought; that you do not even enjoy the right of road that a human being should have in every part of the world, and that it was not without much difficulty that you were able successfully to get one girl admitted into a municipal school in Calicut.
('40', 314, 1, 9, 727802) I do not know how far this last allegation, which is specific, is true; but I am quite aware that the substance of your address is true.
('40', 314, 1, 10, 727939) And it is true, because, even we, who have gathered here and are witnessing this giving of address to me and my speech to you, have been and are neglectful of your interests.
('40', 314, 1, 11, 728114) If we, who falsely call ourselves touchables, and what not, and arrogate superiority to ourselves, really felt for you as blood brothers, these things could not stand for one single day.
('40', 314, 1, 12, 728301) But there is a silver lining to this black cloud.
('40', 314, 1, 13, 728351) Hindu conscience has been stung to the quick, and, at the present moment, a mighty movement is going on throughout the length and breadth of India to do some little reparation to you for the atrocious wrong that has been done to you.
('40', 314, 1, 14, 728585) Many Indians who are known as great men are today interesting themselves in this matter.
('40', 314, 1, 15, 728674) I have therefore no doubt whatsoever in my mind that the time is soon coming when these disabilities will disappear in their entirety.
('40', 314, 1, 16, 728809) And I have no doubt also that if these disabilities do not disappear by some act of sacrifice and repentance on the part of the Hindus, Hinduism itself will disappear.
('40', 314, 1, 17, 728977) You have suggested, or it has been suggested on your behalf, in the addresses, that institutions should be established for you all over, which have residential arrangements for the instruction of your boys.
('40', 314, 1, 18, 729184) The idea is no doubt admirable.
('40', 314, 1, 19, 729216) You have yourselves mentioned the

('40', 315, 1, 2, 729292) name of Mr. Kelappan Nair.
('40', 315, 1, 3, 729319) He is conducting one such institution.
('40', 315, 1, 4, 729358) Not very far from here is also Sabari Ashram.
('40', 315, 1, 5, 729404) But I know that these are all too short for their requirements.
('40', 315, 1, 6, 729468) And I want to tell you, and tell everybody in this audience that if more institutions have not sprung into being, it is not due to want of funds, but it is due to want of workers.
('40', 315, 1, 7, 729648) There are Hindus enough today in India, who are willing to give as much money as may be required, if they can be assured that there are honest, industrious, self sacrificing and intelligent workers to do this work.
('40', 315, 1, 8, 729863) But to the shame of savarna Hindus, it must be confessed that we have not many workers of the stamp I have described for this work, and I am also aware that locally there is not even money enough for this work.
('40', 315, 1, 9, 730074) The largest amount of money required, even for this work, comes from the North.
('40', 315, 1, 10, 730154) It should not be so, and, in order that this movement of reform, which is long overdue in Hinduism, may become really universal in India, it is necessary that local Hindus everywhere should come forward and organize this reform both with men and money.
('40', 315, 1, 11, 730407) And for this purpose, I want to make a concrete suggestion.

('40', 315, 1, 20, 731701) I have no doubt that, if you could only feel your strength, you could free yourselves today.
