('40', 323, 2, 8, 750619) 207. A WORTHY EXAMPLE
('40', 323, 3, 9, 750641) The Vice Chairman of the Municipality of Chanda (C.P.) writes as follows :
('40', 323, 4, 10, 750716) This is the first Municipality in Central Provinces and Berar to exempt khadi from payment of octroi.
('40', 323, 4, 11, 750818) Over and above this, from 1922 it has been regularly making an annual grant of Rs. 500 for khadi work which is being utilized for maintaining a ‘Shuddha Khadi Karyalaya’ here.
('40', 323, 4, 12, 750994) This Karyalaya has now been affiliated to the All India Spinners’ Association.
('40', 323, 4, 13, 751073) The yarn produced in it has been found to be the best in Maharashtra, with regard to its count, evenness and strength.
('40', 323, 4, 14, 751192) Since 1922 the Municipality has been employing, for all its purposes, exclusively khadi manufactured in the Chanda Khadi Karyalaya.
('40', 323, 4, 15, 751324) It is now considering a scheme for introducing khadi in its schools.
('40', 323, 4, 16, 751393) The resolution referred to reads :
('40', 323, 5, 17, 751428) Resolved that all the hand supn and hand woven khadi certified for its genuineness by the All India Spinners’ Association be exempted from payment of octroi duty.
('40', 323, 5, 18, 751591) This is an example worthy of imitation by every munici pality.
('40', 323, 5, 19, 751654) The khadi work by this Municipality is no new love but it is well tried.
('40', 323, 5, 20, 751727) It has survived the vicissitudes through which the other municipalities, large and small, have passed, and it has grown from year to year.
('40', 323, 5, 21, 751866) The Municipality has been able to achieve this success because many of its members not only believe in the message of the wheel but reduce their belief into practice in their own lives.
('40', 323, 5, 22, 752052) Th evolution of khadi in this Municipality has been natural in its stages.
('40', 323, 5, 23, 752127) It commenced with a monetary grant, then they introduced khadi uniform for its servants.

('40', 324, 2, 8, 753156) 208. PROFITABLE COTTON CULTIVATION
('40', 324, 3, 9, 753191) A correspondent suggests that there should be a widespread movement to induce cotton cultivators to store a quantity of cotton for themselves to be converted into hand spun yarn and finally into khadi for their own use.
('40', 324, 3, 10, 753411) He also suggests that in non cotton areas individual peasants should be encouraged to grow enough cotton as they grow vegetables for their own requirements.
('40', 324, 3, 11, 753568) The correspondent contends that if this becomes popular, it will cheapen khadi for the peasantry.
('40', 324, 3, 12, 753666) He says that in some parts of the South before the khadi movement came there were cultivators who followed this method.
('40', 324, 3, 13, 753786) The correspondent thinks that Indian States are best able to promote this kind of cultivation of cotton.
('40', 324, 3, 14, 753891) There is much force in the correspondent’s suggestion.
('40', 324, 3, 15, 753946) The experiment of inducing cotton cultivators to retain sufficient cotton for their own needs is being tried in Bijolia (Rajputana), Bardoli and Kathiawar.
('40', 324, 3, 16, 754102) But it has been found difficult in Kathiawar for the cultivators to resist the temptation of selling stored cotton when prices ruled high.
('40', 324, 3, 17, 754241) This is not possible, until the cultivators appreciate the economics of khadi, and the fact that labour spent upon cotton during their leisure hours in subjecting it to the processes antecedent to weaving will bring about the same result that they achieve by selling cotton at a high price, and will in addition free themselves from the clutches of the speculator.
('40', 324, 3, 18, 754606) This means that the All India Spinners’ Association will have to educate the cultivators in the economics of
('40', 325, 0, 1, 754715) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 325, 1, 2, 754757) There is no doubt that in order to overtake all the branches of khadi work it is necessary for khadi workers to come in close touch with the cotton growers, because even for buying cotton for the manufacture of khadi for town consumption, it would be necessary to come to touch with the cotton growers, and buy from them direct instead of buying in the market as is being done at present.
('40', 325, 1, 3, 755146) If we would be independent of the speculator and the fluctuations of the cotton market and stabilize the price of khadi, we shall have to come in touch with the cultivator and induce him to deal with us directly.
('40', 325, 1, 4, 755359) The greater the progress of khadi the more shall we find that our methods have to be far different from those hiterto adopted by the commercial world, which believes in selling at the highest price obtainable and buying at the cheapest rate possible.
('40', 325, 1, 5, 755610) The world commerce at the present moment is not based upon equitable considerations.
('40', 325, 1, 6, 755695) Its maxim is: ‘Buyers beware.’ The maxim of khadi economics is: ‘Equity for all.’ It therefore rules out the present soul killing competitive method.
('40', 325, 1, 7, 755845) Khadi economics are designed in the interest of the poorest and the helpless, and khadi will be successful only to the extent that the workers permeate the masses and command their confidence.
('40', 325, 1, 8, 756038) And the only way of commanding their confidence is doing selfless work among them.
('40', 325, 1, 9, 756121) The correspondent’s suggestion that the Indian States are more fortunately placed in the matter of storing cotton by cotton cultivators and growing enough for home consumption by other cultivators is no doubt true.
('40', 325, 1, 10, 756336) The question however is: ‘Who will bell the cat ?’ The majority of the States are little concerned with the welfare of the peasantry.
('40', 325, 1, 11, 756470) Their aim in life for the present moment seems to be to increase their revenue as much as possible and at any cost, and to spend the largest part of it for their own pleasures.
('40', 325, 1, 12, 756647) Moreover they, like other capitalists, have little faith in khadi economics.
('40', 325, 1, 13, 756724) A very cautious experiment is now being tried, in Mysore, of finding out the possibilities of the spinning wheel as a village industry.
('40', 325, 1, 14, 756860) One may hope that if that experiment is tried scientifically and patiently and is found to succeed, it would prove infectious.

('40', 326, 3, 5, 757564) The drama is based on the real experience of the depressedclass member of our District School Board, who was refused admission into a school housed in a temple in a neighbouring village, while his Mussalman fellow member and companion was admitted to inspect the school!

('40', 327, 4, 10, 760284) 211. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('40', 327, 5, 11, 760312) OMBAY October 29, 1927
('40', 327, 6, 12, 760335) When asked by a representative of The Indian Daily Mail whether he would be prepared to accept the appointment of assessors on the Royal Commission or boycott it, Mahatma Gandhi said : I have not given any thought to this question.
('40', 327, 7, 13, 760567) He said he was out of touch with events being away in South India and hence was not prepared to say anything about the rumours he was told about Indians being excluded from the Royal Commission.
('40', 327, 8, 14, 760762) Referring to the Unity Conference, Gandhiji said that he had not been specially invited to it, but being a member of the All India Congress Committee and the Working Committee he would under ordinary circumstances have attended the Conference.
('40', 327, 8, 15, 761006) He did not attend the Conference, because there was no way in which his services would be of any use.
('40', 327, 9, 16, 761108) The representative asked him: “As the question of Hindu Muslim unity is important, don’t you think that if you had lent your support to the deliberations of the Conference, it would have been of great assistance in arriving at an amicable settlement of the problem?”
('40', 327, 10, 17, 761375) 1 Gandhiji left Mangalore on the morning of October 27 to see the Viceroy on November 2.
('40', 328, 0, 1, 761464) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 329
('40', 328, 1, 2, 761513) [GANDHIJI]: I admit it is a very important question.
('40', 328, 1, 3, 761566) If I had thought that I could assist the deliberations of the Conference, I would certainly have suspended my tour and gone to Calcutta.
('40', 328, 1, 4, 761703) In short, I simply say that I hold strange views about the way of bringing about unity which in the present atmosphere cannot get accepted.
('40', 328, 1, 5, 761843) Therefore, I can only be a hindrance rather than a help.
('40', 328, 1, 6, 761900) So I felt that my abstaining was a kind of service.
('40', 328, 2, 7, 761952) Mahatmaji added that his “strange views” might be gleaned from the pages of Young India.
('40', 328, 3, 8, 762041) [In reply to another question Gandhiji said :] If someone invites me to consult me on some public matter I never reject the invitation.
('40', 328, 4, 9, 762177) He said he was not going to meet the Viceroy as a representative of anyone.
('40', 328, 4, 10, 762253) Speaking about the Unity Conference at Calcutta, he said : I was not invited to the Conference.

('40', 328, 6, 17, 762881) Answering the critism evoked by his statement that in some Hindu temples God was present only as much as He was in brothels, Gandhiji said : I am not prepared to withdraw a single word of what I said.
('40', 328, 6, 18, 763082) In a way, it is the truth.

('40', 329, 3, 6, 764218) 212. NOTES
('40', 329, 4, 7, 764229) WNERLESS A language which does not possess a universally accepted dictionary but admits all words in it may be regarded as ownerless.
('40', 329, 4, 8, 764363) We have inexhaustible means at our disposal for checking spellings of English words.
('40', 329, 4, 9, 764448) From huge dictionaries to the smallest and cheapest pocket sized ones they are available.
('40', 329, 4, 10, 764538) In all of them uniform spellings are to be found.
('40', 329, 4, 11, 764588) I have an impression that commonly accepted dictionaries are available for Hindustani and other language.
('40', 329, 4, 12, 764694) Gujarati is the only language which has hitherto remained ownerless.
('40', 329, 4, 13, 764763) I do not know of a single Gujarati dictionary which is commonly accepted or which contains all the words in the language.
('40', 329, 4, 14, 764885) I have often made efforts in this direction but failed every time.
('40', 329, 4, 15, 764952) Some workers have been making efforts over several years to remedy this deficiency.
('40', 329, 4, 16, 765036) Their work may now be regarded as having secured a good footing.
('40', 329, 4, 17, 765101) Shri Narahari Parikh has taken upon himself the special responsibility for this.
('40', 329, 4, 18, 765182) Kakasaheb Kalelkar is its founder compiler.
('40', 329, 4, 19, 765226) The approval of as many learned men as possible has been secured in regard to the principles that are being followed in the compilation of this dictionary 2. It will be published under their seals and their signatures.
('40', 329, 4, 20, 765445) However, an increasing number of difficulties are cropping up as this work makes headway.
('40', 329, 4, 21, 765535) Every lover of the language can help in
('40', 329, 5, 22, 765575) 1 For the removal of Neill statue in Madras; vide also “The Neill Statue and Non Violence”, September 29, 1927 and “Neill Statue Satyagraha”, October 13, 1927. 2 Jodni Kosh, published in 1929 with a preface by D. B. Kalelkar
('40', 330, 0, 1, 765800) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 331
('40', 330, 1, 2, 765849) solving some of these difficulties.
('40', 330, 1, 3, 765885) The reader will see for himself how and in what particular manner he can help by reading Shri Narahari Parikh’s appeal to the lovers of the language published in this issue.
('40', 330, 1, 4, 766059) Without the assistance of a large number of persons this work cannot be accomplished as well as it should be.

('40', 330, 2, 7, 766279) 213. INTERVIEW TO “INDIAN NATIONAL HERALD”
('40', 330, 3, 8, 766322) [On or before October 30, 1927] 1
('40', 330, 4, 9, 766356) A representative of the Indian National Herald questioned him as to what attitude he would take up at the Viceregal Conference, if he were faced with the proposition so much in the air, viz., that the Statutory Commission is to be composed of parliamentarians and Indians to act as mere assessors.
('40', 330, 4, 10, 766654) Gandhiji replied : How the Royal Commission should be constituted is as alien a subject to me as, say, the cure for tuberculosis which falls in the province of a medical expert.
('40', 330, 4, 11, 766832) I have paid no thought to the subject of Royal Commission because it is distinctly outside the sphere of my knowledge, thoughts and activities.
('40', 330, 5, 12, 766976) Q. Would you accept a seat on the Royal Commission, if one was offered to you?
('40', 330, 6, 13, 767055) A. What is the use of asking me that question?
('40', 330, 6, 14, 767102) I had once speculated what I would do if I were appointed Viceroy of India, but those days of speculation are gone.
('40', 330, 7, 15, 767218) In the end, the Herald’s representative asked: “As a sure panacea for the country’s ills, it has been suggested that you should be given dictatorial powers in all our national activities and be persuaded to play the Mussolini in India.
('40', 330, 7, 16, 767454) How do you think that idea will work?”
('40', 330, 8, 17, 767493) Gandhiji returned a hearty laugh, then replied in all seriousness : I have neither the ambitions of Mussolini nor can I have his powers.
('40', 330, 8, 18, 767630) If dictatorship were thrust on me, I should cut a sorry figure as an Indian Mussolini.
('40', 330, 8, 19, 767717) Moreover, you can’t impose by force any reforms, social or otherwise.
('40', 330, 8, 20, 767787) In other words, you cannot make people good by force.
('40', 330, 8, 21, 767841) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 3 11 1927
('40', 330, 9, 22, 767873) 1 Gandhiji arrived in Bombay on October 29 and left for Delhi on the 30th.

('40', 333, 9, 19, 772149) 219. SPEECH AT JAMIA MILLIA ISLAMIA, DELHI
('40', 333, 10, 20, 772192) November 2, 1927 The boys that were just introduced to you are grandsons of my friend and fellow worker who was like a blood brother to me, the late Ahmed Mahomed Kachhalia whom I naturally recall as I see the boys, and about whom I think I had better tell you something.
('40', 333, 10, 21, 772464) Amongst the Hindus and Mussalmans that lived in South Africa in the days of satyagraha there was not a single Indian who could compare with Kachhalia in his bravery and his integrity.
('40', 333, 10, 22, 772648) He sacrificed his all for the honour and prestige of his country.
('40', 333, 10, 23, 772714) He cared not for his business nor for his wealth, nor for his friends, and plunged himself whole heartedly into the struggle.
('40', 333, 10, 24, 772840) Even in those days the cursed Hindu Muslim differences now and then cropped up, but Kachhalia held the
('40', 333, 11, 25, 772943) 1 Addressee’s wife who had passed away a few days earlier
('40', 334, 0, 1, 773001) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 335
('40', 334, 1, 2, 773050) scales even between the two.
('40', 334, 1, 3, 773079) No one ever accused him of partiality for his community.
('40', 334, 1, 4, 773136) And he had learnt this great virtue of patriotism and tolerance not at any school nor in England, but in his own home, for he wrote even Gujarati with difficulty.
('40', 334, 1, 5, 773299) Lawyers were amazed at the way in which he met their arguments and puzzled them, and his uncommon common sense was often very helpful to them.
('40', 334, 1, 6, 773442) It was he who led the satyagrahis, and he died in harness.
('40', 334, 1, 7, 773501) 1 He had a son called Ali whom he had trusted to my care.
('40', 334, 1, 8, 773559) A lad of 11 he was wonderfully restrained, and a devout Mussalman.
('40', 334, 1, 9, 773626) He never missed a day of fast during the sacred month of Ramzan.
('40', 334, 1, 10, 773691) And yet he had not will towards Hindu boys.
('40', 334, 1, 11, 773735) Today so called religious devoutness in either is synonymous with a dislike, if not hatred, for other religions.
('40', 334, 1, 12, 773848) Ali had no such dislike, no hatred.
('40', 334, 1, 13, 773884) Well, both the father and the son are to me names to conjure with, and may their example inspire you.
('40', 334, 1, 14, 773986) In those days when Hindus and Mussalmans seemed to be one and ready to shed their blood for one another, and for their country, I appealed to the students to leave Government schools and colleges.
('40', 334, 1, 15, 774183) The many years that have passed have left me utterly unrepentant for having asked those boys to come out of those institutions, and I am firmly of opinion that those who responded to the call served their land, and I am sure the future historian of India will record their sacrifice with approval.
('40', 334, 1, 16, 774481) But alas, today there are Muslims who go to mosques and offer prayers, and there are Hindus who visit temples, worship God and they are full of hatred against each other.
('40', 334, 1, 17, 774652) They have begun to think that going to mosque or temple means that we should hate each other.
('40', 334, 1, 18, 774746) But Ali, though a very religious soul, never thought so.
('40', 334, 1, 19, 774803) I have related this story to you simply because I wish every one of you to be truly patriotic like the great Kachhalia and his loving son Ali.
('40', 334, 1, 20, 774946) I pray to God to bless you with their noble heart.
('40', 334, 2, 21, 774997) Hakimji has reminded you of that memorable day (11th October, 1920) , when Hindus and Muslims had sun their differences and they had united for ever, when students all over India were invited

('40', 335, 1, 3, 775598) I know that I had a great hand in this invitation, but I make bold to say that even after seven years, I don’t feel the least sorry for that nor do I think that I committed a blunder in that.
('40', 335, 1, 4, 775790) I believe that those who gave up thier studies at the Government institutions did a great service to the country.

('40', 335, 2, 9, 776491) Freedom has very little to do with your learning the letters or even with mere mechanical plying of the takli.

('40', 335, 2, 15, 777091) In fact I am glad that we should be living from hand to mouth, so that we may all the better cherish our Maker and fear Him.
('40', 335, 3, 16, 777216) Mahatmaji laid great stress on the fact that if the University was doing good work, they must be confident that God will supply them with funds.

('40', 337, 0, 1, 780109) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 337, 1, 2, 780151) 220. NEED FOR SELF CONVERSION
('40', 337, 2, 3, 780181) Lokamanya gave us his message in four simple words.
('40', 337, 2, 4, 780233) But there are even now people who question the proposition that swaraj is their birthright even as there are some who question the existence of God.
('40', 337, 2, 5, 780382) The swaraj movement, therefore, is a movement to make us realize that swaraj is our birthright.
('40', 337, 2, 6, 780478) In the midst of the many reminders that we already have of the existence of this need of self conversion, the debate in the Madras Legislative Council on the Neill statue satyagraha came as an additional and emphatic reminder of that need.
('40', 337, 2, 7, 780718) The innocent resolution asking for the removal of the offending statue was lost by an overwhelming majority.
('40', 337, 2, 8, 780827) Almost all the Indian members, except the stalwarts, voted against the resolution.
('40', 337, 2, 9, 780910) The motion showed the sharp difference between the Swarajist mentality and every other.
('40', 337, 2, 10, 780998) This vote and the debate are a fresh demonstration of the fact that swaraj is delayed not so much by the obstinacy of the English ‘rulers’ as by our own refusal to recognize and work for our status.
('40', 337, 2, 11, 781197) This agitation for the removal of the Neill statue is, in my humble opinion, a step towards our goal.
('40', 337, 2, 12, 781299) National self respect demands the removal not only of the Neill statue but of every emblem of our slavery, as I regard this statue to be.
('40', 337, 2, 13, 781437) The agitation gains force by reason of the fact that it has no material gain as its objective.
('40', 337, 2, 14, 781532) Swaraj will be within easy reach when millions of Indians unite in sacrificing themselves for the vindication of mere self respect.
('40', 337, 2, 15, 781664) Why does an Englishman feel personally insulted by and would die in the attempt to resent an insult offered to the Union Jack?
('40', 337, 2, 16, 781791) It is not a sentiment to be despised or curbed.
('40', 337, 2, 17, 781839) The method he adopts to resent the wrong is no doubt often barbarous, but if he ceased to cherish the sentiment itself, he would lose national solidarity and the power of sacrificing himself for the nation to which he belongs.
('40', 337, 2, 18, 782066) Even so, if we were conscious of our birthright, it should be a matter for pride for us to know that there are young men who resent the presence in our midst of a statue that is an insult to the nation.
('40', 337, 2, 19, 782269) Many Indian members who took part in the debate betrayed no such consciousness or pride.
('40', 337, 2, 20, 782358) To them the young men who were fighting the nations’s battle were ignorant men whose conduct was worthy only of condemnation.
('40', 337, 2, 21, 782484) They saw nothing wrong in the statue standing in a prominent public place where there should be statues only of national heroes whose lives
('40', 338, 0, 1, 782624) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 339
('40', 338, 1, 2, 782673) would inspire and ennoble the nation.
('40', 338, 1, 3, 782711) It cannot be too clearly pointed out that this satyagraha is not aimed at General Neill as man.
('40', 338, 1, 4, 782807) It would be just as appropriate and necessary if instead of General Neill it was General Virsingh whose statue was erected in order to perpetuate a reign of ‘frightfulness’ There was in the debate a defence of the statue offered on behalf of the Europeans.
('40', 338, 1, 5, 783064) It was cautiously, temperately and plausibly worded.
('40', 338, 1, 6, 783117) Nevertheless it betrayed the European mentality.
('40', 338, 1, 7, 783166) That for which General Neill stood was necessary for saving the Empire.
('40', 338, 1, 8, 783238) And in order to cover the misdeeds of General Neill, it became necessary for the defender to vote down Mr. Thompson, the author of The Other Side of the Medal, as a neurotic, and to unearth a fulsome address presented to General Neill’s regiment by 110 Hindus of Madras two years after the Mutiny.
('40', 338, 1, 9, 783536) I have no means of ascertaining the circumstances in which the address was presented, but it does not appear to me to be at all strange that such an address was presented.
('40', 338, 1, 10, 783708) For it is possible to quote such instances from contemporary events.
('40', 338, 1, 11, 783777) Was not General Dyer presented with a similar address in Amritsar itself?
('40', 338, 1, 12, 783851) And it would be strange if even now Sir Michael O’Dwyer, if he returned to India, did not find 110 Indians to present an address to him, if it was found necessary in the interest of good government.
('40', 338, 1, 13, 784050) Have not the most unpopular Viceroys received addresses and trophies in our own times?
('40', 338, 1, 14, 784137) It is a matter of great pity to find Englishmen applaud sentiments in us which they would be ashamed to see expressed by Englishmen.
('40', 338, 1, 15, 784270) I remember the wife of a Governor leading loud applause at a conference at which in speaking to a resolution on loyalty a learned Indian permitted himself to say that he considered every Britisher to be his teacher and that he owed all he was to Britain.
('40', 338, 1, 16, 784525) The Madras performance was somewhat after that style and it grieved me.
('40', 338, 1, 17, 784597) But let not the adverse vote of the Madras Council discourage the young men who are fighting the battle against symbols of terrorism.
('40', 338, 1, 18, 784731) They must not be angry against either Englishmen or the Indians who are now opposing the agitation.
('40', 338, 1, 19, 784831) They must have faith in themselves and their cause, and they will convert the very men who are now opposing them.

('40', 348, 4, 7, 798528) 238. WAS IT A FAILURE?
('40', 348, 5, 8, 798551) Repeatedly does one read in the papers that non co operation was a perfect failure.
('40', 348, 5, 9, 798635) Several courteous critics often apologetically broach the question in conversations, and gently tell me that the country would have made great progress if I had not led it astray by my ill conceived non co operation.
('40', 348, 5, 10, 798852) I should not refer to this subject, which may be said to have no bearing on the politics of the day, but for my belief that non co operation has come to us as an active force that may assume a universal form any moment, and but for the purpose of reassuring those who are bravely holding on in the face of criticism and scepticism.
('40', 348, 5, 11, 799184) Let me, how ever, admit the dangerous half truth that non co operation entirely failed the moment it became violent.
('40', 348, 5, 12, 799301) Indeed, non co operation and violence are here contradictory terms.
('40', 348, 5, 13, 799369) It is a living belief that violence lived on itself and it required counter violence for its daily maintenance that gave rise to non violent non co operation.
('40', 348, 5, 14, 799528) The fact, therefore, is that the moment non co operation became violent it lost its vitality and nation building character.
('40', 348, 5, 15, 799652) But in so far as it was and remained non violent, it was a demonstrably complete success.
('40', 348, 5, 16, 799742) The mass awakening that took place in 1920 all of a sudden was perhaps the greatest demonstration of the efficacy of non violence.
('40', 348, 5, 17, 799873) The Government has lost prestige never to be regained.
('40', 348, 5, 18, 799928) Titles, law courts, educational institutions no longer inspire the awe they did in 1920. Some of the best lawyers in the country have given up law for ever as a profession and are happy for having accepted comparative poverty as their lot.
('40', 348, 5, 19, 800168) The few national schools and colleges that remain are giving a good account of themselves, as witness the great organization that came into being in Gujarat when the floods turned into a waste what was once a rich
('40', 348, 6, 20, 800382) 1 The Kathiawar Political Conference
('40', 349, 0, 1, 800419) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 349, 1, 2, 800461) garden.
('40', 349, 1, 3, 800469) But for the students and teachers of national institutions and other non co operators the timely help that the afflicted peasantry of Gujarat received and so much needed would never have been at its disposal.
('40', 349, 1, 4, 800678) It is possible to multiply illustrations of this character and prove that wherever there is real national life, a bond between the classes and the masses in India, non co operation is the cause of it.
('40', 349, 1, 5, 800879) Take again the three constructive items of the programme.
('40', 349, 1, 6, 800937) Khadi is a growing factor in national regeneration and is serving over 1,500 villages through an army of nearly two thousand workers and is giving tangible productive relief to over fifty thousand spinners and at least ten thousand weavers, printers, dyers, dhobis and other artisans.
('40', 349, 1, 7, 801222) Untouchability is a waning thing just struggling for existence.
('40', 349, 1, 8, 801286) Hindu Muslim unity of 1920 21 showed its vast possibilities.
('40', 349, 1, 9, 801347) The violence, deceit, falsehood and the like that mark the rupture between the two great communities today are no doubt ugly signs, but they are a demonstration of crude self consciousness.
('40', 349, 1, 10, 801537) The process of churning that the movement of non co operation was and is has brought the dirt to the surface.
('40', 349, 1, 11, 801647) And if non violent non co operation is a living and purifying force, it will presently bring to view the pure unity that is invisibly forming itself under the very visible dirt that obtrudes itself on our gaze today.
('40', 349, 1, 12, 801864) It is therefore clear to me as daylight that real swaraj, whenever it comes to us, will have to be not a donation rained on us from London, but a prize earned by hard and health giving non co operation with organized forces of evil.

('40', 349, 2, 14, 802121) 239. LETTER TO HARJIVAN KOTAK
('40', 349, 3, 15, 802151) ON THE BOAT “KAVERIMBA” November 10, 1927 One should feel worried and ashamed even if there is involuntary discharge only once.
('40', 349, 3, 16, 802279) It is certain that such discharge is the result of impure desires.
('40', 349, 3, 17, 802346) I was told recently that a person who suffers from constipation may also get it.
('40', 349, 3, 18, 802427) This is true, but constipation is also the result of impure desires.
('40', 349, 3, 19, 802496) A man or woman who is free from such desires will not eat even a grain too much of food.
('40', 349, 3, 20, 802585) Such persons never suffer from constipation.
('40', 349, 3, 21, 802630) But, then, there are two kinds of worry, one necessary and uplifting and another unnecessary and tending to drag us down.
('40', 349, 3, 22, 802752) Despite worry and shame, we would remain cheerful if our lapse was
('40', 350, 0, 1, 802819) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 351
('40', 350, 1, 2, 802868) not intentional or if we did not take pleasure in it.
('40', 350, 1, 3, 802922) Such worry may also be called vigilance.
('40', 350, 1, 4, 802963) The second kind of worry is the remorse one feels afterwards though one had taken pleasure in the lapse when it occurred.
('40', 350, 1, 5, 803085) Such worry preys upon one’s mind and yet one sinks even deeper into the vice.
('40', 350, 1, 6, 803163) A person who worries in this sense gets involuntary discharges more and more frequently, whereas the man who exercises vigilance gets them less and less frequently.
('40', 350, 1, 7, 803328) You will perhaps understand now that a man who gets involuntary discharges cannot afford to remain unconcerned.
('40', 350, 1, 8, 803440) He should sincerely strive to overcome his impure desires.
('40', 350, 1, 9, 803499) If he can remain free from them during waking hours, he should not be frightened by involuntary discharges but should take them as a warning that impure desires are secretly eating him up from within, and he should ceaselessly struggle to save himself from them.
('40', 350, 1, 10, 803762) If, despite his efforts, he cannot stop the discharges, he may have patience but ought not to give up the struggle.
('40', 350, 1, 11, 803878) I am myslef not completely free from involuntary discharges.
('40', 350, 1, 12, 803939) There was a period in my life when I remember to have remained free from them for many years but after I came to India and started taking milk they became more frequent.
('40', 350, 1, 13, 804109) There are other causes besides milk.
('40', 350, 1, 14, 804146) The atmosphere here revived memories of early life.
('40', 350, 1, 15, 804198) There will be a chapter on this in the Autobiography.
('40', 350, 1, 16, 804252) Read it.
('40', 350, 1, 17, 804261) [From Gujarati]

('40', 353, 1, 2, 808675) 244. AN ILL MATCHED UNION OR CHILD SLAUGHTER
('40', 353, 2, 3, 808720) The facts that have come to my knowledge regarding the ill matched union that has taken place or is about to take place in Dhrangadhra State remind me of the essays on this subject which I read forty years ago.
('40', 353, 2, 4, 808931) It is a matter of regret that such unions can take place even today.
('40', 353, 2, 5, 809000) The culprit in this case is a Brahmin servant of Dhrangadhra State.
('40', 353, 2, 6, 809068) His name is Shri Keshavlal Damodar Bhatt.
('40', 353, 2, 7, 809110) He is a revenue officer at Charadva.
('40', 353, 2, 8, 809147) He is about fifty five years old.
('40', 353, 2, 9, 809181) He has three daughters.
('40', 353, 2, 10, 809205) Four years ago he lost his wife and, now with the intention of remarrying, he has got himself engaged to a girl thirteen or fourteen years old.
('40', 353, 2, 11, 809349) The eldest son in law of this Keshavlal has sent me the correspondence that he had with the latter on this subject, in the hope that I would write something about it in Navajivan which might perhaps have some salutary effect on the old man or make him feel ashamed.
('40', 353, 2, 12, 809615) As there is still time to wake up, let him do so and save himself from the great sin of child slaughter.
('40', 353, 2, 13, 809720) Bhartrihari has stated from his own experience that those who seek the gratification of their desires know neither fear nor shame.
('40', 353, 2, 14, 809851) If this lustful old father of three daughters has some fear or shame instilled in him in some manner, that young girl who is fit to sit in his lap as his grand daughter will surely be saved.
('40', 353, 2, 15, 810042) Bhattji wrote the following letter 1 to his son in law on the 6th of October : Prabha is Bhattji’s youngest daughter and this good man has thought of remarriage at this advanced age only because he might feel lonely when she gets married.
('40', 353, 2, 16, 810281) However, almost every one of his letters gives proof of his lust.
('40', 353, 2, 17, 810347) This elderly man, who, blinded by his lust, is about to remarry, exhibits his own hopes in greater detail in his second letter 2. We find from this letter that Bhattji regards this betrothal as an auspicious deed.
('40', 353, 2, 18, 810561) He informs his son in law of his desire to dress his

('40', 354, 2, 3, 810940) However, both his elder daughters and his eldest son in law are against this sinful marriage and oppose it, and the latter requests his father in law to save himself from this sin.
('40', 354, 2, 4, 811121) In reply to this, Bhattji writes to say as follows : 2

('40', 361, 2, 3, 824454) CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I want first of all to apologize to you for not standing up to speak to you.
('40', 361, 2, 4, 824553) For years past I have been unable to address audiences standing; so you will not consider it discourteous on my part if I address you sitting and that I have not received your address standing.
('40', 361, 2, 5, 824747) I am sorry also that at the present moment I have not a voice that would carry far, and I have also to apologize to you and to the citizens of Colombo for not having arrived here in time.
('40', 361, 2, 6, 824935) But for that the blame must rest on stronger shoulders.
('40', 361, 2, 7, 824991) I refer to His Excellency the Viceroy.
('40', 361, 2, 8, 825030) It was he who invited me to go to Delhi, and if you want to pass a vote of censure on His Excellency the Viceroy I will certainly join you.
('40', 361, 2, 9, 825170) But perhaps you will excuse His Excellency and, through him, me also.
('40', 361, 2, 10, 825240) The second cause of my delay was that I came as a passenger on two cargo boats and in spite of the efforts of the captains and the officers to bring me here as soon as they ever could, you will understand the limitations that are imposed upon cargo boats.
('40', 361, 2, 11, 825496) Cargo boats have got to take care of their cargo rather than the passengers, who are interlopers.
('40', 361, 2, 12, 825594) It is a matter of great pleasure to me to receive this address at your hands.
('40', 361, 2, 13, 825672) I was totally unprepared for it.
('40', 361, 2, 14, 825705) Mine, if you will like to take it so, is a mercenary visit.
('40', 361, 2, 15, 825765) I have come to Ceylon in reply to invitations from some of my own countrymen, and I have devoted this year which is about to expire to getting collections on behalf of the cause which is designed to serve millions of paupers in India.
('40', 361, 2, 16, 826000) The temptation that these friends gave me was irresistible.
('40', 361, 2, 17, 826060) I very nearly came to this pearl among the islands of the world in 1901. You may not know that I have many Mussalman friends in South Africa.
('40', 361, 2, 18, 826202) They are dear to me as life itself, and some of them urged me to come to Colombo on my way to India, and I would gladly have done so then, and then I would have come as a sojourner in your midst to appreciate the unrivalled beauties of this very beautiful island and to enjoy also your open hospitality.
('40', 361, 2, 19, 826506) But I cannot say the same today; so that I was not prepared for this address because I hardly deserve it at the present moment.
('40', 362, 0, 1, 826634) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 363
('40', 362, 1, 2, 826683) But I am a lover of municipal life, and although it never fell to my lot to serve a municipality as a councillor, I came as a citizen into the closest touch with two great Corporations.
('40', 362, 1, 3, 826869) I mean the Corporation of Durban and the Corporation of Johannesburg.
('40', 362, 1, 4, 826939) And if you were to ask the mayors of these two Corporations, they will perhaps testify that I served them as much as a single citizen, humble like myself, could possibly do.
('40', 362, 1, 5, 827113) I consider it a great privilege for a person to serve any place where he has cast his lot.
('40', 362, 1, 6, 827204) I have since been studying the methods of great Corporations throughout India, more or less closely, and I have been in search of an ideally conducted municipality in the East.
('40', 362, 1, 7, 827381) I must confess to you that I have not yet found one in my own country.
('40', 362, 1, 8, 827452) I should love to think that you are that ideal Corporation.

('40', 363, 1, 5, 829580) My medical adviser would tell me: ‘In your dilapidated condition you must not go to a place like Colombo’—and if I was inclined to listen to my medical advisers I would not have come if I had read a report of that character before I came here.

('40', 363, 1, 10, 830223) I was sent by friends whilst I was having my convalescence in the Nandi Hills a book on vitamins, and if these writers and distinguished specialists are truthful, they tell us lay people that milk is robbed of its vitamins when subjected to a certain temperature.

('40', 363, 1, 16, 830816) Why go through all this trouble and why not municipalize your dairies and take control of your milk supply, and, believe me, you will then conserve the health of your babies and you will conserve also the health of an old and dilapidated man like myself.
('40', 363, 1, 17, 831071) I have no doubt that you have in Colombo very old men and that they stand in need of milk, and there is a very great labouring population for whom milk should be cheap.
('40', 363, 1, 18, 831240) It should be standardized like your stamps, and the people should be able to get their milk absolutely guaranteed.
('40', 363, 1, 19, 831355) And if you want to do that you cannot do better than municipalize your milk supply and make it accessible to the poorest man in Colombo.
('40', 363, 1, 20, 831492) The third thing and I have done.

('40', 364, 1, 5, 831926) I fancy not.
('40', 364, 1, 6, 831939) They are trustees for those who cannot look after themselves.

('40', 364, 3, 17, 833247) 254. SPEECH AT ANANDA COLLEGE, COLOMBO
('40', 364, 4, 18, 833286) November 15, 1927
('40', 364, 5, 19, 833304) MR. PRINCIPAL, TEACHERS AND BOYS, It has given me great pleasure to be able to come to Colombo and Ceylon and to make your acquaintance.
('40', 364, 5, 20, 833441) Wherever I go I love to see school children.
('40', 364, 5, 21, 833486) Here in Ceylon the majority of the boys come under the influence of Buddhist teaching.
('40', 364, 5, 22, 833573) That great Master taught us what is known as the Right Path, and you, boys, come to institutions of this character to learn the Right Path.
('40', 364, 5, 23, 833713) And to learn the Right Path is not merely to pack our brains with many things that sound nice, goods or sweet, but to do the right things.
('40', 364, 5, 24, 833852) Well, the first maxim of the Right Path is to tell the Truth, to think the Truth and to act the Truth.
('40', 365, 0, 1, 833955) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 365, 1, 2, 833997) the second maxim is to love all that lives.
('40', 365, 1, 3, 834041) Gautama Buddha was so filled with mercy and kindness that it was he who taught us to love not only the members of the human family but also to love all life, to love all the animal world.
('40', 365, 1, 4, 834229) And he taught us also personal purity of life.
('40', 365, 1, 5, 834276) Therefore, if you, boys, are not truthful, are not loving and kind, and not pure in your personal conduct, you have learnt nothing in this institution.
('40', 365, 1, 6, 834428) And which of the boys will tell me where Gautama Buddha was born?
('40', 365, 2, 7, 834494) A very small boy tot who was in front of the Mahatma replied : He was born in Kapilavastu.
('40', 365, 3, 8, 834585) MAHATMAJI : And where is Kapilavastu ?
('40', 365, 4, 9, 834624) THE BOY : It is in India.
('40', 365, 5, 10, 834650) MAHATMAJI : Then I suggest to you all, boys, that you owe something to Gautama’s countrymen, and I am sorry to have to tell you boys, if you do not know it already, that in the land where Gautama lived and taught, and which he hallowed by his feet, there is dire poverty and distress.
('40', 365, 5, 11, 834935) One reason why the sacred people of India, the millions of them, are so poor is because they have abandoned their ancient industry or have been deprived of it, I mean the spinning wheel.
('40', 365, 5, 12, 835122) Well, now, they can revive the spinning wheel if everybody in India and others will wear what can be spun and woven from it.
('40', 365, 5, 13, 835247) That cloth is called khadi.
('40', 365, 5, 14, 835275) Now, if you will render something unto Gautama for the great message of mercy that he delivered to you and to my countrymen, certainly wear khadi.
('40', 365, 5, 15, 835422) So far as I know all the cloth that you little boys and others have worn has not been produced in Colombo or Ceylon, and seeing that you must buy some cloth in order to cover yourselves it is your primary duty to buy that cloth which is woven by the famishing millions, the countrymen of Gautama.
('40', 365, 5, 16, 835719) And if you will do so you will then certainly act or begin to act according to the second maxim in the Right Path.
('40', 365, 5, 17, 835834) What I have told you naturally applies with double force to your teachers and your parents.
('40', 365, 5, 18, 835926) If you are clever, good and brave boys, you will discuss these things with your teachers and your parents and ask them: “What is it this strange man called Gandhi told you?” And if I am not mistaken they will endorse every word of what I have said to you.
('40', 365, 5, 19, 836182) You have given this money to me for this very purpose, and I thank you and the teachers for giving me this money thinking of the famishing millions of India.
('40', 365, 5, 20, 836340) To wear khaddar

('40', 366, 1, 2, 836405) is merely to follow up the step that you have taken today.

('40', 387, 1, 2, 890337) 262. READY MADE KHADI CLOTHES
('40', 387, 2, 3, 890367) A Parsi friend makes some suggestions about ready made khadi clothes which I expand as follows : Just as we have readymade khadi caps on the market, why not khadi vests and shirts both after the Indian and European styles?
('40', 387, 2, 4, 890590) Surely our khadi shopkeepers should be resourceful enough to find the different varieties of clothes that are sold readymade and to have them made of khadi.
('40', 387, 2, 5, 890747) The suggestion is worthy of consideration by khadi shops.
('40', 387, 2, 6, 890805) It will be one method of cheapening khadi and providing remu nerative employment for the town dweller.
('40', 387, 2, 7, 890908) If the khadi tailor has patriotism enough to take a trifle less than the market wage, the saving can go to reduce the price of khadi required for the articles.
('40', 387, 2, 8, 891068) Miss Mithubehn Petit has found out ingenious patterns which she works on khadi and charges prices which her chosen customers gladly pay for the knowledge that they are not only supporting khadi but also girls who might otherwise have been without such a clean method of earning livelihood as khadi work provides for them.
('40', 387, 2, 9, 891390) In Bihar and Tamil Nad, I saw tailors who were working exclusively on khadi.
('40', 387, 2, 10, 891467) There is no reason why even educated Indians should not go in for tailoring with a view to serving khadi at the same time that they may be serving themselves.
('40', 387, 2, 11, 891626) Young India, 17 11 1927
('40', 387, 3, 12, 891650) 263. SPEECH AT NEGOMBO
('40', 387, 4, 13, 891673) November 17, 1927
('40', 387, 5, 14, 891691) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I am deeply grateful to you for presenting me with this very beautiful and artistic address.
('40', 387, 5, 15, 891810) Ever since my arrival in your beautiful island I have been surrounded with affectionate attention in all quarters and you have but added to the same by bringing me to this picturesque place and presenting this address.
('40', 387, 5, 16, 892029) I hope that my countrymen who are living in your midst are living with you in peace and harmony.
('40', 387, 5, 17, 892126) And I suggest to you who are from India that you will consider yourselves representatives of India’s culture and tradition and live up to them.
('40', 387, 5, 18, 892270) I would ask you, inhabitants of this island, to bear with them as your next door neighbour, whenever you see shortcomings in them.
('40', 388, 0, 1, 892401) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 389
('40', 388, 1, 2, 892450) At the end of my talk I shall consider myself a happy and fortunate man if, as you have co operated and made my mission happy, so also you have lived in mutual co operation.
('40', 388, 1, 3, 892624) It does not surprise me in the least that you, the hospitable people of Ceylon, recognize the usefulness and necessity of my humble mission.
('40', 388, 1, 4, 892765) Indeed I would have been greatly surprised if you had not risen to the occasion and endeavoured to do your duty by responding to the dire call of millions and millions of the people who, everybody will admit, are living in a state of semi starvation.
('40', 388, 1, 5, 893016) I thank you once more for your address.

('40', 388, 2, 7, 893090) 264. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KURUNEGALA
('40', 388, 3, 8, 893132) November 17, 1927
('40', 388, 4, 9, 893150) Mr. Tambiraja had referred to the political situation of Ceylon, and his expectations from the Reform Commission.
('40', 388, 4, 10, 893264) If he [Gandhiji] expressed an opinion on the matter, he would be abusing the hospitality he had received.
('40', 388, 4, 11, 893370) He, however, expressed a wish that the expectations of the country would be fulfilled, and hoped that when the deliberations of the Royal Commission were over, their finding would be to the entire satisfaction of the people.
('40', 388, 5, 12, 893595) There was another question, he said, about which he could freely express himself.
('40', 388, 5, 13, 893677) That was with regard to temperance.
('40', 388, 5, 14, 893713) During the short time he had, he had made an attempt to gather some idea about the statistics and it was with great pain he discovered that Ceylon was no better off than her neighbours across the sea.
('40', 388, 5, 15, 893914) In his opinion one who was a slave to drink was no better than a beast.
('40', 388, 5, 16, 893986) He wished the Temperance Union in Ceylon every success, and he hoped that they would not be contented until Ceylon was entirely “dry”.
('40', 388, 5, 17, 894121) There was one other thing he wished to touch upon.
('40', 388, 5, 18, 894172) He had been informed that women belonging to certain castes in the island were not permitted to wear upper garments by those of higher castes.
('40', 388, 5, 19, 894315) He hoped that the ladies who were present would consider it a personal insult if any woman is prohibited from wearing whatever garment she desired.
('40', 388, 5, 20, 894463) In conclusion, he hoped that the people of this country would help their famishing neighbours in India by buying cloth turned out in India.

('40', 389, 1, 2, 894679) 265. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MATALE
('40', 389, 2, 3, 894717) November 18, 1927 I thank you for these addresses as also for the generous purses that you have presented to me.
('40', 389, 2, 4, 894830) You have in your addresses very kindly mentioned my wife also.
('40', 389, 2, 5, 894893) But I am very sorry to have to inform you that she is not with me this morning.
('40', 389, 2, 6, 894973) The fact is that we are not travelling in Ceylon to receive honours from you, but purely for the business which I have undertaken on behalf of the poor millions of India.
('40', 389, 2, 7, 895144) As a matter of fact, people have often, as a gentleman did last night, mistaken her for my mother.
('40', 389, 2, 8, 895243) For me, as for her also, I hope, it is not only a pardonable mistake, but a welcome mistake.
('40', 389, 2, 9, 895336) For years past, she has ceased to be my wife by mutual consent.
('40', 389, 2, 10, 895400) Nearly forty years ago I became an orphan, and for nearly thirty years she has been my mother, friend, nurse, cook, bottle washer and all these things.
('40', 389, 2, 11, 895552) If in the early hours of the day she had come with me to divide the honours, I should have gone without my food.
('40', 389, 2, 12, 895665) And nobody would have looked after my clothing and creature comforts.
('40', 389, 2, 13, 895735) So we have come to a reasonable understanding that I should have all the honours and she should have all the drudgery.
('40', 389, 2, 14, 895854) I assure you that some of the co workers will duly inform her of all the kind things that you have said about her and I hope that the explanation that I have tendered you will be accepted by you as sufficient excuse for her absence.
('40', 389, 2, 15, 896087) You will forgive me for having taken up so much of your time over a flimsy personal explanation, but if the men in front of me, and especially the women, will understand the serious side of the explanation and appreciate the secret of it I have no doubt that you will all be the happier for it.
('40', 389, 2, 16, 896382) I have no doubt that it is not necessary for me to draw the attention of a people whose country is dominated by the spirit of the Buddha to the fact that life is not a bundle of enjoyments and privileges, but a bundle of duties and services.
('40', 389, 2, 17, 896624) That which separates man from the beast is essentially man’s recognition of the necessity of putting a series of restraints on worldly enjoyment.
('40', 389, 2, 18, 896770) I am therefore surprised to find that in this land of Buddha people are given, as they are given in other parts of the country, to drink.
('40', 389, 2, 19, 896908) In studying the statistics of this island, I found that the drink
('40', 390, 0, 1, 896974) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 391
('40', 390, 1, 2, 897023) revenue was a substantial part of the general revenue.
('40', 390, 1, 3, 897078) I was still more shocked to discover that, unlike us in India, the drink habit did not carry with it a sense of shame and disrespectability.
('40', 390, 1, 4, 897219) You know that I belong to the country where Gautama was born, where he found his Enlightenment, and where he passed his life.
('40', 390, 1, 5, 897345) Whatever the Ceylonese scholars in Buddhism may say to the contrary, I want you to take it from me that this drink habit is totally against the spirit of the Buddha.
('40', 390, 1, 6, 897511) Because in this land, Hinduism, Christianity and Islam are represented in abundance, I tell you that in Hinduism drink is a sin; I know that it is equally held abominable in Islam.
('40', 390, 1, 7, 897692) I am sorry to confess that in Christian Europe drink is not considered disrespectable, but I am glad to be able to tell you that hundreds, if not thousands, whose friendship I have the privilege to enjoy, have assured me that this drink habit in Europe is entirely contrary to the spirit of Christ.
('40', 390, 1, 8, 897991) I am in close touch with Christian America.
('40', 390, 1, 9, 898035) You know how bravely these men in America are battling against the drink evil.
('40', 390, 1, 10, 898114) I would therefore respectfully urge you all, whether you are Buddhists or Hindus, Christians or Mussalmans, to unite together in making a supreme effort to rid this country of this drink curse.
('40', 390, 1, 11, 898308) Whatever may be said about the medical necessity of drink in cold climates, everyone is agreed that there is absolutely no occasion for drink in the climate of a temperate zone like this.
('40', 390, 1, 12, 898496) One of the things to which I would like to draw your attention is the existence of untouchability in the most liberal religion in the world Buddhism.
('40', 390, 1, 13, 898646) I wish you would take immediate steps to declare every man to be absolutely equal with the rest of you.
('40', 390, 1, 14, 898750) You are denying Buddhism, you are denying humanity, so long as you regard a single man as an untouchable.
('40', 390, 1, 15, 898856) Lastly, since you have been good enough to sympathize with my mission, I would ask you to broaden your sympathy by making your purchase of cloth in khadi alone, so long as your clothes are not manufactured in this beautiful island.
('40', 390, 1, 16, 899088) My barber friends have presented me with an address and a purse.
('40', 390, 1, 17, 899153) It is a manifestation from fellow workers of sympathy for the starving millions, which deeply touches me.
('40', 390, 1, 18, 899259) I would be happier if those, who have, will always think of those, who have not.
('40', 390, 1, 19, 899340) I thank you once more for the addresses and the purses.
('40', 390, 2, 20, 899396) With Gandhiji in Ceylon, pp.

('40', 391, 1, 2, 899467) 266. SPEECH AT DHARMARAJ COLLEGE, KANDY November 18, 1927
('40', 391, 2, 3, 899525) It has been my good fortune to feel at home and make myself at home wherever I have gone in any part of the world, and had I not been able to do so, probably I should have died long ago without having had to commit suicide.
('40', 391, 2, 4, 899749) But I feel doubly at home when I see my Parsi friends.
('40', 391, 2, 5, 899804) You cannot understand this really.
('40', 391, 2, 6, 899839) And you might also think that I am joking.
('40', 391, 2, 7, 899882) It is not joking.
('40', 391, 2, 8, 899900) It is serious, because of my having been in closest association with Parsis in South Africa and in India, and having had personally nothing but treasures of love from them.
('40', 391, 2, 9, 900073) Even now you do not know, of course, but it gives me great pleasure to own before you that some of my best workers are Parsis, and they are those three grand daughters of the Grand Old Man of India.
('40', 391, 3, 10, 900272) But I must not detain you on my personal and family affairs.
('40', 391, 3, 11, 900333) I thank you very much for this purse and I like this opportunity of having come to you.
('40', 391, 4, 12, 900421) As I told the boys of the Trinity College a little while ago, your education is absolutely worthless if it is not built on a solid foundation of truth and purity.
('40', 391, 4, 13, 900584) If you, boys, are not careful about the personal purity of your lives and if you are not careful about being pure in thought, speech, and deed, then I tell you that you are lost, although you may become perfect finished scholars.
('40', 391, 5, 14, 900814) I have been asked to draw your attention to one thing.
('40', 391, 5, 15, 900869) Purity consists first of all in possessing a pure heart, but what there is in the heart really comes out also and is shown in outward acts and outward behaviour.
('40', 391, 5, 16, 901031) And a boy who wants to keep his mouth pure will never utter a bad word.
('40', 391, 5, 17, 901103) Of course, that is quite clear.
('40', 391, 5, 18, 901135) But he neither will put anything into his mouth that will cloud his intellect, cloud his mind and damage his friends also.
('40', 391, 5, 19, 901258) I know that there are boys who smoke, and in Ceylon perhaps you are as bad as they are in Burma, though boys are becoming bad everywhere so far as this wretched habit of smoking is concerned.
('40', 391, 5, 20, 901450) And of course, Parsis as you know, are called or rather miscalled, fire worship pers.
('40', 391, 5, 21, 901536) They are no more fire worshippers than you and though they see God through that great manifestation the Sun which is nothing but the God of Fire.
('40', 392, 0, 1, 901682) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 393
('40', 392, 1, 2, 901731) Some of you good Parsis never smoke, and you make it a point, whenever you have a number of boys in your care, to train the boys not to foul their mouths by smoke.
('40', 392, 2, 3, 901895) If any of you are smoking, you will henceforth give up that bad habit.
('40', 392, 2, 4, 901966) Smoking fouls one’s breath.
('40', 392, 2, 5, 901994) It is a disgusting habit.
('40', 392, 2, 6, 902020) When he is in a railway carriage, the smoker never cares whether there are ladies or men sitting about him who never smoke, and that the stench that comes out from his mouth may be disgusting to them.
('40', 392, 3, 7, 902221) The cigarette might be a small thing from a distance, but when the cigarette smoke goes into one’s mouth and then comes out, it is poison.
('40', 392, 3, 8, 902360) Smokers do not care where they spit.
('40', 392, 4, 9, 902397) Here Gandhiji related a story from Tolstoy to explain how the tobacco habit was more disastrous in its effects than drink and proceeded :
('40', 392, 5, 10, 902535) Smoking clouds one’s intellect, and it is a bad habit.
('40', 392, 5, 11, 902590) If you ask doctors, and they happen to be good doctors, they will tell you that smoke has been the cause of cancer in many cases, or at least that smoke is at the bottom of it.
('40', 392, 6, 12, 902767) Why smoke, when there is no necessity for it?
('40', 392, 6, 13, 902813) It is no food.
('40', 392, 6, 14, 902828) There is no enjoyment in it except in the first instance through suggestion from outside.
('40', 392, 7, 15, 902918) You, boys, if you are good boys, if you are obedient to your teachers and parents, omit smoking and whatever you save out of this, please send on to me for the famishing millions of India.

('40', 396, 0, 1, 910984) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 397
('40', 396, 1, 2, 911033) You may not all know that nearly a generation of my life has been passed either in the midst of labourers or in closest contact with them and nothing would have given me greater pleasure than to have passed a few days in your midst, understanding your wants and aspirations, but I hope that the cause which prevents me from doing so will be accepted as sufficient excuse for my not coming in your midst and living with you for a time.
('40', 396, 1, 3, 911468) The cause is that I am travelling just now as a self appointed representative of millions in India who are infinitely worse off than any of you here.
('40', 396, 1, 4, 911618) It is for their sake that these purses, that you have seen presented to me, have been given.
('40', 396, 1, 5, 911711) Every rupee of this purse will go to find employment in their own huts for 16 women, at least per day.
('40', 396, 1, 6, 911814) These are men and women who cannot afford, even if they semi starve, to leave their own homes, huts and fields.
('40', 396, 1, 7, 911926) Out of the moneys that are being collected throughout the year nearly every year 50,000 women are being supported in their own homes through the spinning wheel industry.
('40', 396, 1, 8, 912096) Behind these spinners, several thousand weavers, dyers, printers, washermen and others are also being supported, who, but for this revival of spinning, would have been without any work.
('40', 396, 1, 9, 912282) This work is being done through the agency of an all India organization called the All India Spinners’ Association which contains several self sacrificing men, either sons of millionaires or of proved merit and integrity.
('40', 396, 1, 10, 912504) Whilst for this cause I gladly collect sums from moneyed men, it gives me great joy to be able to collect also from poor men like those of you who are sitting in front of me.
('40', 396, 1, 11, 912679) Every cent, every anna received from a willing heart is just as welcome as the rupee or ten rupee note received from a rich man.

('40', 398, 1, 3, 916079) Well, the spinning wheel has a message for all this class of people.
('40', 398, 1, 4, 916148) To the starving man or woman who has no work possibly for him or her to do, the spinning wheel says : ‘Spin me and you will at least find a crust of bread for yourself.’ That is its economic message, but it has also a cultural message for one and all.
('40', 398, 1, 5, 916400) The spinning wheel says culturally to you and to me : ‘Seeing that there are millions on the face of this earth who are compulsorily idle for want of work, and since I am the only instrument that can be placed in their hands without taking work away from a single mouth, will you not spin me for the sake of these millions and produce an atmosphere of honest industry, honest work and self reliance and hope for all on God’s earth?’ That is the cultural message the spinning wheel addresses to all people of the earth, no matter to what country, religion or race they belong.
('40', 398, 1, 6, 916976) I assure you that slowly but surely this cultural appeal of the spin ning wheel is finding a lodgment in the remotest corners of the earth.

('40', 398, 1, 8, 917223) And I assure well to do men and women of Ceylon that if they will accept the cultural message of the spinning wheel and try to make at least some part of their own clothing they will find themselves, at the end of the task, much taller than they are today.
('40', 398, 1, 9, 917480) The spinning wheel has a third message which is metaphorical.
('40', 398, 1, 10, 917542) It stands for simple life and high thinking.
('40', 398, 1, 11, 917587) It is a standing protest against the modern mad rush for adding material comfort upon comfort and making life so complicated as to make one totally unfit for knowing one’s self or one’s God.
('40', 398, 1, 12, 917778) It says appealingly every minute of our life to you and to me : ‘Use me and you will find that if all of you unitedly make use of me, small and insignificant though I may appear, I shall be an irresistible force against the mad, indiscriminate worship of the curse called machinery.’ It is a standing rebuke to the men and women of Ceylon who go in for all kinds of fashions and styles and it tells them : ‘Do not for the sake of your country ape the manners and customs of others which can only do harm to you and for heaven’s sake do not wish to be what every one of the people of Ceylon cannot be.’

('40', 406, 1, 6, 936353) I hope that whilst the friends are making their collections no noise will be made, but please preserve silence while I speak, for I want to make a personal appeal to labourers whom I see in front and behind me from neighbouring estates surrounding this beautiful hill.
('40', 406, 1, 7, 936622) I want you, the labourers, to understand that I am but one of you and have been casting my lot with you ever since my visit to South Africa nearly 30 years ago.
('40', 406, 1, 8, 936783) I want you to realize and recognize your own dignity as men and women.
('40', 406, 1, 9, 936854) Do not despise yourselves or allow others to despise you because you are labourers.
('40', 406, 1, 10, 936938) There never was and never is shame in honest labour.
('40', 406, 1, 11, 936991) Without the existence of labour around these hills, their present condition would have been utterly impossible, but there are some well defined conditions attached to your dignity, if you will preserve it.
('40', 406, 1, 12, 937197) The first and foremost is that you must not go near the liquor shops.
('40', 406, 1, 13, 937267) Drink is a devil in whose net you must not find yourselves.
('40', 406, 1, 14, 937327) A man who comes under the influence of drink forgets the distinction between his wife and sisters.
('40', 406, 1, 15, 937426) You should therefore, if you have not already given up, make a sacred resolve that you will not pollute your lips by the touch of that cursed water, but if after having fed and clothed yourselves and your families, you have got some money to lay by, keep it for a better purpose, keep it for educating your children, keep it for a rainy day when your hands and your feet can no longer work and the time comes for you to rest.
('40', 406, 1, 16, 937852) All these savings would come in useful to you and I would ask you to use a portion of the same for people much poorer than yourselves in the name of God.
('40', 406, 1, 17, 938006) I know also that many of you are not leading pure lives.
('40', 407, 0, 1, 938063) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 407, 1, 2, 938105) wrong to live an impure life.
('40', 407, 1, 3, 938135) God has made man so that he of all beings on earth can distinguish between women who are his sisters, daughters, mother and wife.
('40', 407, 1, 4, 938265) Refuse to live under conditions which will make it impossible for you to live a life of discipline, purity and restraint.

('40', 407, 1, 14, 939538) I know positively that this disease is due only to filth.
('40', 407, 1, 15, 939596) The letter that I have received says that there are some remedies which are quite good and if there are such, you can certainly resort to them, but the better thing is to prevent the disease, seeing that it is so easily preventible and the chief thing is to regulate your sanitary life.
('40', 407, 1, 16, 939883) Your methods of sanitation are not of the best kind, I am sorry to confess.
('40', 407, 1, 17, 939959) I know that if planters will take proper measures to teach you sanitation, they will be doing their duty to themselves, to you and to humanity.

('40', 407, 1, 19, 940195) If you will only understand and learn the elementary lessons in sanitation and if you do not pollute the water which you drink by washing or dirtying it, you will never get hook worm.

('40', 412, 1, 2, 947057) He gave them a picture of the starving millions, and said : When Mahendra came to Ceylon the children of the motherland were not starving either materially or spiritually, our star was in the ascendant and you partook of the glory.

('40', 413, 3, 7, 950240) 280. SPEECH AT ZAHIRA COLLEGE, COLOMBO November 22, 1927 It has indeed given me great pleasure to be able to visit this College.
('40', 413, 3, 8, 950369) You have reminded me of the happy days I spent in South Africa.
('40', 413, 3, 9, 950433) Those were days when my life was almost wholly cast in the midst of my Mussalman countrymen and it was early in 1893 that I found myself in the company of some of the finest Mussalmans it has been my good fortune to meet, as also to influence.
('40', 413, 3, 10, 950677) It therefore does not surprise me that you have invited me to meet you in this hall.
('40', 413, 3, 11, 950762) Maulana Shaukat Ali when he returned from Ceylon gave me what he said was a message from the Mussalmans of Ceylon to hasten to Ceylon as soon as possible.
('40', 413, 3, 12, 950917) But the work in which both he and I were engaged made it impossible for me to come here at that time.
('40', 413, 3, 13, 951019) Those of you who are in the habit of reading Indian newspapers will know that just before I embarked for Colombo I had the pleasure of meeting the professors and boys of the Jamia College at Delhi.
('40', 413, 3, 14, 951217) I have not got the time to give you a set speech, because there are other appointments waiting for me, but I would summarize the speech 1 I gave to the boys in Delhi.
('40', 413, 3, 15, 951384) All the education that you are receiving in this great College will be reduced to nothing if it is not built on the foundation of a pure character.
('40', 413, 3, 16, 951532) As I was reading your magazines I could not help admiring the zeal with which the work was done here and the marvellous progress that has been made in a few years.

('40', 414, 1, 4, 952178) It cannot be built by other hands than your own.
('40', 414, 1, 5, 952227) The Principal and the professors cannot give you character from the pages of books.
('40', 414, 1, 6, 952311) Character building comes from their very lives and, really speaking, it must come from within yourselves.

('40', 414, 3, 19, 953742) 281. SPEECH TO PARSIS, COLOMBO November 22, 1927 You have apologized for your inability to present me with a proper address.
('40', 414, 3, 20, 953867) Your address is written on your hearts which you have laid bare before me.
('40', 414, 3, 21, 953942) A strange relationship binds me to the Parsis.
('40', 414, 3, 22, 953989) The affection they have showered on me, a Hindu, wherever I have come in contact with them is something inexplicable and impregnable.
('40', 414, 3, 23, 954123) Wherever I have gone Parsis have not failed to find me out.
('40', 414, 3, 24, 954183) When scarcely anyone knew me, when the burden of Mahatmaship
('40', 415, 0, 1, 954244) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 415, 1, 2, 954286) had not yet been imposed on me, a Parsi befriended me and made me his own.
('40', 415, 1, 3, 954361) I refer to the late Parsee Rustomji of South African fame.
('40', 415, 1, 4, 954420) When the South African Europeans mobbed and lynched me on my landing at Durban in 1896 Parsee Rustomji harboured me and my family at grave risk to his person and property.
('40', 415, 1, 5, 954592) The mob threatened to burn his house, but nothing daunted Rustomji who gave us shelter under his roof.
('40', 415, 1, 6, 954695) Ever since, throughout his lifelong friendship with me he helped me and my movements and in 1921 his was the biggest donation to the Tilak Swaraj Fund from an Indian abroad.
('40', 415, 1, 7, 954869) Mr. (afterwards Sir) Ratan Tata sent me a cheque for Rs. 25,000 when I most needed it during the satyagraha in South Africa.
('40', 415, 1, 8, 954994) And Dababhai Naoroji.
('40', 415, 1, 9, 955016) How can I describe my debt to him?
('40', 415, 1, 10, 955051) He took me to his bosom when I was an unknown and unbefriended youth in England, and today his grand daughters are a tower of strength to me in my khadi work.
('40', 415, 1, 11, 955210) I ask you to continue the tradition of your forefathers, I ask you not to forget their simplicity and their frugal ways by aping the showy fashion of the West.
('40', 415, 1, 12, 955370) Your community has been known throughout the world for its charity, and luxury loving ease and extravagance go ill together with charity.
('40', 415, 1, 13, 955508) I am glad to find that you here have retained some of your simplicity and your Indian ways.
('40', 415, 1, 14, 955600) You are known for your business capacity and your people have made fortunes wherever they have gone.

SPEECH TO CEYLON NATIONAL CONGRESS, COLOMBO November 22, 1927 I thank you for the words that you have spoken about myself, and I thank you also for the pleasant reminder that you have given me of the ancient times when the connection between India and Ceylon was established.
('40', 415, 3, 19, 956160) I do not propose, however, to take up your time by giving my own views upon what that connection means to India, means to you, and shall I say to the world.
('40', 415, 3, 20, 956317) But I will say this that in my opinion the teaching of Gautama Buddha was not a new religion.
('40', 415, 3, 21, 956411) In so far as I have been able to study those lofty teachings, I have come to the conclusion—and that conclusion I arrived long before
('40', 416, 0, 1, 956545) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 417
('40', 416, 1, 2, 956594) now—that Gautama was one of the greatest of Hindu reformers, and that he left upon the people of his own time and upon the future generations an in delible impress of that reformation.
('40', 416, 1, 3, 956779) But it would be wrong on my part to take up your time and my own, limited as it is, to consider that very fascinating subject.
('40', 416, 1, 4, 956906) I therefore come to mundane matters relating to the Congress.
('40', 416, 1, 5, 956968) In India the Congress is a word to conjure with.
('40', 416, 1, 6, 957017) It is an association with an unbroken record of over 40 years.
('40', 416, 1, 7, 957080) And it enjoys today a reputation which no other political association in India enjoys, and that is, in spite of the many ups and downs which the Congress in common with all worldly institutions and associations has gone through.
('40', 416, 1, 8, 957309) I therefore take it for granted that in adopting this name you are also, as far as may be and is necessary, following the traditions of the parent body if I may call the National Congress of India by that name.
('40', 416, 1, 9, 957520) And on that assumption I venture this afternoon to place before you my views of what a Congress should be, or how the National Congress in India has been able to build up its reputation.
('40', 416, 1, 10, 957707) I know that after all my connection with the Congress in India does not stretch over a period longer than 10 years—or I may now say, more accurately speaking, 12 years.
('40', 416, 1, 11, 957876) But as you are aware that 12 years’ association is so close, and I have been so much identified with the Congress that probably what I may say might be taken with some degree of authority.
('40', 416, 1, 12, 958065) But in one way my association with the parent body is nearly 30 years old now.
('40', 416, 1, 13, 958144) It was in South Africa in the year 1893 when I went there that I dreamt about the Congress.
('40', 416, 1, 14, 958236) I knew something about its activities, though I had never attended a single one of the annual sessions of that great institution.
('40', 416, 1, 15, 958366) Just like you, as a youngster, I took my proper share in founding an association called the Natal Indian Congress after the fashion of the Indian National Congress, making such changes as were necessary to suit the local conditions.
('40', 416, 1, 16, 958599) I shall therefore be able to give you the results of my experience of public life in connection with such institutions dating back to 1893. And what I learnt even so early as 1894 was that any such association, to be really serviceable, to deserve the name of being called ‘national’, requires a fair measure— I was going to say a great measure—of self sacrifice on the part of the principal workers.
('40', 416, 1, 17, 959000) I have no hesitation in confessing to you that that ideal I found to be very difficult to put into practice even in that little community, because we were after all a very small body of men and women in Natal, which is the smallest province of South Africa, where
('40', 417, 0, 1, 959264) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 417, 1, 2, 959306) we had a population of nearly 60 thousand Indians of whom the vast majority had no vote in the deliberations of the Congress.
('40', 417, 1, 3, 959432) The Congress however was a representative institution and fully representative of things that interested the people, because it constituted itself the trustee of the welfare of those men.
('40', 417, 1, 4, 959620) But I must not linger over the history of that institution.
('40', 417, 1, 5, 959680) Even in that small body we found bickerings and a desire more for power than for service, a desire more for self aggrandizement than for self effacement, and I have found during my 12 years’ association with the parent body also that there is a continuous desire for self seeking and self aggrandizement; and for you as for us who are still striving to find our feet, who have still to make good the claims for self expression and self government, self sacrifice, self effacement, and self suppr ession are really absolutely necessary and indispensable for our existence and for our progress.
('40', 417, 1, 6, 960273) I do not profess to have studied your politics during the brief stay that I have made here, I do not know the internal working of this organization, I do not know how strong it is, and how popular it is.
('40', 417, 1, 7, 960477) I only hope it is strong and is popular.
('40', 417, 1, 8, 960518) I hope you are free the blemishes that I have just mentioned.
('40', 417, 1, 9, 960580) It is, I know, a pleasurable pastime (and I have indulged in it sufficiently as you know) to strive against the powers that be, and to wrestle with the government of the day, especially when that government happens to be a foreign government and a government under which we rightly feel we have not that scope which we should have, and which we desire, for expansion and fullest self expression.
('40', 417, 1, 10, 960976) But I have also come to the conclusion that self expression and self government are not things which may be either taken from us by anybody or which can be given us by anybody.
('40', 417, 1, 11, 961153) It is quite true that if those who happen to hold our destinies, or seem to hold our destinies in their hands, are favourably disposed, are sympathetic, understand our aspirations, no doubt it is then easier for us to expand.

('40', 418, 0, 1, 961896) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 419
('40', 418, 1, 2, 961945) means that are required for individual self government or self rule, and so as you know also, I have striven in India to place this ideal before the people, in season and out of season, very often much to the disgust of those who are merely politically minded.
('40', 418, 1, 3, 962206) I belong to that body of political thought which was dominated by Gokhale.

('40', 422, 1, 6, 973030) There is in India an association called the All India Spinners’ Association.

('40', 422, 1, 16, 973974) Whereas before the advent of the spinning wheel, they had no work whatsoever to do for four months in the year, now since the advent of the spinning wheel, they got between one and two annas per day whilst they are working the wheel.

('40', 423, 1, 2, 974595) reclaimed, as also dhobis, whose special function is to wash such khadi, dyers, printers, and traders.

('40', 433, 3, 10, 1000025) 290. SPEECH AT YOUNG MEN’S BUDDHIST ASSOCIATION, COLOMBO
