('40', 433, 5, 12, 1000100) At the outset Gandhiji pleaded for toleration.
('40', 433, 5, 13, 1000147) He did not claim to be a scholar in any sense of the term.
('40', 433, 5, 14, 1000206) His first introduction to any religious study was through a single book, viz, Sir Edwin Arnold’s The Light of Asia, which fascinated and engrossed him.
('40', 433, 5, 15, 1000358) Ever since, the spirit of Buddha had haunted him, so much so that he had been accused of being a Buddhist in disguise.
('40', 433, 5, 16, 1000477) And as he had said on a previous occasion he accepted the accusation as a compliment though he knew that if he made any such claim it would be summarily rejected by orthodox Buddhists.
('40', 433, 5, 17, 1000662) As one, however, who had imbibed the spirit of Buddhism, he would reassert in all humility, but unhesitatingly, if in a different language, what he said on the previous occasion: There are some conditions laid down in Hinduism for a proper prayerful study of religions.
('40', 433, 5, 18, 1000932) They are of a universal character.
('40', 433, 5, 19, 1000967) Remember also that Gautama was a Hindu of Hindus.
('40', 433, 5, 20, 1001017) He was saturated with the spirit of Hinduism, with the Vedic spirit, he was born and bred up in those exhilarating surroundings, exhilarating for the spirit, and so far as I am aware, he never rejected Hinduism, or the message of the Vedas.
('40', 433, 5, 21, 1001258) What he did was therefore to introduce a living reformation in the petrified faith that surrounded him.
('40', 433, 5, 22, 1001362) I venture to suggest to you that your study of Buddhism will be incomplete unless you study the original sources from which the Master derived his inspiration, that is, unless you study Sanskrit and the Sanskrit scriptures.
('40', 433, 5, 23, 1001586) But your duty, if you are to understand the spirit of the Buddha and not the letter of Buddhism, does not end there.
('40', 433, 5, 24, 1001703) That study has those conditions which I am about to describe to you.
('40', 433, 5, 25, 1001772) Those conditions are that a man or a woman who approaches a study of religion has first of all to observe what are called the five yamas.
('40', 434, 0, 1, 1001910) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 435
('40', 434, 1, 2, 1001959) are the five rules of self restraint and I will repeat them before you.
('40', 434, 1, 3, 1002031) First, brahmacharya, celibacy; the second is satya, truth; the third is ahimsa, absolute innocence, not even hurting a fly; the next condition is asteya, non stealing, not merely not stealing in the ordinary sense in which the word is understood, but if you appropriate or even cast your greedy eyes on anything that is not your own, it becomes stealing.
('40', 434, 1, 4, 1002386) Lastly, aparigraha—a man, who wants to possess worldly riches or other things, won’t be fit really to understand the spirit of the Buddha.
('40', 434, 1, 5, 1002525) These are the indispensable conditions.
('40', 434, 1, 6, 1002565) There are other conditions, but I am going into these because these are the fundamental ones, and Gautama before he attained his knowledge had conformed to all these rules, and conformed, as few of his contemporaries had ever done, to the spirit of those rules.
('40', 434, 1, 7, 1002827) I humbly suggest to you that you will not understand the spirit of the Buddha unless you have also yourselves conformed to these rules and then prayerfully tried to ascertain what the Master meant.
('40', 434, 1, 8, 1003025) It makes no difference that you know of him through all the books that have been written, but even these very books, I make bold to assure you, you will understand and you will interpret with a new light, immediately you have gone, first of all, through these preliminary observances.
('40', 434, 1, 9, 1003310) Look what many critics of Islam have done—how they have torn the very book, that millions of Mussalmans swear by, to pieces and held up the teachings of Islam to scorn.
('40', 434, 1, 10, 1003479) They were not dishonest men who wrote this criticism, they were honest men, they were not men who were not trying to search the truth, but they did not know the conditions that they had to fulfil before they could make any religious study.
('40', 434, 1, 11, 1003719) Again look at what the critics of Hinduism have done.
('40', 434, 1, 12, 1003773) I read many of those criticisms, trying to enter into the spirit of the critics but came to the conclusion that they did not know the A B C of Hinduism and that they were grossly misinterpreting Hinduism.
('40', 434, 1, 13, 1003978) Take Christianity itself.
('40', 434, 1, 14, 1004004) Many Hindus have misinterpreted Christianity.
('40', 434, 1, 15, 1004050) They approach the Bible, the Old Testament and the New Testament in a carping spirit, with preconceived notions.

('40', 437, 2, 5, 1010195) Their welfare must be our primary concern.
('40', 437, 2, 6, 1010238) Our own must be subordinate to theirs.
('40', 437, 2, 7, 1010277) That seems to be the only line consistent with dignity, and it follows along the lines of the great teaching that we should do unto others as we wish that they should do unto us.
('40', 437, 2, 8, 1010456) Thinking along these lines, as you know, I have repeatedly suggested to Englishmen in India that they should subordinate their own interests to the interests of the teeming millions of the country in which they are living, and nobody has questioned the propriety of that statement.
('40', 437, 2, 9, 1010738) There cannot be one law to govern the relations between ourselves and foreigners who come to our land and another law governing us when we go to another foreign land.
('40', 437, 2, 10, 1010905) And though I consider that Ceylon is not a foreign land and though it has given me the greatest pleasure to hear from the lips of the Sinhalese that they own India as their mother country, it is much better, when we wish to regulate our relations with them, that we regard them as foreigners.
('40', 437, 2, 11, 1011198) The safest rule of conduct is to claim kinship when we want to do some service and not to insist upon kinship when it is a matter of asserting a right.
('40', 437, 2, 12, 1011350) Indeed, I have applied this rule of life, which I call the golden rule of conduct, between communities and communities even in provincial inter relations in India.
('40', 437, 2, 13, 1011514) For instance, whenever I have gone to Bengal or to Madras or to any other province but Gujarat, and wherever I have seen Gujarati settlements, I have not hesitated to submit to the Gujaratis that they must consider the welfare of the people of the province to which they go superior to their own.
('40', 437, 2, 14, 1011811) I know of no other method of preserving sweet relations in human affairs and I am fortified by my experience extending for a long period of years that wherever there has been an interruption in the observance of this golden rule which I have submitted to you, there have been bickerings and quarrels and even the breaking of heads.

('40', 448, 3, 5, 1037795) 295. SPEECH TO STUDENTS’ CONGRESS, JAFFNA November 26, 1927 I thank you for the beautiful address that you have presented to me this evening.
('40', 448, 3, 6, 1037937) You have taken upon yourselves, and very rightly, the credit of bringing me to this fair island, but you must remember also that those who take credit for anything have also to take discredit if any mishap occurs.
('40', 448, 3, 7, 1038151) It is very difficult for me this evening to give you a message for the simple reason that I do not know your Congress sufficiently, nor do I know sufficiently the composition of my audience but your worthy Chairman has informed me of the objects of your Congress.
('40', 448, 3, 8, 1038415) I shall try to give you some thoughts that occur to me on some of those objects.
('40', 448, 3, 9, 1038496) If I understand him rightly, your first object is to revive ancient culture.
('40', 448, 3, 10, 1038573) You have then to understand what that ancient culture is and it must be necessarily culture which all students, whether they are Hindus, Christians, Buddhists or to whatever faith they belong, would be interested in reviving, because I take it that by ancient culture you do not want to confine yourselves purely to Hindu students.
('40', 448, 3, 11, 1038905) I take it that this Students’ Congress includes all students, Hindus, Christians, Muslims and Buddhists.
('40', 448, 3, 12, 1039010) Though today it has on its rolls no Muslim student or Buddhist student, it does not much matter for my argument for the simple reason that your ultimate object is attainment of swaraj, not merely for the Hindus and Christians of Jaffna, but for all the inhabitants of this island of which Jaffna is but a part.
('40', 448, 3, 13, 1039321) What I have said with reference to the inclusion of students belonging to these religions must hold good.
('40', 448, 3, 14, 1039427) That being so, we hark back to the question, what ancient culture it is we want to revive.
('40', 448, 3, 15, 1039518) It must, therefore, be such as to be common to all these elements and such as to be acceptable to all these elements.
('40', 448, 3, 16, 1039636) Therefore, whilst that culture will undoubtedly be predominantly Hindu culture, it can never be exclusively Hindu.
('40', 448, 3, 17, 1039751) The reason why I say that it must be predominantly Hindu is because you who are seeking to revive ancient culture are predominantly Hindu,

('40', 449, 1, 2, 1039932) and are all the while thinking of that country which you rightly and proudly delight to call your motherland.

('40', 449, 1, 4, 1040229) I have never seen anything in the life of Gautama to warrant the belief that he renounced Hinduism and adopted a new faith.

('40', 449, 1, 12, 1041546) He also said that a prudent man would not swear by anything because it was ancient, but he told the audience that any culture ancient or modern, must be submitted to the test of reason and experience.

('40', 449, 1, 14, 1041960) I see from my own experience in India that many who are professing to revive ancient culture do not hesitate under the name of that revival to revive old superstitions and prejudices.

('40', 450, 1, 7, 1043615) So I came by a process of examination to this irresistible conclusion that there was nothing so very ancient in this world as these two good old things—truth and non violence—and arguing along these lines of truth and non violence, I also discovered that I must not attempt to revive ancient practices if they were inconsistent with, call it if you will, modern life as it must be lived.
('40', 450, 1, 8, 1044003) Ancient practices may have been perfectly good and perhaps abso lutely necessary at the time when those practices were adopted but they might be entirely out of date with modern needs and still not be contrary to truth or non violence.

('40', 453, 3, 9, 1050314) 298. DISCUSSION WITH CHRISTIAN MISSIONARIES, JAFFNA 1
('40', 453, 4, 10, 1050368) November 27, 1927
('40', 453, 5, 11, 1050386) W. A. Kathirgamer asked what would be the religious future of India and the share that Christianity would take in it and what Gandhiji wished it to be.
('40', 453, 6, 12, 1050538) Mahatmaji replied that the first question was beyond his capacity to answer.
('40', 453, 6, 13, 1050615) The second question he could.
('40', 453, 6, 14, 1050645) For years past his wish had been that all religions should flourish in India in their true light, because he did not consider any one religion to be exclusively true.
('40', 453, 6, 15, 1050812) That being his position and having a tolerant nature all through his life, he had no like or dislike.
('40', 453, 6, 16, 1050914) He endorsed the appeal made by the Dewan of Mysore to missionaries and Mussalmans who believed in conversion to make the untouchables better Hindus.
('40', 453, 6, 17, 1051063) He thought that if all men belonging to the different great faiths became better by contact with one another the world would be a much better place to live in.
('40', 453, 6, 18, 1051223) So long as there were different points of view they would have large classifications such as Christianity, Islam, and Hinduism and in all of these religions no two persons thought alike.
('40', 453, 6, 19, 1051410) If, however, they examined the religion of .
('40', 453, 6, 20, 1051455) the respective parties from their own standpoints all should agree quickly.
('40', 453, 6, 21, 1051531) He did not expect the India of his dream to develop one religion only, but expected it to be respectful to all faiths working side by side without exciting the slightest suspicion on jealousy which he noticed even in Jaffna.
('40', 453, 7, 22, 1051756) J. Bicknell asked : “You have been working towards Hindu Muslim unity in India.
('40', 453, 7, 23, 1051836) Is there any likelihood of unity among them?”
('40', 453, 8, 24, 1051882) MAHATMAJI : O yes.
('40', 453, 8, 25, 1051901) Most decidedly.
('40', 453, 9, 26, 1051917) BICKNELL : The one is a cow worshipper and the other is a cow eater; the one is an idol worshipper and the other is an idol breaker?
('40', 453, 10, 27, 1052050) Mahatma Gandhi admitted that there were differences on the surface and as he was a bit of a cook he knew what happened when he took dirty salt and a bit of dirty sugar.
('40', 453, 10, 28, 1052219) Put them in the melting pot and add a little water.
('40', 453, 10, 29, 1052271) All the dirt would come up to the surface; and if he were an unskilled cook he would come to the conclusion that it was all dirt and therefore in his impatience he would throw it away; but being fairly a
('40', 453, 11, 30, 1052475) 1 At the Missionary Conference
('40', 454, 0, 1, 1052506) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 455
('40', 454, 1, 2, 1052555) skilled cook he knew that the dirt should be easily removed from the surface and that pure crystals of salt and sugar could be separated.
('40', 454, 1, 3, 1052693) So it was with Hindus and Mussalmans.
('40', 454, 1, 4, 1052731) Today they were fighting like dogs, he might say, but they were fighting only to come together and they were fighting really not because one was an idol worshipper and the other an idol breaker, because the one was cow eater and the other was a cow worshipper; but it was the mutual fear which was working upon them and mutual distrust which was always the first born of fear.
('40', 454, 1, 5, 1053108) That was what was happening today and unfortunately both the communities were ill advised and both had forgotten the fundamental precepts of their respective faiths.
('40', 454, 1, 6, 1053274) The Hindu had undoubtedly forgotten the principle of ahimsa, although he was never tired of saying “ahimsa paramo dharmah”.
('40', 454, 1, 7, 1053398) The Mussalmans seemed to think that in Islam there was ample room for violence as there was for non violence, but when he cross questioned his Mussalman friends they had stated that non violence was always the law, but if they could not be non violent, then it was permissible to be violent.
('40', 454, 1, 8, 1053690) In any case therefore non violence was really common between the two.

('40', 455, 2, 4, 1055765) 299. SPEECH AT INDIANS’ MEETING, JAFFNA November 27, 1927 Ever since I have come to Lanka the conviction has been growing upon me that I am not in Lanka but in India glorified.
('40', 455, 2, 5, 1055942) A glorified edition of India Lanka certainly is from a scenic point of view.
('40', 455, 2, 6, 1056019) Though I was prepared for the scenery in Lanka, the scenery I have actually witnessed has surpassed all my expectations and so I could not help saying at a recent meeting that Ceylon seemed to be a fragrant, beautiful pearl dropped from the nasal ring of India.
('40', 455, 2, 7, 1056281) If the people of Lanka are really, as they should be, inheritors of this culture of India, they also should represent in their lives a glorious edition of mother India.
('40', 455, 2, 8, 1056450) After all, was not Gautama Buddha one of the greatest of Hindu reformers?
('40', 455, 2, 9, 1056524) And why should not the people of Lanka who have inherited and adopted the teachings of the great Master do better than the children of the motherland?
('40', 455, 2, 10, 1056675) today the source from which the strength of Lanka was derived in the days of your seems almost to have dried up.
('40', 455, 2, 11, 1056788) We of India seem at the present moment to have fallen on evil days.
('40', 455, 2, 12, 1056856) We are ourselves struggling for our very existence, so much so that according to English historians at least one tenth of the population of India is living in a state of perpetual starvation.
('40', 455, 2, 13, 1057048) It is in order to remove the sting of this growing, grinding pauperism that I have been ceaselessly wandering from place to place, exciting the sympathy of moneyed people on behalf of these men and women who do not know what a full meal can be.
('40', 455, 2, 14, 1057293) And it has been a matter of the greatest consolation, indeed, a sense that sustains me in spite of darkness surrounding us on all sides, that wherever I go I receive a ready response from our countrymen.
('40', 455, 2, 15, 1057497) It causes me, therefore, no surprise that you have brought me here to meet you and given me your tangible sympathy.
('40', 455, 2, 16, 1057613) But you do not need to be told by me that the sympathy that you have given me in the shape of money is by no means enough.
('40', 455, 2, 17, 1057736) I can only take it as a token of your desire to render still more help, and therefore I must repeat for the thousandth time what I have been saying to every
('40', 456, 0, 1, 1057893) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 457
('40', 456, 1, 2, 1057942) audience, that you will not have done your elementary duty by these famishing brothers and sisters of ours unless you follow up your donations by a fixed determination never more to make your cloth purchases in anything but khadi.
('40', 456, 1, 3, 1058173) And the sisters who are also to be found in this hall must really help and respond to the dumb appeal of the famishing millions.
('40', 456, 1, 4, 1058302) Neither they nor the men may contemptuously tell me that khadi is too dear, that khadi is not fine enough, that it does not satisfy their taste.
('40', 456, 1, 5, 1058447) I have not yet heard a single mother to complain of the want of beauty of her children nor have I ever heard a mother complain that her children were a burden upon her purse.
('40', 456, 1, 6, 1058622) If you really feel for these famishing millions, if you really believe that they are famishing and that they are your own blood brothers and blood sisters, how can you complain of the price or quality of khadi?
('40', 456, 1, 7, 1058833) What right have you to think of fashion or of prices when you find that there are millions of people hungry for food and can be fed by you if only you will wear khadi which is manufactured by their sacred but shaking hands?
('40', 456, 1, 8, 1059057) Will you not take a leaf out of the book of Englishmen and Germans who taxed themselves, suffered untold privations and suffered all kinds of difficulties, including death, under circumstances too terrible to relate, and all for what they believed to be the honour of their country?
('40', 456, 1, 9, 1059340) How much more then should you deprive yourselves of your manufactured tastes and notions about fashionable dress and pay a little higher price for khadi when it is not merely the honour of your sisters which is at stake but when it is their very existence which is in danger.

('40', 456, 1, 15, 1060321) You must be in the midst of such people as trustees of your own culture, and you should make common cause with those people alike in their joys as well as their sorrows.

('40', 457, 1, 2, 1060562) 300. SPEECH TO CEYLON HINDUS, JAFFNA November 27, 1927 This is the last of a series of many meetings, whose number even I cannot now remember, that I have been addressing today.
('40', 457, 1, 3, 1060740) 1 Precious as all of them have been, this to me is the most precious, because you have conceived a meeting of Hindus specially to be addressed by me.
('40', 457, 1, 4, 1060890) This I take to mean that I must speak to you Hindus as a Hindu.
('40', 457, 1, 5, 1060954) And it gives me the greatest pleasure to have been invited to do so.
('40', 457, 1, 6, 1061023) As you know, though my claim has not been accepted by those who call themselves orthodox Hindus I persist in calling myself an orthodox Hindu.
('40', 457, 1, 7, 1061166) But by making that claim I, a votary of Truth, must not mislead you in any way whatsoever.
('40', 457, 1, 8, 1061257) If orthodox Hinduism consists in dining or not dining with this man or that man, and touching this man and not touching that man, or in quarrelling with Mussalmans and Christians, then I am certainly not an orthodox Hindu.
('40', 457, 1, 9, 1061480) But if orthodox Hinduism can mean an incessant search after what Hinduism possibly can be, if orthodox Hinduism can mean an incessant striving to live Hinduism to the best of one’s lights, then I do claim to be an orthodox Hindu.
('40', 457, 1, 10, 1061710) I am also an orthodox Hindu in the sense in which the author of the Mahabharata, the great Vyasa, would have it.
('40', 457, 1, 11, 1061823) He has said somewhere in the Mahabharata to this effect : Put Truth in one scale and all sacrifices whatever in the other; that scale which contains Truth will outweigh the one that contains all the sacrifices put together, not excluding rajasuya 2 and ashvamedha yajna 3. And if the Mahabharata may be accepted as the fifth Veda, then I can claim to be an orthodox Hindu, because every moment of the twenty four hours of my life I am endeavouring to follow truth counting no cost as too great.
('40', 457, 1, 12, 1062318) Having thus registered my claim in the presence of this audience, I now wish to tell you as an orthodox Hindu what in my humble opinion your duty is in Jaffna, and in Ceylon.
('40', 457, 1, 13, 1062493) First of all I want to speak to you about your duty towards the predominant population in this island.
('40', 457, 1, 14, 1062596) And I wish to suggest to you that they are
('40', 457, 2, 15, 1062639) 1 Gandhiji had addressed nine gatherings before this meeting.
('40', 457, 2, 16, 1062701) 2 A great sacrifice performed by an emperor (in which the tributory princes also took part) at the time of his coronation as a mark of his undisputed sovereignty 3 A sacrifice in which the wanderings of a sacrificial horse established the extent of the jurisdiction of a conquering king
('40', 458, 0, 1, 1062988) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 459
('40', 458, 1, 2, 1063037) your co religionists.
('40', 458, 1, 3, 1063059) They will, if they choose to, repudiate the claim.
('40', 458, 1, 4, 1063110) For they will say that Buddhism is not Hinduism and they will be partly right.
('40', 458, 1, 5, 1063189) Many Hindus certainly repudiate the claim of Buddhism to be part and percel of Hinduism.
('40', 458, 1, 6, 1063278) On the contrary, they delight in saying that they successfully drove Buddhism out of India.
('40', 458, 1, 7, 1063370) But I tell you that they did nothing of the kind.
('40', 458, 1, 8, 1063420) Buddha himself was a Hindu.
('40', 458, 1, 9, 1063448) He endeavoured to reform Hinduism.
('40', 458, 1, 10, 1063483) And he succeeded in his attempt to a very great extent and what Hinduism did at that time was to assimilate and absorb all that was good and best in the teachings of the Buddha.
('40', 458, 1, 11, 1063661) And on that account I ventured to say that Hinduism became broadened, and having assimilated the best of Buddhism, it is true that Hinduism drove out from India what might be termed the excrescences that had gathered round the teachings of Gautama.
('40', 458, 1, 12, 1063910) And the way in which you can demonstrate this to the Buddhists of Ceylon is by living the broadened Hinduism in their midst.
('40', 458, 1, 13, 1064035) The one thing that the Buddha showed India was that God was not a God who can be appeased by sacrificing innocent animals.
('40', 458, 1, 14, 1064158) On the contrary, he held that those who sacrificed animals in the hope of pleasing God were guilty of a double sin.
('40', 458, 1, 15, 1064274) So if you will be true to Hinduism, you will take care that you will not defile a single temple of yours by indulging in animal sacrifice.
('40', 458, 1, 16, 1064413) I am prepared to declare against the whole of Hindu India that it is wrong, sinful and cirminal to sacrifice a single animal for the purpose of gaining any end whatsoever, or for the purpose of propitiating God.
('40', 458, 1, 17, 1064625) The second thing that Gautama taught was that all that caste means today—as it meant in his time also—was wholly wrong.
('40', 458, 1, 18, 1064745) That is to say, he abolished every distinction of superiority and inferiority that was even in his time eating into the vitals of Hinduism.
('40', 458, 1, 19, 1064885) But he did not abolish varanashrama dharma.
('40', 458, 1, 20, 1064929) Varna dharma is not caste.
('40', 458, 1, 21, 1064956) As I have said in so many speeches in South India, and as I have written fairly exhaustively on varna dharma in Young India, I hold that there is nothing in common between caste and varna.
('40', 458, 1, 22, 1065145) Whilst varna gives life, caste kills it, and untouchability is the most hateful expression of caste.
('40', 458, 1, 23, 1065246) You will therefore banish untouchability from your midst.
('40', 458, 1, 24, 1065304) I make bold to say that there is no warrant whatsoever in Hinduism for untouchability as it is practised today.
('40', 458, 1, 25, 1065416) If therefore you want to live your Hinduism in its purity in the midst of Buddhist countrymen, you will take care that you will not consider a single human being as an untouchable.
('40', 458, 1, 26, 1065597) Unfortunately the Buddhists in Ceylon have themselves borrowed this curse from Hindus.
('40', 458, 1, 27, 1065684) They should never have had this
('40', 459, 0, 1, 1065716) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 459, 1, 2, 1065758) institution of caste in their midst.
('40', 459, 1, 3, 1065795) For heaven’s sake forget that some are high but others are low; remember that you are all Hindus— brothers in arms.
('40', 459, 1, 4, 1065911) I have a letter from a Jaffna Hindu telling me that there are some temples in this place where you have dances by women of ill fame on certain occasions.
('40', 459, 1, 5, 1066065) If that information is correct, then let me tell you that you are converting temples of God into dens of prostitution.
('40', 459, 1, 6, 1066184) A temple, to be a house of worship, to be a temple of God, has got to conform to certain well defined limitations.
('40', 459, 1, 7, 1066299) A prostitute has as much right to go to a house of worship as a saint.
('40', 459, 1, 8, 1066370) But she exercises that right when she enters the temple to purify herself.
('40', 459, 1, 9, 1066445) But when the trustees of a temple admit a prostitute under cover of religion or under cover of embellishing the worship of God, then they convert a house of God into one of prostitution.
('40', 459, 1, 10, 1066632) And if anybody no matter how high he may be comes to you and seeks to justify the admission of women of ill fame into your temples for dancing or any such purpose, reject him and agree to the proposal that I have made to you.

('40', 459, 1, 14, 1067224) There are still certain things that demand your attention.

('40', 464, 6, 9, 1075229) 308. SPEECH AT ST.
('40', 464, 6, 10, 1075248) JOHN COLLEGE, JAFFNA November 29, 1927 If you had been looking forward to meeting me under this roof, I can say that I was no less looking forward to meeting you.
('40', 464, 6, 11, 1075411) Though I receive, and receive with thankfulness, money from millionaires, it is a source of much greater plesure to me to receive small gifts, no matter how small they may be, from boys and girls who are sitll making their lives.
('40', 464, 6, 12, 1075641) It gives me greater pleasure for two reasons.
('40', 464, 6, 13, 1075687) One is, the gift that spring from innocent boys and girls fructifies much more than gifts of those who may be considered worldly wise men.
('40', 464, 6, 14, 1075826) The second reason is that gifts such as yours give me a keener sense of responsibility that perhaps I should otherwise have.
('40', 464, 7, 15, 1075951) I have not the power to make any return for your kindness and your generosity.
('40', 464, 7, 16, 1076030) I can only pray to God that He may bless you for all the good things that you may do in life.
('40', 464, 7, 17, 1076124) I know that mere mental training is nothing if it is not accompanied by a true training of the heart.
('40', 464, 7, 18, 1076226) And may your heart extend in the manner that your minds may.
('40', 464, 7, 19, 1076287) I thank you once more.

('40', 465, 0, 1, 1076752) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 465, 1, 2, 1076794) you have repeated this morning 1 .
('40', 465, 1, 3, 1076829) I have many engagements between now and 10.30; therefore, and also for other reasons into which I do not want to enter, I would fain have avoided this question.
('40', 465, 1, 4, 1076990) But on the principle that has guided my life that I must take things as they come to me, unless I find it utterly impossible for me to cope with them, I propose to devote the very few minutes that I have at my disposal to answer that question.
('40', 465, 1, 5, 1077234) I say in one sentence that for many many years I have regarded Jesus of Nazareth as one amongst the mighty teachers that the world has had, and I say this in all humility.
('40', 465, 1, 6, 1077406) I claim humility for this expression for the simple reason that this is exactly what I feel.
('40', 465, 1, 7, 1077499) Of course, Christians claim a higher place for Jesus of Nazareth than as a non Christian and as a Hindu I have been able to feel.
('40', 465, 1, 8, 1077629) I purposely use the word ‘feel’ instead of ‘give’, because I consider that neither I, nor anybody else can possibly arrogate to himself the claim of giving place to a great man.
('40', 465, 1, 9, 1077807) The great teachers of mankind have had the place not given to them, but the place has belonged to them as a matter of right, as a matter of service that have rendered, but it is given to the lowest and the humblest amongst us to feel certain things about certain people.
('40', 465, 1, 10, 1078078) The relation between great teachers and ourselves is somewhat after the style of relation between a husband and wife.
('40', 465, 1, 11, 1078196) It would be a most terrible thing, a tragic thing, if I was to argue out intellectually for myself what place I was to give to my wife in my heart.
('40', 465, 1, 12, 1078344) It is not in my giving, but she takes the place that belongs to her as a matter of right in my heart.
('40', 465, 1, 13, 1078446) It is a matter purely for feeling.
('40', 465, 1, 14, 1078481) Then I can say that Jesus occupies in my heart the place of one of the great teachers who has had considerable part in finding that place in my heart.
('40', 465, 1, 15, 1078632) Leave the Christians alone for the present.
('40', 465, 1, 16, 1078676) I shall say to the 75 per cent Hindus receiving instruction in this College that your lives will be incomplete unless you reverently study the teaching of Jesus.
('40', 465, 1, 17, 1078838) I have come to the conclusion, in my own experience, that those who, no matter to what faith they belong,reverently study the teaching of other faiths broaden their own, instead of slackening their hearts.
('40', 465, 1, 18, 1079044) Personally, I do not regard any of the great religions of the world as false.
('40', 465, 1, 19, 1079122) All have served in embellishing mankind and are even now serving their purpose.

('40', 474, 3, 15, 1100724) 315. HINDU MUSLIM UNITY
('40', 474, 4, 16, 1100748) Dr. Ansari told me when I was recently in Delhi that he heard in Calcutta from reliable men that I had lost faith and interest in Hindu Muslim unity and that I was avoiding Mussalman friends such as the Ali Brothers.
('40', 474, 4, 17, 1100965) Dr. Ansari therefore proposed that in order to dispel any illusion and disarm suspicion, I should make a declaration of my faith before a public meeting in Delhi.
('40', 474, 4, 18, 1101128) I could not accept the proposal if only because the old Delhi of Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan and Swami Shraddhanandji had become the new Delhi of hooligans where it was difficult for me to stay and much more so to address public meetings.
('40', 474, 4, 19, 1101362) I however promised Dr. Ansari that I would clear my position as early as I could through these pages.
('40', 474, 4, 20, 1101464) This I do now.
('40', 474, 4, 21, 1101479) My interest and faith in Hindu Muslim unity and unity among all the communities remain as strong as ever.
('40', 474, 4, 22, 1101585) My method of approach has changed.
('40', 474, 4, 23, 1101620) Whereas formerly I tried to achieve it by addressing meetings, joining in promoting and passing resolutions now I have no
('40', 475, 0, 1, 1101742) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('40', 479, 2, 3, 1110709) APPENDIX I BRAHMIN NON BRAHMIN QUESTION 1
('40', 479, 3, 4, 1110751) [A CATECHISM]
('40', 479, 4, 5, 1110765) During Gandhiji’s tour in South India Non Brahmin friends in various places sought interviews with him, and discussed the various aspects of the Brahmin Non Brahmin question.
('40', 479, 4, 6, 1110940) The same questions were often asked at various places, but the scope of the answers depended on the receptivity of the questioners at each place.
('40', 479, 4, 7, 1111086) I have brought all of them together, and arranged them in the form of a catechism.
('40', 479, 4, 8, 1111169) This covers all the talks in Tanjore, Chettinad, Virudhunagar and Tinnevelly.
('40', 479, 4, 9, 1111247) I was not present during the conversations at Madura, but I think the collected talks will cover the topics discussed there also.
('40', 479, 4, 10, 1111377) I omit, of course, the references to the question in public speeches at Cuddalore, Tanjore and Coimbatore which I have already given in these pages, and I omit also talks already summarized, as for instance the one at Tirupur on superiority and inferiority.
('40', 479, 4, 11, 1111635) —MAHADEV DESAI
('40', 479, 5, 12, 1111650) CLEAR THE ISSUE
('40', 479, 6, 13, 1111666) GANDHIJI : I want you to make your position clear to me, as I do not want to be told that I refuse to try to understand or sympathize with your viewpoint.
('40', 479, 6, 14, 1111821) The impression left on my mind is that the real cause of the movement is political.
('40', 479, 7, 15, 1111905) NON BRAHMIN FRIEND : The movement is older than the exponents of its political aspect.
('40', 479, 7, 16, 1111992) There is the social and the religious aspect as well.
('40', 479, 8, 17, 1112046) A CHRISTIAN FRIEND : The rise of the Justice Party is due to the feeling that the Brahmins have a monopolizing tendency and hence cannot be trusted.
('40', 479, 8, 18, 1112195) I am speaking in reference only to the South Indian Brahmins of today.
('40', 479, 9, 19, 1112266) [At this stage there were swift questions and answers.
('40', 479, 9, 20, 1112321) I summarize below Gandhiji’s replies only.—MAHADEV DESAI]
('40', 479, 10, 21, 1112379) GANDHIJI : But should you not in considering the question consider the course that Brahminism has taken in North India?
('40', 479, 10, 22, 1112499) In North India whatever status a Brahmin enjoys has been given him by the Non Brahmins.
('40', 479, 10, 23, 1112587) He has no independent status.
('40', 479, 10, 24, 1112617) In fact the consideration in North and West India is not whether a particular leader is a Brahmin or a Non Brahmin, but whether he can lead.

('40', 480, 1, 2, 1113109) respected by the Brahmins as by Non Brahmins.
('40', 480, 2, 3, 1113155) In South India you seem to have divided Hinduism not only into two camps, but divided India into Brahmins and Non Brahmins, which term may include Mussalmans and Christians as well.
('40', 480, 2, 4, 1113337) Now I want you to have a clear cut crystallized notion of your own aims and ideals.

('40', 480, 5, 21, 1115189) THE LAW OF VARNA
('40', 480, 6, 22, 1115206) QUESTION : We do not understand your emphasis on varnadharma.
('40', 480, 6, 23, 1115268) Can you justify the present caste system?
('40', 480, 6, 24, 1115310) What is your definition of varna?
('40', 480, 7, 25, 1115344) ANSWER : Varna means pre determination of the choice of man’s profession.
('40', 480, 7, 26, 1115418) The law of varna is that a man shall follow the profession of his ancestors for earning his livelihood.
('40', 480, 7, 27, 1115522) Every child naturally follows the ‘colour’ of his father, or chooses his father’s profession.
('40', 480, 7, 28, 1115616) Varna therefore is in a way the law of heredity.
('40', 480, 7, 29, 1115665) Varna is not a thing that is superimposed on Hindus, but men who were trustees for their welfare discovered the law for them.
('40', 480, 7, 30, 1115791) It is not a human invention, but an immutable law of nature—the statement of a tendency that is ever present and at work like Newton’s law of gravitation.
('40', 480, 7, 31, 1115946) Just as the law or gravitation existed even before it was discovered so
('40', 481, 0, 1, 1116018) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 481, 1, 2, 1116060) did the law of varna.
('40', 481, 1, 3, 1116082) It was given to the Hindus to discover that law.
('40', 481, 1, 4, 1116131) By their discovery and application of certain laws of nature, the peoples of the West have easily increased their material possessions.
('40', 481, 1, 5, 1116267) Similarly, Hindus by their discovery of this irresistible social tendency have been able to achieve in the spiritual field what no other nation in the world has achieved.
('40', 481, 2, 6, 1116438) Varna has nothing to do wish caste.
('40', 481, 2, 7, 1116474) Caste is an excrescence, just like un touchability, upon Hinduism.
('40', 481, 2, 8, 1116541) All the excrescences that are emphasized today were never part of Hinduism.
('40', 481, 2, 9, 1116617) But don’t you find similar ugly excrescences in Christianity and Islam also?
('40', 481, 3, 10, 1116694) Fight them as much as you like.
('40', 481, 3, 11, 1116726) Down with the monster of caste that masquerades in the guise of varna.
('40', 481, 3, 12, 1116797) It is this travesty of varna that has degraded Hinduism and India.
('40', 481, 3, 13, 1116864) Our failure to follow the law of varna is largely responsible both for our economic and spiritual ruin.
('40', 481, 3, 14, 1116968) It is one cause of unemployment and impoverishment, and it is responsible for untouchability and defections from our faith.
('40', 481, 4, 15, 1117092) But in quarrelling with the present monstrous form, and monstrous practices to which the original law has been reduced, do not fight the law itself.
('40', 481, 5, 16, 1117241) Q. How many varnas are there?
('40', 481, 6, 17, 1117271) A. Four varnas, though it is not a rigid division inherent in varna itself.
('40', 481, 6, 18, 1117347) The rishis after incessant experiment and research arrived at this fourfold division—the four ways of earning one’s livelihood.
('40', 481, 7, 19, 1117475) Q. Logically, therefore, there are as many varnas as there are professions?
('40', 481, 8, 20, 1117551) A. Not necessarily.
('40', 481, 8, 21, 1117571) The different professions can easily be brought under the four main divisions—that of teaching, of defending, of wealth producing, and of manual service.
('40', 481, 8, 22, 1117725) So far as the world is concerned, the dominant profession is the wealth producing, just as grihasthashrama is the most dominant amongst all ashramas.
('40', 481, 8, 23, 1117875) Vaisya is the keynote among the varnas.
('40', 481, 8, 24, 1117915) The defender is not wanted if there is no wealth and property.
('40', 481, 8, 25, 1117978) The first two and the foruth are necessary because of the third.
('40', 481, 8, 26, 1118043) The first will always be very few because of the severe discipline required for it, the second must be few in well ordered society, and so the fourth.

('40', 493, 7, 8, 1147085) APPENDIX III INTERVIEW TO C. KUTTAN NAIR 1
('40', 493, 8, 9, 1147128) October 4, 1927
('40', 493, 9, 10, 1147144) Mr. T. K. Madhavan has received a wire 2 today from Gandhiji asking him to start civil disobedience in regard to the ban on untouchables in regard to the use of Thiruvarppu temple roads.
('40', 493, 10, 11, 1147331) Mr. C. Kuttan Nair, a co worker of Mr. Madhavan, interviewed Gandhiji this morning at Virudhunagar in regard to the Thiruvarppu temple roads questions.
('40', 493, 10, 12, 1147483) Mahatma Gandhi went through all the papers which Mr. Kuttan Nair submitted .
('40', 493, 10, 13, 1147560) and after ascertaining the real facts .
('40', 493, 11, 14, 1147600) From the facts before me, I have no hesitation in saying that a very strong case has been made out for starting satyagraha in the matter of opening out the roads to the avarna Hindus in Thiruvarppu.
('40', 493, 12, 15, 1147799) Asked whether by satyagraha he meant that form that was adopted at Vaikom, he said emphatically “No”.
('40', 493, 12, 16, 1147901) He said it should be comprehensive enough to include all
('40', 493, 13, 17, 1147958) 1Vide “Speech at Trivandrum”, 10 10 1927. 2 Not available
('40', 494, 0, 1, 1148016) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 495
('40', 494, 1, 2, 1148065) forms of civil disobedience.
('40', 494, 1, 3, 1148094) He said he was even for mass civil disobedience at Thiruvarppu, provided there is an atmosphere of non violence.
('40', 494, 1, 4, 1148207) Failure on the part of the Travancore Government to follow up the Vaikom settlement in logical way resulted in the present muddle and that, he said, would strengthen the demand for temple entry for avarnas.
('40', 494, 1, 5, 1148414) “Yes”, he said, “temple entry is coming.”
('40', 494, 2, 6, 1148456) Gandhiji promised to try to visit Thiruvarppu on his way to Ernakulam.
('40', 494, 3, 7, 1148527) The Hindu, 6 10 1927
('40', 494, 4, 8, 1148548) APPENDIX IV INTERVIEW WITH SHRI SHANKARACHARYA OF KANCHI 1
('40', 494, 5, 9, 1148607) In the latter half of 1927, Mahatma Gandhi was touring the South to popularize Congress objectives and collect funds.
('40', 494, 5, 10, 1148725) Gandhiji, who had already heard about the Acharya through Mr. A. Rengaswamy Iyengar, Manager, The Hindu, and Mr. S. Satyamurti, decided to call on him.
('40', 494, 5, 11, 1148877) The historical meeting took place on October 15,1927 in a cattle shed adjoining the Acharya’s camp at Nellicheri in Palghat.
('40', 494, 5, 12, 1149002) Only a few persons were present, but no Press reporter.
('40', 494, 6, 13, 1149058) Gandhiji paid his respects to the Acharya in the traditional Hindu style.
('40', 494, 6, 14, 1149132) The overwhelming saintliness of the sannyasi, clad in ochre coloured khadi and seated on the floor, made a deep impression on Gandhiji mind.
('40', 494, 6, 15, 1149273) A spell of silence ensued.
('40', 494, 6, 16, 1149300) Then the Acharya spoke a few words in Sanskrit by way of welcome and asked him to be seated.
('40', 494, 6, 17, 1149393) Gandhiji sat down and said that he was not used to speaking in Sanskrit, but could understand the language somewhat, and wanted permission to speak in Hindi.
('40', 494, 6, 18, 1149551) Since the Acharya could understand Hindi, this arrangement suited both.
('40', 494, 6, 19, 1149623) Gandhiji spoke in Hindi and the Acharya in Sanskrit.
('40', 494, 7, 20, 1149676) The Acharya expressed appreciation of Gandhiji’s efforts to spiritualize politics, since healthy national life should be based on spiritual foundations and nations devoid of religion and dependent on materialistic forces were bound to perish.
('40', 494, 7, 21, 1149919) On the question of temple entry for Harijans the Acharya thought that it might amount to a form of himsa to wound the feelings of those who still believed in the supremacy of Shastras and tradition.
('40', 494, 7, 22, 1150118) The discussion continued on spiritual matters; it was open hearted and reflected mutual regard.
('40', 494, 7, 23, 1150214) There was no disputation or polemics.
('40', 494, 8, 24, 1150252) The conversation went on for about an hour.
('40', 494, 8, 25, 1150296) On taking leave, Gandhiji said that he was immensely benefited by this visit, and that he would keep the Acharya’s wishes in mind and fulfil them to the best of the capacity.
('40', 494, 9, 26, 1150471) 1 Vide second footnote to “Conversation with Depressed Classes Deputations”, October 15, 1927.
('40', 495, 0, 1, 1150566) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 495, 1, 2, 1150608) As Gandhiji would take no food after 6 p.m., Mr. C. Rajagopalachari went and reminded him about his meal at 5.30 p.m.
('40', 495, 1, 3, 1150726) But Gandhiji said : “This talk with the Acharya is my food for the day.” Then the Acharya offered to Gandhiji a big citrus fruit which he gladly accepted, saying he had a special liking for the fruit.
('40', 495, 2, 4, 1150927) Later at a public meeting held at Coimbatore the same evening, when Gandhiji was questioned about his discussion with the Acharya, he said that it was private and confidential and hence Press reporters were kept out.
('40', 495, 3, 5, 1151144) [From Tamil]
('40', 495, 4, 6, 1151157) Shri Jagadguru Divya Charitram, pp.
('40', 495, 5, 7, 1151193) APPENDIX V GANDHI IRWIN INTERVIEW 1
('40', 495, 7, 8, 1151229) When he saw the Viceroy, the interview was a cold affair.
('40', 495, 7, 9, 1151287) Lord Irwin placed in his hands the Secretary of State’s announcement regarding the Simon Commission, and when asked whether that was all the business, Lord Irwin said “Yes”.
('40', 495, 7, 10, 1151461) Gandhiji felt that a one anna envelope would have reached it to him.
('40', 495, 8, 11, 1151530) The History of the Indian National Congress, Vol. I (1885 1935), p.
('40', 495, 9, 12, 1151598) In fact, Gandhi and Irwin had a long conversation at this first meeting at which they listened to one another with exemplary patience and courtesy.
('40', 495, 9, 13, 1151746) Gandhi was in good humour .
('40', 495, 9, 14, 1151774) promising to convert the Viceroy to khaddar.
('40', 495, 9, 15, 1151819) 2 He listened to Irwin attentively, and, after he had finished, developed his own general political philosophy at length.
('40', 495, 9, 16, 1151941) He saw no need for British tutelage.
('40', 495, 9, 17, 1151978) He was prepared to wait indefinitely rather than ask India to impair the self respect she ought to have.
('40', 495, 9, 18, 1152083) Parliament, he said, should give India what India desired.
('40', 495, 9, 19, 1152142) Therefore he felt remote from all these things.
('40', 495, 9, 20, 1152190) Congress was trying to serve an idea—the idea of non co operation which would ultimately impress itself upon the mind of Parliament, Communalism would pass; the communities had been trying to absorb India.
('40', 495, 10, 21, 1152396) It was Irwin’s experience of the Mahatma’s incoherent political technique.
('40', 495, 10, 22, 1152471) He found him vague .
('40', 495, 10, 23, 1152492) but without bitterness, and in conversation pleasantly reasonable.
('40', 495, 10, 24, 1152559) But there was little in his .
('40', 495, 10, 25, 1152589) discourse on which the Viceroy’s practical mind could take hold.
('40', 495, 10, 26, 1152654) Only when Gandhi and the others said that they attached
('40', 495, 11, 27, 1152710) 1 On 2 11 1927; vide “Letter to C. F. Andrews”, 11 11 1927. 2 Vide “Letter to Lord Irvin”, 26 4 1928.
('40', 496, 0, 1, 1152812) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 497
('40', 496, 1, 2, 1152861) little importance to the procedure by which the representatives from the Indian Legislature would be invited to confer with the English Parliamentary Committee did Irwin seize the chance of telling them sharply that if they refrained from availing themselves of this opportunity, they would be committing a political blunder of the first magnitude and would hopelessly prejudice British opinion against their case.
('40', 496, 2, 3, 1153276) Halifax : The Life of Lord Halifax, p.
('40', 496, 3, 4, 1153315) III It is believed in certain quarters that His Excellency the Viceroy was prompted by a mandate from Whitehall that India should accept as fait accompli an absolutely parliamentary Commission consisting of representatives of all British political Parties; and that those who might prove to be pestilential agitators should be told beforehand that the Government would stand no more bluff and nonsense.
('40', 496, 3, 5, 1153718) Indians will, however, be associated in the work of the Commission in the capacity of assessors.
('40', 496, 3, 6, 1153815) Even in regard to the selection of assessors the communal clamour will be heard; but this can be silenced by appointing only official Indians as assessors.
('40', 496, 3, 7, 1153971) This is believed to be the substance of the Viceroy’s lecture.
('40', 496, 3, 8, 1154034) Mr. Gandhi said that such a Commission would be a failure as self respecting Indian opinion could not but resent such deliberate insult.
('40', 496, 3, 9, 1154171) It can lead only to boycott of the Commission.
('40', 496, 3, 10, 1154218) However, to him, and to those of his way of thinking the Commission was not of any consequence, however well composed it might be and however liberal its terms of reference.
('40', 496, 3, 11, 1154392) Asked if he would advise his countrymen, particularly the Swarajists, to co operate with the Commission in its investigation, Mr. Gandhi said that it was none of his business.
('40', 496, 3, 12, 1154568) He was not prepared to induce anybody to co operate with the Commission.
('40', 496, 3, 13, 1154641) The Swarajists were all veterans in political warfare and not children to be dictated to.
('40', 496, 3, 14, 1154731) Mr. Gandhi, however, assured His Excellency that he would not himself initiate a movement for boycott of the Commission as he had long since abdicated the political functions of leadership to the Swarajists.
('40', 496, 3, 15, 1154939) Mr. Gandhi, in conclusion, said that he would not—as indeed he could not—prevent anyone from participating in the work of the Commission.
('40', 496, 4, 16, 1155077) The Hindu, 9 11 1927
('40', 496, 5, 17, 1155098) APPENDIX VI EXTRACT FROM S. D. NADKARNI’S LETTER 1
('40', 496, 6, 18, 1155149) What varna nearly always has been is the artificially maintained, hard and fast division, otherwise called ‘caste’.
('40', 496, 6, 19, 1155265) Be it fourfold, as it was ‘once upon a time’, or
('40', 496, 7, 20, 1155314) 1 Vide ‘Varnashrama and Its Distortion’ 17 11 1927.
('40', 497, 0, 1, 1155366) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('40', 497, 1, 2, 1155408) forty thousand fold, as it is today, it is in essence the same.
('40', 497, 1, 3, 1155472) It is a system of monopolies and restraints distributed according to mere birth.
('40', 497, 1, 4, 1155553) Now, Mahatmaji, if you and I will be true Hindus, and not ‘Vaishya’ and ‘Brahmin’ only—for I own to ‘Brahmin’ parentage—then we are bound to worship the memory of Shambuka, the ‘Sudra’ ascetic of Rama’s days, as the oldest asserter of religious freedom we know, and the first martyr on record in India or perhaps the whole world.
('40', 497, 1, 5, 1155883) Mahatmaji, are you prepared to do that with me?
('40', 497, 1, 6, 1155931) Thus only may the sting be taken out of the anti Brahmin agi tation, and a united Hinduism arise out of the ashes of this age old struggle.
('40', 497, 1, 7, 1156071) I say, let Shambuka be vindicated, if Hinduism is to live yet and prosper.
('40', 497, 2, 8, 1156146) If it were so, all Gandhis should stick to grocery and Ramanama, and never—take to social and political reform of their country, unless perhaps, after finishing the householder’s life, they have formally entered upon the fourth ashrama at the prescribed age.
('40', 497, 2, 9, 1156405) Else, it would be trenching upon “the spiritual” of Brahmins and Kshatriyas for a Vaisya to take to politics!
('40', 497, 2, 10, 1156515) But would it be a salutary rule?
('40', 497, 2, 11, 1156548) And how stands the law of heredity?
('40', 497, 3, 12, 1156584) If we but think over it, it will be clear as daylight that we have overdone the principle of heredity by investing it with tyrannous sanctions in the name of religion.
('40', 497, 4, 13, 1156752) Just as you of Vasya parentage hold the Vaisyas as a class responsible for the economic downfall of India, so I who happen to be Brahmin by birth have no hesitation in declaring that the Brahmins as a class are responsible for the enslavement, both spiritual and economic, of all India.
('40', 497, 4, 14, 1157039) From those to whom much was given, much was expected.
('40', 497, 4, 15, 1157093) But alas, a narrow bigotry born of a short sighted selfishness stood in the way of their giving of their best to the community.
('40', 497, 4, 16, 1157221) And great has been the fall of all Brahminists, and with them of the Brahmins.

('40', 497, 6, 18, 1157324) APPENDIX VII EXTRACT FROM STATEMENT BY THE VICEROY ON THE INDIAN STATUTORY COMMISSION 1
('40', 497, 7, 19, 1157412) November 8, 1927
('40', 497, 8, 20, 1157429) When the Commission has reported and its report has been examined by the Government of India and His Majesty’s Government, it will be the duty of the latter to present proposals to Parliament.
('40', 497, 8, 21, 1157622) But it is not the intention of His Majesty’s Government to ask Parliament to adopt these proposals without first giving a full opportunity for Indian opinion of different schools to contribute its view upon them.
('40', 497, 9, 22, 1157835) 1 Vide “Interview to the Associated Press”, 1 12 1927.
('40', 498, 0, 1, 1157890) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 499
('40', 498, 1, 2, 1157939) And to this end it is intended to invite Parliament to refer these proposals for consideration by a Joint Committee of both Houses, and to facilitate the presentation to that Committee both of the view of the Indian Central Legislature by delegations who will be invited to attend and confer with the Joint Committee, and also of the views of any other bodies whom the Joint Parliamentary Committee may desire to consult.
('40', 498, 2, 3, 1158361) In the opinion of His Majesty’s Government the procedure contemplated fulfils to a very great extent the requisites outlined above.
('40', 498, 2, 4, 1158493) Such a Commission, drawn from men of very British political party and presided over by one whose public position is due to outstanding ability and character, will evidently bring fresh, trained, and unaffected judgment to bear upon an immensely complex constitutional issue.
('40', 498, 2, 5, 1158768) Moreover, the findings of some of its own members can count in advance upon a favourable reception at the hands of Parliament, which will recognize them to speak from a common platform of thought, and to be applying standards of judgment which Parliament will feel instinctively to be its own.
('40', 498, 2, 6, 1159062) For myself I cannot doubt that the quickest and surest path of those who desire Indian progress is by the persuasion of Parliament, and that they can do this more certainly through members of both Houses of Parliament than in any other way.
('40', 498, 2, 7, 1159303) The Indian nationalist has gained much if he can convince Members of Parliament on the spot, and I would therefore go further and say that if those who speak for India have confidence in the case which they advance on her behalf, they ought to welcome such an opportunity being afforded to as many members of the British Legislature as may thus to come into contact with the realities of Indian life and politics.
('40', 498, 2, 8, 1159717) Furthermore, while it is for these reasons of undoubted advantage to all who desire an extension of the Reforms that their case should be heard in the first instance by those who can command the unquestioned confidence of Parliament, I am sanguine enough to suppose that the method chosen by His Majesty’s Government will also assure to Indians a better opportunity than they could have enjoyed in any other way of influencing the passage of these great events.
('40', 498, 2, 9, 1160179) For not only will they, through representatives of the Indian Legislatures, be enabled to express themselves freely to the Commission itself, but it will also be within their power to challenge in detail or principle any of the proposals made by His Majesty’s Government before the Joint Select Committee of Parliament, and to advocate their own solutions.
('40', 498, 2, 10, 1160536) It should be observed moreover that at this stage Parliament will not have been asked to express any opinion on particular proposals and therefore, so far as Parliament is concerned, the whole field will still be open.
('40', 498, 3, 11, 1160755) Viceroy and Governor General
('40', 498, 4, 12, 1160784) India in 1928 29, pp.

('40', 499, 1, 2, 1160848) APPENDIX VIII THE INDIAN STATUTORY COMMISSION 1
('40', 499, 2, 3, 1160896) Whereas We have deemed it expedient that the Commission for which provision is made in Section 84A of the Government of India Act should forthwith be appointed for the purpose of inquiring into the working of the system of government, the growth of education, and the development of representative institutions, in British India, and matters connected therewith, and should report as to whether and to what extent it is desirable to establish the principle of responsible government, or to extend, modify or restrict the degree of responsible government then existing therein, including the question whether the establishment of second chambers of the local legislature is or is not desirable :
('40', 499, 3, 4, 1161591) Now know ye that We, reposing great trust and confidence in your knowledge and ability, have on the advice of Our Secretary of State for India acting with the concurrence of both Houses of Parliament authorized and appointed, and do by these presents authorize and appoint you, the said Sir John Allsebrook Simon (Chairman); Harry Lawson Webster, Viscount Burnham; Donald Sterling Palmer, Baron Strathcona and Mount Royal; Edward Cecil George Cadogan; Stephen Walsh 2; George Richard Lane Fox and Clement Richard Attlee to be Our Commissioners for the purposes aforesaid.
('40', 499, 4, 5, 1162163) And for the better effecting the purposes of this Our Commission, We do by these presents give and grant unto you, or any three or more of you, full power at any place in Our United Kingdom or in India or elsewhere in Our Dominions to call before you such persons as you shall judge likely to afford you any information, upon the subject of this Our Commission : and also whether in Our said Kingdom, or in India, or elsewhere in Our Dominions to call for information in writing; to call for, have access to and examine all such books, documents, registers and records as may afford you the fullest information on the subject, and to inquire of and concerning the premises by all other lawful ways and means whatsoever, including the appointment by the Commission with the sanction of Our Secretary of State for India, of any person or persons to make subordinate enquiries and to report the result to the Commission :
('40', 499, 5, 6, 1163082) And We do by these presents authorize and empower you or any of you to visit and inspect personally such places as you may deem it expedient so to inspect for the more effectual carrying out of the purposes aforesaid :
('40', 499, 6, 7, 1163301) And We do by these presents will and ordain that this Our Commission shall
('40', 499, 7, 8, 1163376) 1Vide “Interview to the Associated Press”, 1 12 1927. 2 Stephen Walsh having resigned for reasons of ill health, Vernon Hartshorn was appointed in his place on December 7, 1927.
('40', 500, 0, 1, 1163554) VOL. 40 : 2 SEPTEMBER, 1927 1 DECEMBER, 1927 501
('40', 500, 1, 2, 1163603) continue in full force and virtue, and that you, Our said Commissioners, or any three or more of you, may from time to time proceed in the execution thereof, and of very matter and thing therein contained, although the same be not continued from time to time by adjournment :
('40', 500, 2, 3, 1163879) And We do further ordain that you, or any three or more of you, have liberty to report your proceedings under this Our Commission from time to time if you shall judge it expedient so to do :
('40', 500, 3, 4, 1164070) And Our further will and pleasure is that you do, with as little delay as possible, report to Us under your hands and seals, or under the hands and seals of any three or more of you, your opinion upon the matters herein submitted for your consideration.
